(Ord. 522, § 1, 5-7-2013; Ord. 485, § 1, 12-20-2011; Ord. 377, § 1, 9-2-2008; Ord. 75, § 3, 2003; Ord. 382, § 1, 1996; prior code § 2-3-4; Ord. No. 683, § 1, 6-6-2017) 
2.16.050 - Duties and powers of city officials. 
A.  City officers and employees listed in this chapter shall have those powers, duties and responsibilities as provided for by state law, city ordinances, city position descriptions (on file with the city administrator) and individual employment contracts. City officers and employees shall perform such other duties and responsibilities not inconsistent with law as may be prescribed by the mayor, common council and/or city administrator. 
B.  Officers whose powers and duties are not enumerated in Chapter 62, Wisconsin Statutes, shall have such powers and duties as are prescribed by law for like officers or as directed by the council. 
C.  All officers and departments may make the necessary rules for the conduct of their duties and incidental proceedings consistent with this Code of Ordinances. 
D.  The general laws for the punishment of bribery, misdemeanors and corruption in office, shall apply to city officers. 
E.  Whenever a city official in his or her official capacity proceeded against or is obliged to proceed before any court, board or commission, to defend or maintain his or her official position, or because of some act arising out of the performance of his or her official duties, and he or she has prevailed in such proceedings, or the council has ordered the proceedings discontinued, the council may provide for payment to such official such sum as it sees fit, to reimburse him or her for the expenses reasonably incurred for costs and attorney's fees. 
(Ord. 522, § 1, 5-7-2013; Ord. 377, § 1, 9-2-2008; prior code § 2-3-15) 
2.16.060 - Oath of office-Bonds of officers. 
A.  Oath. Every person elected or appointed to any statutory office shall take and file his or her official oath within ten (10) days after notice of his or her election or appointment. 
B.  Bonds. The treasurer, clerk, municipal judge and such other statutory officers as the laws of Wisconsin or the common council may direct, shall execute and file an official bond in such form as the council may determine. The council may at any time require new or additional bonds of any officer. All official bonds must be approved by the mayor, and when so approved, then be filed within ten (10) days after the officer executing the same shall have been notified of this election or appointment. Official bonds, excepting for that of the municipal judge, which shall be filed with the clerk of circuit court, shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be recorded by him in a book kept by him or her for that purpose. 
(Ord. 377, § 1, 9-2-2008; prior code § 2-3-16) 
2.16.070 - Terms of office. 
    The regular terms of office of the mayor and alderpersons shall commence on the third Tuesday of April succeeding their election. The regular terms of other officers shall commence on the first day of May succeeding their election, unless otherwise provided by ordinance, employment contract or the Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 377, § 1, 9-2-2008; prior code § 2-3-17) 
2.16.080 - Combination of appointive offices. 
    More than one appointive office may be held by the same person when such offices, as so combined, are deemed compatible by the mayor and common council. In event of consolidation of statutory offices, a Charter ordinance shall be required. 
(Ord. 377, § 1, 9-2-2008; prior code § 2-3-18) 
2.16.090 - Rule making authority. 
A.  Authorization for Department Heads. Heads of departments of the city may make rules, regulations, or directives for the administration of their departments, but not for the conduct of the general public. 
B.  Approval of Rules. Any proposed departmental rule, regulation, or directive other than those proposed by the police or fire department shall be referred to the city administrator for review. All rules shall be consistent with city ordinances, resolutions and the city personnel rules and regulations manual. Any rule, or any part thereof, returned by the city administrator to the department head shall be deemed to be unacceptable and not in force. 
C.  Time of Taking Effect. All proposed rules, regulations, or directives shall be effective thirty (30) calendar days after presentation to the city administrator, unless returned by either the city administrator, or the common council acts by resolution to nullify such rule. In emergency situations requiring immediate actions, rules may become effective immediately; but all rules so enacted shall be reported to the city administrator within twenty-four (24) hours, with the reasons for the necessity of immediate implementation. All emergency rules are temporary in nature, and must be formally presented as required in subsection B. of this section to become permanent rules. 
(Ord. 522, § 1, 5-7-2013; Ord. 377, § 1, 9-2-2008; prior code § 2-3-19) 
2.16.100 - Deputy city clerk. 
A.  Position of Deputy City Clerk. There is created the position of deputy city clerk to act as city clerk when the city clerk, due to vacation, absence, disability, vacancy or other authorized time away from the position, is unable or not available to perform the duties of that position. 
B.  Bond Requirement. The acts of the deputy city clerk shall be covered by official bond as the common council shall direct. 
(Ord. 377, § 1, 9-2-2008; Ord. 268, § 1, 8-15-2006; prior code § 2-3-20) 
Chapter 2.20 - CODE OF ETHICS 
Sections: 

2.20.010 - Ethical standards of public officials-Declaration of policy. 
    The proper operation of democratic government requires that public officials and employees be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made in proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of the government. In recognition of these goals, there is established a code of ethics for all city officials and employees, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid, including members of boards, committees and commissions of the city. The purpose of this chapter is to establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials and employees by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible with the best interests of the city and by directing disclosure by such officials and employees of private financial or other interests in matters affecting the city. The provisions and purpose of this chapter and such rules and regulations as may be established are declared to be in the best interests of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-5-1) 
2.20.020 - Responsibilities of public office. 
A.  Public officials and employees are bound to observe in their official acts the highest standards of morality and to discharge faithfully the duties of their office regardless of personal considerations, recognizing that the public interest must be their primary concern. Their conduct in both their official and private affairs shall be above reproach. 
B.  Public officials are bound to uphold the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the state and to carry out impartially the law of the nation, state and municipality. 
(Prior code § 2-5-2) 
2.20.030 - Dedicated service. 
A.  All officials and employees of the city should be loyal to the objectives expressed by the electorate and the programs developed to attain these objectives. Appointive officials and employees should adhere to the rules of work and performance established as the standard for their positions by the appropriate authority. 
B.  Public officials and employees shall not exceed their authority or breach law or ask others to do so, and they shall work in full cooperation with other public officials and employees unless prohibited from doing so by law or by officially recognized confidentiality of their work. 
(Prior code § 2-5-3) 
2.20.040 - Use of public property-Obligations of citizens. 
A.  Use of Public Property. No public official or employee shall request, use or permit the use of city-owned vehicles, equipment, materials or property for personal convenience or profit, except when authorized by the city's personnel policies. 
B.  Obligation of Citizen. No public official or employee shall grant any special consideration, treatment or advantage to any citizen beyond that which is available to every other citizen. 
(Prior code § 2-5-4) 
2.20.050 - Conflict of interest. 
    No official or employee, whether paid or unpaid, shall engage in any business or transaction or shall have a financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his or her official duties in the public judgment or will tend to impair his or her independence or judgment or action, in the performance of his or her official duties. 
(Prior code § 2-5-5) 
2.20.060 - Specific conflicts of interest. 
    Specific conflicts of interest are enumerated below for the guidance of officials. The following list is illustrative merely and not exclusive: 
A.  Incompatible Employment. No alderperson or other public official or employee shall engage in or accept private employment or render services for private interests when such employment or service is incompatible with the proper discharge of his or her official duties or tends to impair his or her independence of judgement or action in the performance of his or her official duties. In the event an alderperson, official or employee possesses a financial or personal interest in any business or transaction, any presumption of conflict of interest with his or her public duties shall be removed by his disclosure of the nature and extent of such investment to the common council for the records of that authority. 
B.  Disclosure of Confidential Information. No alderperson, other public official or employee, shall, without proper legal authorization, disclose confidential information concerning the property, government or affairs of the city, nor shall he or she use such information to advance the financial or other private interest of himself or herself or others. 
C.  Gifts and Favors. No alderperson or other public official or employee shall accept any gift, whether in the form of service, loan, thing or promise, from any person who to his knowledge is interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in business dealings with the city, except as permitted by the city's personnel policies. 
D.  Representing Private Interests Before City Agencies or Courts. No alderperson or other public official or employee whose salary is paid in whole or in part by the city shall appear in behalf of private interests before any agency of the city. He or she shall not represent private interests in any action or proceeding against the interest of the city in any proceedings to which the city is a party. 
E.  Contracts with the City. No city employee, officer or other public official who in his or her capacity as such officer, employee or public official shall participate in the making of a contract in which he or she has a private pecuniary interest, direct or indirect, or perform in regard to that contract some function requiring the exercise of discretion on his or her part, shall enter into any contract with the city unless within the exceptions contained in Section 946.13(2), Wisconsin Statutes. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the designation of a public depository of public funds, nor to contracts in any one year under five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
F.  Use of Office for Personal Gain. An elected official shall not use his or her elected office or title to develop any personal financial gain. 
G.  Disclosure of Interest in Legislation. 
1.  An alderperson who has a financial or other private interest in any legislation shall disclose on the records of the council the nature and extent of such interest. This provision shall not apply if the alderperson disqualified himself or herself from voting and council discussion of the matter. 
2.  Any other appointed or elected public official or employee, including citizen members of boards and commissions, who has a financial or other private interest, and who participates in discussion with or gives an official opinion to the council shall disclose on the record of the council the nature and extent of such interest. 
(Ord. 327, § 1, 8-21-2007; Ord. 496 § 1, 2000; prior code § 2-5-6) 
2.20.070 - Advisory opinion. 
    Any questions as to the interpretation of any provisions of the code of ethics chapter shall be referred to the city attorney for an advisory opinion and such opinion shall be given to the common council for its action, if any. 
(Prior code § 2-5-7) 
2.20.080 - Sanctions. 
    Violation of any provision of this section should raise conscientious questions for the alderpersons or any other official or employee concerned as to whether voluntary resignation or other action is indicated to promote the best interest of the city. Violation may constitute a cause for suspension, removal from office or employment, or other disciplinary action. 
(Prior code § 2-5-8) 
Chapter 2.24 - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.24.010 - Chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall be appointed by the police and fire commission pursuant to Section 62.13, Wisconsin Statutes, and shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by the commission for cause. 
(Prior code § 2-3-11) 
2.24.020 - Organization of police department. 
    The police department shall consist of a chief of police, and such other officers, assistants, and patrol officers as from time to time may be appointed, pursuant to the provisions of the Wisconsin Statutes, the ordinances and resolutions of the common council, and the rules and regulations of the board of police and fire commissioners. 
(Prior code § 5-1-1) 
2.24.030 - Records and reports. 
A.  Monthly Reports. The chief of police shall submit a written monthly report to the common council, of all activities and transactions of the department during the preceding month. 
B.  Police Records. There shall be kept by the department, a suitable record in which shall be entered the name of every person arrested in the city, the name of the person making the arrest, the date and cause of the arrest, the court from which the warrant was issued, the disposition made of the case, the amount of fine and costs paid and to whom paid, bond posted and all complaints in full. 
(Prior code § 5-1-2) 
2.24.040 - General powers of police officers. 
    Every member of the police department shall: 
A.  Familiarize himself or herself with the ordinances of the city and the state statutes and attend to the enforcement of such ordinances by all lawful means; 
B.  Help prevent crimes, misdemeanors and violations of city ordinances and protect the health, safety, public peace and order of the city and its inhabitants; 
C.  Report all street and sidewalk obstructions, unlighted street lamps, unlawful street signs or signals and defective or dangerous streets and sidewalks to the appropriate person or organization responsible for their repair or service; 
D.  Maintain order at the scene of a fire or any other fire response within the city; 
E.  See that the necessary permits and licenses issued by the state or city are in the possession of or properly displayed by any person engaged in an activity or business within the city for which such permit or license is required and that the terms of such permits or licenses are complied with; 
F.  Perform such other lawful duties as ordered by the chief of police or his or her authorized representative. 
(Prior code § 5-1-3) 
2.24.050 - Responsibilities of chief of police. 
A.  Duties. In addition to the duties imposed upon him or her elsewhere in this code of ordinances, the chief of police shall: 
1.  Have command of the police department on administrative matters, subject to the direction of the mayor, to the extent that the council may delegate such authority of direction to him or her; 
2.  Cause to be maintained accurate records of complaints, crimes, traffic accidents, ordinance violations, arrests, summons, incidents and calls for police service and shall provide a system of periodic summary and analysis to ensure the most efficient and effective deployment and use of the department's resources. He or she shall submit or cause to be submitted to the various agencies such reports and summaries as are required by state statutes or ordinances and shall participate in voluntary programs designed to improve law enforcement and public safety; 
3.  Submit such reports and comply with such administrative procedures as may be prescribed by the city administrator relative to fiscal and administrative matters; 
4.  Submit such reports and/or information and comply with such policies as may be prescribed by common council; 
5.  Have exclusive control of the assignment, hours of duty and transfer of all members of the department; 
6.  Plan, organize, staff, direct and control all of the human and material resources of the department for the most effective and efficient discharge of its duty to protect persons and property, preserve the peace, protect the rights of citizens and enforce the Wisconsin Statutes and the ordinances of the city as are within its jurisdiction. He or she shall supervise the preparation and presentation of annual reports and budgets for the police department. He or she shall be required to certify to the correctness of all bills incurred by the department; 
7.  Strive to maintain suitable, productive relationships with other city departments and with other governmental agencies and private organizations concerned with law enforcement, crime prevention, administration of justice and public safety. He or she shall cooperate and exchange information with other city departments in matters relating to their various functions; 
8.  Plan and execute programs designed to prevent and repress crime, apprehend and prosecute offenders, recover property and regulate noncriminal conduct, giving highest priority in the allocation of resources to crime and other offenses most hazardous to life and property. 
B.  Custody of Department Equipment. The chief of police shall be the custodian of all city property, equipment and supplies under the control of, or used by, the police department, and shall be responsible for the care, maintenance, safeguarding and accurate records of such property, equipment and supplies. 
C.  Custody of Department Property. The chief of police shall be the custodian of all property and shall be responsible for the safekeeping, lawful disposition and accurate record of the same. He or she shall see that all property is returned to its lawful owner or otherwise disposed of according to the applicable statutes. 
(Prior code § 5-1-4) 
2.24.060 - Rules and policies for the police department. 
    The chief of police shall establish and promulgate, rules of conduct, directives and policies and procedures and prescribe such duties for individual members as he or she may deem necessary for the effective and efficient command and operation of the department; providing no such rules of conduct, directive or policy procedure duties or assignment shall be in conflict with the statutes, ordinances and approved city personnel rules and regulations. 
(Prior code § 5-1-5) 
2.24.070 - Maintenance of personnel records and performance evaluations. 
    The chief of police shall cause to be maintained adequate personnel records of employment, assignment, promotions, attendance, performance and training for all members of the department. He or she shall also comply with all provisions of the law enforcement standards board in regard to background investigations. He or she shall keep himself or herself adequately informed of the activities of the department and be assured that the duties of his or her subordinates are properly discharged. He or she shall formulate procedures for recognizing outstanding performance by department members, for investigating complaints of misconduct by any department member and for taking appropriate disciplinary action subject to the provisions of the applicable statutes and rules of the department. 
(Prior code § 5-1-6) 
2.24.080 - Police chief's responsibility for training. 
    The chief of police is responsible for the training of all members of the department. He or she shall cause adequate and progressive programs or training to be organized and conducted to prepare department members in the knowledge, procedures and techniques of their duties and responsibilities. He or she will insure that, within budgetary limitations, members of the department attend training courses, seminars and conferences necessary to maintain and improve their job skills and professional knowledge. He or she shall encourage department members to further their education in law enforcement through study, special courses, college attendance, extension programs and independent readings. 
(Prior code § 5-1-7) 
2.24.090 - Civilians to assist. 
    All persons in the city, when called upon by any police officer or peace officer, shall promptly aid and assist him or her in the execution of his or her duties and whoever shall neglect or refuse to give such aid or assistance shall be subject to the general penalty as provided in Title 1 of this code of ordinances. 
(Prior code § 5-1-8) 
2.24.100 - Law enforcement personnel expenses pursuant to intermunicipal agreement. 
A.  The City of Sun Prairie, pursuant to Section 66.0101(4), Wisconsin Statutes, hereby elects not to be governed by those portions of Section 66.0513, Wisconsin Statutes, relating to reimbursement of police expenses when acting outside municipal limits, which are in conflict with this ordinance [section]. 
B.  Whenever Sun Prairie law enforcement personnel are serving in the City of Fitchburg or the City of Middleton, the requesting city shall be responsible for all disability payments, worker's compensation claims, damage to equipment and clothing, and medical expenses arising out of these activities. Wage, pension and all other benefits other than disability payments, worker's compensation claims, damage to equipment and clothing and medical expenses shall be paid by Sun Prairie without reimbursement from Middleton or Fitchburg. 
C.  Whenever Fitchburg or Middleton law enforcement personnel are serving in Sun Prairie, Sun Prairie shall be responsible for all disability payments, worker's compensation claims, damage to equipment and clothing, and medical expenses arising out of these activities. Wage, pension and all other benefits other than disability payments, worker's compensation claims, damage to equipment and clothing and medical expenses shall be paid by Middleton or Fitchburg without reimbursement from Sun Prairie. 
D.  Effective Date. 
1.  This ordinance [section] shall take effect upon notice that the Common Councils of Middleton, Sun Prairie and Fitchburg have approved a Police Cooperation Intergovernmental Agreement containing the language specified in subsections B. and C. herein. This ordinance [section] shall become null and void upon the city no longer being party to the agreement. 
2.  This is a Charter Ordinance, and shall take effect sixty (60) days after its passage and publication unless within such sixty-day period a referendum petition, as provided by Section 66.0101(5), Wisconsin Statutes, shall be filed, in which event this ordinance [section] shall not take effect until it shall have been submitted to a referendum vote of the electors and approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon. 
(Chtr. Ord. 215, § 1, 9-20-2005) 
Chapter 2.28 - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

2.28.010 - Fire chief and officers. 
    When the City of Sun Prairie contracts for fire services, the fire service provider shall nominate each of its officers, including but not limited to its chief, assistant chief, captain, fire ground officers and firefighters of each class as required by the department. Said nomination(s) shall be submitted to and subject to confirmation by the executive committee of the fire advisory committee. Fire department will cooperate fully with the executive committee of the fire advisory committee in establishing criteria for nomination and hiring of all individuals interested in employment. In the event of a vacancy or incapacity of an officer, the next ranking officer of the department shall perform the duties of said vacancy until the vacancy is filled. Officers shall continue to serve in their approved position while in good standing. All promotional activity for fire service provision is subject to approval of the executive committee of the fire advisory committee. 
(Ord. 584, § 1, 12-16-2014; Ord. 548, § 1, 11-19-2013) 
Editor's note- Ord. 548, § 1, adopted November 19, 2013, repealed the former § 2.28.010, and enacted a new § 2.28.010 as set out herein. The former § 2.28.010 pertained to the fire chief and derived from prior code § 2-3-12 and Ord. 255, § 1, 1993. 
2.28.020 - Impeding fire equipment prohibited. 
    No person shall impede the progress of the fire engine or fire truck or other fire apparatus of the Sun Prairie fire department along the streets or alleys of such city at the time of a fire or when the fire department of the city is using such streets or alleys in response to a fire alarm or for practice. 
(Prior code § 5-2-1) 
2.28.030 - Police power of the department-Investigation of fires. 
A.  Police Authority at Fires. 
1.  The chief and assistants or officers in command at any fire are vested with full and complete police authority at fires. Any officer of the department may cause the arrest of any person failing to give the right-of-way to the fire department in responding to a fire. 
2.  The fire chief may prescribe certain limits in the vicinity of any fire within which no persons, excepting fire fighters and police officers and those admitted by order of any officer of the department, shall be permitted to come. 
3.  The chief shall have the power to cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire or to prevent the spreading of fire or to protect the adjoining property, and during the progress of any fire he or she shall have the power to cause the removal of all wires or other facilities and the turning off of all electricity or other services where the same impedes the work of the department during the progress of a fire. 
B.  Fire Inspection Duties. 
1.  The fire chief shall be the fire inspector of the city and shall have the power to appoint one or more deputy fire inspectors and shall perform all duties required of the fire inspectors by the laws of the state and the rules of the department of Industry, Labor and Human Relations, particularly Section 101.14, Wisconsin Statutes. 
2.  While acting as fire inspector pursuant to Section 101.14(2), Wisconsin Statutes, the fire chief, or any officer of the fire department designated by the fire chief, shall have the right and authority to enter any building or upon any premises in the city at all reasonable hours for the purpose of making inspections or investigations which, under the provisions of this code of ordinances, he or she may deem necessary. Should the fire inspector find that any provisions of this code relating to fire hazards and prevention of fires are being violated, or that a fire hazard exists which should be eliminated, it shall be his or her duty to give such directions for the abatement of such conditions as he or she shall deem necessary, and if such directions are not complied with, to report such noncompliance to the city administrator for further action. 
3.  The chief of the fire department is required, by himself or herself or by officers or members of the fire department designated by him or her as fire inspectors, to inspect all buildings, premises, and public thoroughfares, except the interiors of private dwellings, for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire, or any violations of any law or ordinance relating to the fire hazard or to the prevention of fires. Such inspections shall be made at least once in six months in all of the territory served by such fire department, and not less than once in three months in such territory as the common council has designated or thereafter designates as within the fire limits or as a congested district subject to conflagration, and more often as the chief of the fire department orders. Each six-month period shall begin on January 1 and July 1, and each three-month period on January 1, April 1, July 1 and October 1 of each year. 
4.  Written reports of inspections shall be made and kept on file in the office of the chief of the fire department in the manner and form required by the Department of Industry, Labor and Human Relations. A copy of such reports shall be filed with the city clerk. 
5.  The fire chief or deputy fire inspectors may issue citations for violations of any provision of this Code of Ordinances. Persons cited under this provision are subject to penalties as provided in the general penalty provisions, Section 1.24.010 of this Code. The fire chief or deputy fire inspector shall also have the power granted under Section 8.44.060 of this Code and under state law to abate violations of the fire code which constitute public nuisances. 
(Prior code § 5-2-2) 
2.28.040 - Damaging fire hose prohibited-Parking by hydrants-Blocking fire lanes. 
A.  Driving Over Fire Hose. No person shall willfully injure in any manner, any hose, hydrant or fire apparatus belonging to the city, and no vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the fire department when laid down on any street, private driveway or other place, to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire department official in command. 
B.  Parking Vehicles Near Hydrants. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle or leave any object within ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant at any time. 
C.  No Parking Near Fire. It shall be unlawful for any person, in case of fire, to drive or park any vehicle within one block from the place of fire without the consent and authority of the fire chief or any police officer. 
(Prior code § 5-2-3) 
2.28.050 - Firemen may enter adjacent property. 
A.  Entering Adjacent Property. It shall be lawful for any fire fighter while acting under the direction of the fire chief or other officer in command to enter upon the premises adjacent to or in the vicinity of any building or other property then on fire for the purpose of extinguishing such fire and in case any person shall hinder, resist or obstruct any fire fighter in the discharge of his or her duty as is hereinbefore provided, the person so offending shall be deemed guilty of resisting fire fighters in the discharge of their duty. 
B.  Destruction of Property to Prevent the Spread of Fire. During the progress of any fire the fire chief or his or her assistant shall have the power to order the removal or destruction of any property necessary to prevent the further spread of fire; provided that it is inevitable that unless such property is removed, other property is in danger of being destroyed by fire. 
(Prior code § 5-2-4) 
2.28.060 - Duty of bystanders to assist. 
    Every person who shall be present at a fire shall be subject to the orders of the fire chief or officer in command and may be required to render assistance in fighting the fire or in removing or guarding property. Such officer shall have the power to cause the arrest of any person or persons refusing to obey such orders. 
(Prior code § 5-2-5) 
2.28.070 - Vehicles to yield right-of-way. 
    Whenever there shall be a fire or fire alarm, or the fire department shall be out for practice, every person driving or riding in a motorized or other vehicle shall move and remain to the side of the street until the fire engine and fire truck and other fire apparatus shall have passed. 
(Prior code § 5-2-6) 
2.28.080 - Interference with use of hydrants prohibited. 
    No person shall occupy any portion of such streets or alleys with a motorized or other vehicle between such fire engine or fire truck or other fire apparatus or any hydrant to which a fire hose may be, or may be about to be attached. 
(Prior code § 5-2-7) 
2.28.090 - Ambulance fees. 
    Ambulance fees shall be established by resolution of the city council. Ambulance fees may be amended from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 157, § 1, 8-3-2004; Ord. 2001-22, § 1, 2001) 
Chapter 2.32 - MUNICIPAL COURT 
Sections: 

2.32.010 - Municipal judge-Municipal court. 
A.  Established. Pursuant to the authority granted by Chapter 755, Wisconsin Statutes, there is established the municipal court for the city. 
B.  Office of Municipal Judge Created. Pursuant to the authority granted by Chapter 755, Wisconsin Statutes, there is created the office of municipal judge for the municipal court for the city. To be eligible for the office of municipal judge, a person must be an attorney licensed to practice law and in good standing in the State of Wisconsin. The person must have been so licensed for five years immediately prior to election or appointment. Should any eligibility condition not be met or in the event the conditions of Section (E) are not met, the office shall be deemed vacant. 
C.  Election-Term. The municipal judge shall be elected at large at the spring election on the odd numbered years for a term of two years with the term commencing on May 1 succeeding the election. Effective with the April 1991 election and all subsequent elections the term of the municipal judge shall be for a term of four years. The municipal judge shall be subject to the Wisconsin Code of Judicial Ethics and shall file an annual financial statement. 
D.  Salary. The salary of the municipal judge may be increased for a new term prior to the beginning of the term for the judge, and before the beginning of each succeeding year of the term. 
E.  Bond-Oath. The municipal judge shall execute and file with the clerk of the circuit court for Dane County the oath prescribed by Section 755.03, Wisconsin Statutes, and an official bond in such amount as shall be fixed by the common council. 
F.  Procedure in Municipal Court. 
1.  The procedure in municipal court for the city shall be as provided by the ordinance codified in this chapter and state law, including, but not by way of limitation, Chapters 62, 66, 755, and 800, Wisconsin Statutes. 
2.  The municipal court shall be open as determined by the municipal judge. 
3.  The municipal judge shall keep his or her office and hold court in the Sun Prairie municipal building, or such other place as the common council shall, from time to time, designate. 
4.  If the municipal judge is temporarily absent, sick or disabled, the provisions of Section 800.06(1), Wisconsin Statutes, shall apply, and if the municipal judge becomes incompetent, unable or fails to act, or in the event of a vacancy, the provisions of Section 800.06(2), Wisconsin Statutes, shall apply. Any substitute municipal judge designated or assigned hereunder shall be compensated by the municipal judge from the municipal court budget. 
5.  Upon the proper and timely written request for substitution of the municipal judge, the provisions of Section 800.05, Wisconsin Statutes, shall apply. 
6.  The procedures of the municipal court shall be in accord with the applicable Wisconsin Statutes and city ordinances. The court shall abide by the Wisconsin Rules of Evidence and shall abide by the Uniform State Traffic Deposit Schedule. In nontraffic matters, the municipal judge shall draft a bond schedule, which shall become effective upon approval by the common council. No bond shall exceed the maximum penalty which could be imposed for the ordinance violation. The police chief shall be furnished a copy of all bond schedules and amendments thereto. 
7.  The municipal judge may impose a forfeiture for contempt. Upon any nonpayment of such forfeiture and any applicable costs, fees, assessments, charges, surcharges, and penalties, the municipal judge may impose a jail sentence. The municipal judge may impose the maximum forfeiture and maximum jail sentence allowed by law. 
G.  Fees. 
1.  Bonds for appearance, partial payments and other funds collected by the court shall be treated as escrow funds and deposited in the municipal court banking account. 
2.  The municipal judge shall collect all forfeitures, and costs in any action or proceeding before him or her and shall pay over such moneys to the city treasurer not later than the fifteenth business day succeeding the end of each month. At the time of payment, the municipal judge shall report to the city treasurer the title of the action, the offense for which the forfeiture was imposed and the total amount of the forfeiture, fees, penalty assessments and costs, if any. The city treasurer shall disburse the fees as provided in Section 814.65, Wisconsin Statutes, and disburse any penalty assessments pursuant to Section 66.12(1)(b), Wisconsin Statutes. 
H.  Council May Abolish Municipal Court. The city council may by ordinance or by law abolish the municipal court at the end of any term for which the judge has been elected. 
I.  Statutes Adopted by Reference. Chapters 755 and 800, Wisconsin Statutes, are adopted by reference, including any and all future amendments, revisions or modifications of such statutes, which are incorporated herein by reference and are intended to be made a part of this Code. 
J.  Municipal Court Costs. Court costs in municipal court shall be thirty-eight dollars ($38.00). 
( Ord. No. 734, § 1, 5-15-2018 ; Ord. 549, § 1, 11-26-2013; Ord. 343, § 1, 11-6-2007; Ord. 533 § 1, 2000; Ord. 438 § 1, 1998; prior code § 2-3-13) 
2.32.020 - Court clerk-Deputy court clerk. 
A.  Appointment. The municipal judge shall employ such court clerk and deputy clerks as he or she deems necessary. Such clerk or deputy clerks shall receive salaries as determined by the municipal judge, such salaries to be paid from the compensation from the city to the municipal judge for total municipal court expenses. The clerk(s) shall, before entering upon the duties of their office, take the oath provided by Section 19.01, Wisconsin Statutes, and give such bond as the council may require. Oath and bonds of the clerk and deputy clerk(s) of municipal court shall be filed with the city clerk. 
B.  Duties. The court clerk and deputy court clerk(s) shall: 
1.  File and review citations and complaints, assuring their correctness; 
2.  Reply to departmental mail concerning routine matters as prescribed by the municipal judge; 
3.  Assign docket numbers to citations and complaints, type the docket sheets and gather all material pertinent to cases; 
4.  Determine and schedule court dates and facilities; 
5.  Arrange for juvenile cases to be heard away from regular court; 
6.  Communicate with law officers, attorneys and defendants regarding court proceedings; 
7.  Balance dockets at conclusion of court proceedings; 
8.  Prepare and mail warrants and summons; 
9.  Prepare monthly report of financial activities; 
10.  Assist in the collection of traffic bonds; 
11.  Prepare necessary communications for jury trials and transfers to circuit court; 
12.  Perform such other duties as may be required by the municipal judge and city administrator. 
(Prior code § 2-3-14) 
Chapter 2.36 - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES GENERALLY 

2.36.010 - General provisions regarding meetings and public notice. 
A.  Regular Meetings-Public Notice. Every board, committee and commission created by or existing under the ordinances of the city shall: 
1.  Fix a regular date, time and place for its meetings; 
2.  All meeting notices shall be filed with the city clerk who shall cause the notice to be published and posted in full compliance with the open meeting law requirements; 
3.  Publish notice in the official city newspaper in advance of each such regular meeting of the date, time and place for its meetings; 
4.  Post, at the front door of the city hall, an agenda of the matters to be taken up at such meeting. 
B.  Special Meetings. Nothing in subsection A of this section shall preclude the calling of a special meeting or with dispensing with the publication of notice or such posting of the agenda, for good cause, but such special meetings shall nonetheless comply in all respects with the provisions of Sections 19.81 to 19.89, Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Prior code § 2-4-12) 
2.36.020 - Residency required for service on boards, commissions and committees. 
A.  Appointments. No person not a resident of and not residing in the city shall be appointed to any city board, commission or committee, except as provided for in paragraph B. Any board commission member who moves from the city shall immediately be removed from the board or commission. However, the library board and the historical library and museum board, pursuant to state law, may have as members up to two persons who reside in towns adjacent to the city. 
B.  Nonresident Appointments. 
1.  A nonresident may be appointed to serve on a city board, commission or committee as a representative of another governmental body or as a representative of an organization that has a significant presence in the city. Also, a nonresident may be appointed to serve on a city board, commission or committee if they hold expertise in a field that would benefit the work of the city board, commission or committee to which they are appointed. 
2.  The city clerk shall identify that a nonresident has been nominated to serve on a city board, commission or committee prior to council action on the nomination. 
C.  Exceptions. A member of any business improvement district board need not reside in the city and is excepted from the requirements of subsection A. of this section provided such person owns or occupies real property in the business improvement district. 
(Ord. 150, § 1, 7-6-2004; prior code § 2-4-15) 
2.36.030 - Compensation of duly appointed board and commission members. 
    Effective January 1, 1994, all board and commission members attending scheduled board and commission meetings shall be compensated twenty dollars ($20.00) per meeting, and any member of the police and fire commission that shall participate in a grievance hearing meeting shall be compensated at twenty dollars ($20.00) per grievance meeting, except the water and light commission which will continue to receive thirty dollars ($30.00) per meeting. The board of review members shall receive twenty dollars ($20.00) per day instead of per meeting. 
(Ord. 292, § 1, 1993; prior code § 2-4-16) 
2.36.040 - Business improvement district board. 
    Any business improvement district board which becomes necessary due to the creation of a business improvement district pursuant to Section 66.608, Wisconsin Statutes, shall be established and have the powers and duties as enumerated in Section 66.608, Wisconsin Statutes, as amended; as provided in the operating plan for that district as adopted by the common council; and as provided generally in this code of ordinances. The chamber of commerce shall appoint one of its members or employees as a liaison to any business improvement district established by the city. The liaison shall function as an ex officio nonvoting member and not be counted for purposes of a quorum. 
(Ord. 365, § 1, 7-1-2008; prior code § 2-4-17) 
Chapter 2.38 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 
Sections: 

2.38.010 - Created. 
    Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1335, the community development authority (the "authority") is created. The authority shall be deemed a separate body politic exercising necessary public powers and having the powers, duties and functions conferred on housing and community development authorities under Wis. Stats. § 66.1335, except as otherwise herein provided. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.020 - Composition. 
    The governing body of the community development authority shall consist of seven commissioners. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.030 - Appointment of commissioners. 
    The mayor shall, subject to confirmation of the common council, nominate six residents of the city having sufficient ability and experience in the fields of urban renewal, community development, and housing, as community development authority commissioners. Two of the commissioners shall be members of the common council and five shall be citizen members. Terms of citizen members shall be four years pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1335(2)(b). 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.040 - Officers. 
A.  The mayor shall serve as a voting member and the chair to the authority as referenced in Section 2.08.030 (B)(6). The commissioners shall annually appoint by a majority vote of those present a vice-chairperson of the authority from among the commissioners, at the first authority meeting in May. Vacancies occurring in the office of vice-chairperson shall be filled from among the commissioners for the unexpired portion of the term. 
B.  The director of community development shall be the executive director of the authority and shall be the chief administrative officer of the authority and shall direct, manage and supervise the authority's administrative operations and technical activities in accordance with the directives of the authority. The executive director shall also act as secretary of the authority and shall perform such other duties and have such other powers and responsibilities as may, from time to time, be delegated to him/her by the authority. 
C.  In carrying out its duties, the authority may form committees of commissioners or others, hold public meetings and utilize the services of the city or other public or private services as it deems necessary, subject to the policy and budgetary approval of the common council. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.050 - Meetings; quorum; bylaws. 
A.  All meetings of the authority shall be held in compliance with the provisions of the state open meeting law, Wis. Stats. § 19.81 et seq. 
B.  Four commissioners shall constitute a quorum of the authority for the purpose of conducting its business and exercising its powers and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the authority upon the affirmative vote of a majority of the commissioners present at any meeting of the authority at which a quorum is present. No vacancy in the membership of the authority shall impair the right of a quorum to exercise the powers and perform the functions of the authority. 
C.  The authority may adopt and from time to time amend or repeal such bylaws and other rules and regulations not inconsistent with applicable law as it deems necessary in the performance of its functions. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.060 - Evidence of authority. 
    The filing of a certified copy of the ordinance from which this section is derived with the clerk shall be prima facie evidence of the authority's right to transact business. In any suit, action or proceedings commenced against the authority, a certified copy of the ordinance from which this section is derived or of this division shall be conclusive evidence that the authority is established and authorized to transact business and exercise its powers. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.070 - Statutory powers. 
    The authority shall have all powers necessary to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.1213, and all powers, duties and functions set out in Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1201, 66.1333, and 66.1335 for housing and community development authorities. In this regard, it is authorized to: 
1.  Exercise all powers, duties and functions of redevelopment authority under Wis. Stats. § 66.1333. 
2.  Act as agent of the city in planning and carrying out community development programs and activities approved by the mayor and common council funded under the Federal Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, 42 USC 5301 et seq., and other federal and state laws relating to housing and community development, and, following review and recommendation by the plan commission, to perform all acts, except development of the general plan of the city and other duties performed by the plan commission, under Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1301 to 66.1337, and 66.1105. 
3.  Act as agent of the city in performing all functions required to be performed by a sponsor of a housing rehabilitation program, as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 66.1325, both within and outside of neighborhoods or areas designated by the common council as reinvestment neighborhoods or areas pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1107 and in performing all other functions related to the operation and administration of the city's housing rehabilitation program and any other programs of rehabilitation financing involving financial assistance from either the federal or state government, or both, in which the city participates. 
4.  Issue bonds in aid of its powers and duties and functions as permitted under Wis. Stats. § 66.1201 or Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1301 to 66.1329, Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1331, 66.1333, or 66.1337. Such bonds are declared to be issued for essential governmental and public purposes and to be public instrumentalities and, together with interest thereon and income therefrom, are exempt from taxes. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.080 - Additional powers. 
    In addition to its statutory powers, the authority is further authorized, within the limits of the funds available for such purposes, to: 
1.  Employ such technical experts and such other agents and employees, permanent and temporary, as may be required from time to time in the performance of its duties and functions. 
2.  Contract with the city or any other agency or entity, public, or private, for the provision by the city, or such agency or entity, of any necessary staff services associated with or required by the authority in the staff of the authority. Any staff services provided to the authority by the city pursuant to such contract shall be coordinated through the executive director of the authority or his/her designee. 
3.  Call upon any department, board, commission or agency of the city for assistance and cooperation in the performance of the authority's duties and functions, and all city departments, boards, commissions and agencies are hereby authorized and directed to cooperate with, and furnish assistance to the authority in the performance of the authority's duties and functions. 
4.  Work with business, education, government, labor and citizens to: 
a.  Retain and expand existing business and commercial enterprises within the city. 
b.  Recruit new businesses and encourage the expansion and diversification of business and commercial enterprises within the city to expand local employment opportunities and the tax base. 
c.  Foster and facilitate economic development activities through cooperative efforts with area business organizations, adjoining municipalities, the county, and the state. 
d.  Assist new and existing businesses through programs and resources which facilitate quality growth and development within the city. 
e.  Publicize and promote the business, employment, residential, educational, and recreational opportunities available in the city. 
f.  Foster, develop, and enhance a sense of community, a positive community image, and civic pride. 
5.  To identify itself as the community and economic development authority in anything other than contracts, resolutions, and financial reports. 
6.  The authority has the power to purchase and sell property with the chair having the powers to sign all documents required for purchase and sale of such property. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.090 - Manner of proceeding. 
    The authority and its commissioners shall comply or cause compliance strictly with all provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1201 to 66.1211 and state law and in addition thereto, with each and every term, provision and covenant in any contract of the authority on its part to be kept or performed. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.100 - Plans; recommendation; reports. 
    The authority in consultation with the city plan commission and other appropriate bodies and staff shall: 
1.  Prepare and periodically update an economic development plan and development strategy for use by the mayor and common council. In formulating said plan, the authority shall monitor and evaluate economic conditions in the city, identify economic problem areas, and prioritize any economic problems identified. 
2.  Consider alternative approaches to improving economic deficiencies in the city in problem areas identified. 
3.  Recommend specific programs and projects to allocate available city resources among the elements of the city's economic development effort. 
4.  Recommend items for inclusion in the annual city budget to implement the development strategy adopted by the common council. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.110 - Budget. 
    The authority together with the economic development director shall prepare an annual budget which shall be submitted to the mayor as part of the general budget process. The budget shall include estimated fees for consultants, travel expense for staff, publication costs and other ordinary and necessary expenses. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.120 - Staff. 
    The authority shall receive primary staffing through the offices of the economic development director and the director of community development. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
2.38.120 - Construction. 
    All powers, duties and functions of a community development authority, as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 66.1335 are deemed to have been granted to the authority as though set forth in this section. This section and the powers granted hereunder shall be construed liberally to effectuate its purposes. 
( Ord. No. 702, § 1, 10-17-2017 ) 
Chapter 2.40 - CITY PLAN COMMISSION 

2.40.010 - Composition. 
    The plan commission shall consist of nine voting members as follows: The mayor, two alderpersons, one member of the park and recreation commission, one member of the Sun Prairie area school district board, and four citizens. In addition, the city planner shall serve as an ex officio member of the commission in a nonvoting capacity. The city planner shall be responsible for taking and reporting commission reports in full accordance with city policy. 
(Ord. 465, § 1, 6-7-2011; Ord. 431, § 1 (part), 1998; prior code § 2-4-5(a)) 
2.40.020 - Appointment. 
A.  Election/Appointment of Aldermen Members. At its annual meeting in April of each year the common council shall, by a two-thirds vote of its members, elect one of its number as member of the city plan commission for a period of one year from and after the first day of May next ensuing. The other alderperson shall be appointed by the mayor and serve for the same one-year period. 
B.  Appointment and Terms of Citizen Members. The city plan commission shall consist of nine voting members as follows: The mayor, who shall be its presiding officer, two alderpersons, one member of the park and recreation commission, one member of the Sun Prairie Area School District Board, and four citizens. Citizen members shall be persons of recognized experience and qualifications. The one member of the park and recreation commission and the one member of the Sun Prairie Area School District Board shall be appointed by the mayor for a one-year term. The four citizen members shall be appointed by the mayor for a four-year term. All appointment(s) to the plan commission shall be confirmed by a majority of the common council. 
(Ord. 229, § 1, 12-20-2005; Ord. 431, § 1 (part), 1998; prior code § 2-4-5(b)) 
2.40.030 - Organization. 
    The mayor shall serve as presiding officer. The plan commission shall organize by the election of a vice-chairperson, secretary and such other officers as may in their judgment be necessary. The plan commission shall receive such compensation as determined by the common council. 
(Prior code § 2-4-5(c)) 
2.40.040 - Record. 
    The plan commission shall keep a written record of its proceedings to include all actions taken, a copy of which shall be filed with the city clerk. Five members shall constitute a quorum but all actions shall require the affirmative approval of a majority of all the members of the commission. 
(Ord. 431, § 1 (part), 1998; prior code § 2-4-5(d)) 
Chapter 2.44 - MEDIA CENTER COMMISSION[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 609, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 16, 2015, amended Ch. 2.44 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 2.44, §§ 2.44.010-2.44.050, was entitled "Cable Access Telecommunication Commission" and derived from: Prior code §§ 2-4-9(d), (e); Ord. 579 § 7 (part), 2001; and Ord. 2003-98 §§ 2, 3 (part), 2003. 

2.44.010 - Appointment. 
A.  The media center commission shall be composed of six citizens appointed by the mayor, subject to the approval of the common council each for a term of three years. The commission shall elect its own chairperson yearly. Any vacancy in the office shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to approval by the common council for the remainder of the term. No employee or person with ownership interest in a cable television franchise granted pursuant to this chapter shall be eligible for membership on the commission. No employee or person with financial or familial ties with the Federal Communications Commission shall be eligible for membership on the commission. Names of interested citizens willing and able to serve on the commission shall be accepted and submitted to the mayor for consideration. 
B.  The mayor shall consider the submitted name as well as others as may come to the attention of the mayor as being qualified and every effort shall be made to make said board as broadly representative of the citizens of Sun Prairie as possible. 
(Ord. 609, § 2, 6-16-2015) 
2.44.020 - Powers and duties. 
    The duties of the media center commission shall be as follows: 
A.  The media center commission serves as the city's cable access telecommunications commission as defined in Wisconsin State Statutes § 196.01. 
B.  Advise the common council on applications for franchise. 
C.  Advise the common council on matters, which might constitute grounds for revocation of the franchise in accordance with this chapter. 
D.  Resolve disagreements among franchisee, subscribers, and public and private users of the community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center; such decisions of the commission shall be appealable to the common council. 
E.  Advise the council on the regulation of rates in accordance with this chapter. 
F.  Encourage use and publicize the availability of the community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center among the widest range of institutions, groups and individuals within the city. 
G.  Audit all franchisee records required by this chapter and at the commission's discretion, require the preparation and filing of information additional to that required herein. 
H.  Conduct periodic evaluation of the system, make recommendations to the council for amendments to this chapter or the franchise agreements. 
I.  Assure that all records, rules and charges pertinent to the cable telecommunication network in the city are made available for inspection at reasonable hours upon reasonable notice. 
J.  Ensure that radio station logs as required by the FCC are made available for inspection at any time during normal business hours. 
K.  Confer with the grantee and advise on the interconnection of the city's cable system with other cable communications systems. 
L.  The commission shall be responsible for the overall regulation of the cable provider and the operation of the city's community television and radio facilities in full accordance with the Cable Telecommunication Franchise Enabling Ordinance, as adopted on February 17, 1976, and amended. The commission shall oversee, provide guidance and advisement as to the daily operation of the community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center and keep the common council advised of the status of the community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center. 
M.  The commission shall advise on the safeguarding, maintenance and supervision of the operation of the Sun Prairie Media Center-owned equipment entrusted to its care. 
N.  To facilitate equitable access to community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center for all Sun Prairie citizens seeking access. 
O.  To facilitate the development of programs to increase the public's knowledge and use of the community television and radio facilities which are made available under the franchise. 
P.  Subject to the general fiscal control of the common council the commission shall be responsible for the supervision and operation of the city's community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center. The commission shall make rules for its own proceedings and for the operation of its department. It shall employ a director and shall be authorized to hire additional personnel within the funds approved through the annual budgeting process. All personnel hired by the commission shall be classified as city employees. 
Q.  The commission shall oversee the development of an annual fiscal budget and submit it to the city of Sun Prairie each year. Said budget shall include required expenditures for the regulation and/or operation of the city's community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center including all expenses anticipated to be incurred for the operation and administration of the community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center. 
R.  The commission shall facilitate equal access to all equipment facilities and to the use of the community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center to all members of the community and community groups. Such access shall be negotiated by the Sun Prairie Media Center Director, staff and community member seeking access to community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center. In conjunction with Sun Prairie Media Center staff, the commission shall develop rules which shall govern access within the requirements set forth in this section. All access to community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center and programming for the community television and radio facilities housed at the Sun Prairie Media Center shall be done in full accordance with the policies and procedures established and approved by the commission. 
S.  Funds approved but not expended by the end of each fiscal year shall be carried over into the following fiscal year. Carry over funds shall be included in the subsequent budget for Sun Prairie Media Center. 
T.  The common council shall approve an annual budget as determined by the director and approved by the Media Center Commission. 
U.  The commission shall ensure that the media center director follows the city's purchasing policy for all budgeted funds and shall comply with all city financial reporting requirements. All expenditures shall be done through the city's finance office in full compliance with city operational procedures. All required financial record keeping shall be done in conjunction with the city administrative services and the Sun Prairie Media Center. In addition, the city shall provide payroll service. 
V.  All public access equipment shall remain the property of the Sun Prairie Media Center. All equipment purchased by the Sun Prairie Media Center shall be considered as property owned by the Sun Prairie Media Center. 
W.  The city shall provide all of the required insurance coverage including: workman's compensation, general liability, property and public official liability. The amount of insurance coverage shall equal the amounts set for all city departments. The director shall budget funds so that the city can be reimbursed for the cost of providing said insurance coverage for the Sun Prairie Media Center. 
X.  The commission is authorized to accept the monetary donations and gifts of equipment to the Sun Prairie Media Center for either the community television or radio facilities located at the Sun Prairie Media Center. Such monetary donations shall be so identified and shall be deposited with the city finance officer who shall deposit said donations into the Sun Prairie Media Center's revenue account. The expenditure of donated money and/or the acceptance of the equipment shall not in any fashion commit the city to a higher level of service to the community thereby committing the common council to a level of service not approved through the budget process. 
Y.  Equipment and other expenses totaling under one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the Sun Prairie Media Center will be expended at the discretion of the director. Equipment purchases of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more will need to be brought to the media center commission for a formal vote. Approval by the commission in no way replaces city purchasing policy and the director is expected to comply with all city operational procedures. 
Z.  The media center commission is prohibited from taking on any form of debt without the formal authorization of the common council. 
AA.  The media center commission may authorize the entrance into cooperative agreements with other nonprofit governmental, educational and public service groups or other community television and radio stations in order to produce appropriate community television programs. 
BB.  The city shall retain ultimate control of all public access channels and the expenditure of all budgeted funds. 
(Ord. 609, § 2, 6-16-2015) 
2.44.040 - Recommendations to council. 
    The media center commission shall have the authority to submit proposed rules and regulations for the conduct of its business and the business of the community television and radio facilities located at the Sun Prairie Media Center to the mayor and council for approval, and upon approval, shall have the right to hold hearings and make recommendations to the grantee and to the educational and governmental communities on the coordination of the community television and radio facilities located at the Sun Prairie Media Center. All such actions shall be only advisory. 
(Ord. 609, § 2, 6-16-2015) 
2.44.050 - Children's programming. 
    It shall be the duty of the media center commission to allocate an appropriate share of the media center budget revenues received from the operation of the cable system (franchise payment) to support programming, workshops and other services as deemed desirable by the media center and approved by the media center commission for children. 
(Ord. 609, § 2, 6-16-2015) 
Chapter 2.48 - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION 
Sections: 

2.48.010 - Appointments. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall consist of seven members: one alderperson, the superintendent of the Sun Prairie area school district or the superintendent's designee, and five citizens of recognized experience and qualifications. The alderperson shall be appointed annually by the mayor subject to confirmation by the council for one year terms beginning May 1. One citizen member shall be appointed annually (except for every fourth year, at which time two citizen members shall be appointed) by the mayor subject to confirmation by the common council for a four-year term commencing on May 1. The fifth citizen member shall be appointed for a four-year term commencing on April 6, 1999. The director of parks and recreation shall be an ex officio member of the commission. (Ord. 453 § 1, 1999: prior code § 2-4-6(a)) 
2.48.020 - Compensation-Oath. 
    Commission members shall receive such compensation as shall be determined by the council from time to time. Members shall take an official oath as prescribed by Section 19.01, Wisconsin Statutes, to be filed with the city clerk. (Prior code § 2-4-6(b)) 
2.48.030 - Officers. 
    The commission shall annually elect one member as chairperson. (Prior code § 2-4-6(c)) 
2.48.040 - Procedure. 
    Four members shall constitute a quorum. The chairperson, or acting chairperson, shall be considered in determining a quorum. Action shall be by a majority of those present and voting. The commission shall adopt rules of procedure for governing the conduct of its meetings. (Prior code § 2-4-6(d)) 
2.48.050 - Powers and duties. 
    The commission shall have all the powers conferred by law upon park, recreational, and in cities of the fourth class and shall be chargeable with all the duties so required such as recommend, oversee work, and oversee funds of all parks, playgrounds, and recreational activities as part of properties within the city. The parks and recreation commission is specifically empowered and directed: 
A.  To govern, manage, control, improve and care for all public parks located within, or partly within and partly without, the corporate limits of the city and secure the quiet, orderly and suitable use and enjoyment thereof by the people; also to adopt rules and regulations to promote these purposes; 
B.  To acquire in the name of the city for park purposes by gift, purchase, devise, bequest or condemnation, either absolutely or in trust, money, real or personal property, or in any incorporeal right or privilege, provided gifts to the city of money or other property, real or personal either absolutely or in trust, for park purposes shall be accepted only after they have been recommended by the commission to the common council and approved by such common council by resolution; 
C.  With prior council approval, to buy or lease lands in the name of the city for park purposes within or without the city and with the approval of the common council, to sell or exchange property no longer required for its purposes; 
D.  To execute every trust imposed upon the use of property or property rights by the deed, testament or other conveyance transferring the title of such property to the city for park purposes; 
E.  To have the powers necessary and convenient for the effective and efficient management, control, supervision and operation of the city park system and recreation program, as carried out by the director, subject to budgetary approval by the common council; 
F.  To have jurisdiction of the parks, swimming pool and playgrounds throughout the city and assume full responsibility for the equipping, developing and maintaining the physical facilities of the park system; 
G.  To establish such rules and regulations to promote the quiet, orderly and suitable use of the city parks and playgrounds as the commission shall deem necessary; 
H.  To establish rules and regulations including user fees as deemed necessary as approved by the council, and desirable for the proper use, care and operation of parks, park facilities, recreation programs and other activities under their control, provided however that such rules and regulations do not conflict with the laws of the state of Wisconsin or this code of ordinances. 
I.  And such other and further duties as may be necessary for the proper carrying out of the purposes of such board. (Prior code 2-4-6(e)) 
2.48.060 - Public recreation program. 
    The city parks and recreation commission shall determine the recreational needs and shall have jurisdiction over the public recreation program of the city and shall be empowered to: 
A.  Establish park rules and program policies; 
B.  Cooperate and coordinate with public school activities; 
C.  Cooperate with any private recreational activities; 
D.  Approve schedules of all recreational activities in public parks and school buildings. (Prior code § 2-4-6(f)) 
2.48.070 - Record. 
    The parks and recreation commission shall keep a written record of its proceedings to include all actions taken, a copy of which shall be filed with the city clerk. (Prior code § 2-4-6(g)) 
2.48.080 - Finance. 
A.  Budget. The commission shall assist the director of parks and recreation in preparing an annual budget for submission to the city administrator, which budget shall reflect the commission's recommendations as to maintenance or acquisition of city parks, open spaces, park and related facilities, recreation programs and equipment, summer or seasonal employees, etc. Such annual budget shall contain estimates as to revenues to be derived from recreation programs or activities as well as estimated expenditures for operating the parks and recreation department. The city administrator shall review the budget and submit a recommended budget to the committee of the whole. 
B.  Deposits. All revenues and income from the operation of park and recreation programs shall be deposited with the city finance officer/treasurer as general revenue of the city. 
C.  Monetary Contributions. All moneys donated to the city specifically for park or recreation use shall be deposited in city accounts as a nonlapsing fund or reserve for such specific use. (Prior code § 2-4-6(h)) 
2.48.090 - Meetings. 
    The city parks and recreation commission shall meet at least once each month and a written report of such meetings shall be submitted to the city clerk within one week after such meeting. (Prior code § 2-4-6(i)) 
Chapter 2.52 - POLICE COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. 583, §§ 1, 2, adopted December 16, 2014, repealed the former Chapter 2.52, §§ 2.52.010 and 2.52.020, and enacted a new Chapter 2.52 as set out herein. The former Chapter 2.52 pertained to the police and fire commission and derived from prior code §§ 2-4-8, 5-7-2; Ord. 476, 1999; Ord. 572, 2001; Ord. 218, 10-18-2005 and Ord. 547, adopted November 19, 2013. 

2.52.010 - Board of police commission. 
    The board of police commissioners shall consist of five citizens who are residents of the city, three of whom shall constitute a quorum. The commission shall keep a record of its proceedings. The appointments to the police commission will be made in full compliance with Section 62.13(1), Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 583, § 1, 12-16-2014) 
2.52.020 - Scope of authority. 
A.  The board shall appoint the chief of police who shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by the board for cause. The chief shall appoint subordinates subject to approval by the board. Such appointments shall be made by promotion when this can be done by advantage, otherwise from an eligible list provided by examination, approval by the board and kept on file with the clerk. 
B.  For the choosing of such lists, the board shall adopt and may repeal or modify, rules calculated to secure the best service in the department. These rules shall provide for examination of physical and educational qualifications and experience, and may provide such competitive examinations as the board shall determine and for the classification of positions with special examination for each class. The board shall print and distribute the rules and all changes in them, at city expense. The board shall have such other powers as provided in Section 62.13, Wisconsin Statutes, with the exception of the optional powers provided in Section 62.13(6), Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 583, § 2, 12-16-2014) 
Chapter 2.53 - SUN PRAIRIE FIRE ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

2.53.010 - Sun Prairie Fire Advisory Committee. 
    The Sun Prairie Fire Advisory Committee shall consist of six voting members. The committee shall consist of two members, the Mayor and one member selected by the common council at its annual organizational meeting. The remaining members shall be the President and Vice President of the Sun Prairie Volunteer Fire Department Board of Trustees, or their designees; and two members agreed upon and appointed by the Towns. All members shall be appointed annually on May 1. 
(Ord. 585, § 1, 12-16-2014; Ord. 546, § 1, 11-19-2013; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 6-25-2017 ) 
2.53.020 - Scope of authority. 
    The committee's recommendations are advisory only and the committee has no direct power or authority in regard to the operations, staffing, budget or stature of any department, board or other commission except as specifically set out herein. 
(Ord. 585, § 2, 12-16-2014; Ord. 546, § 2, 11-19-2013) 
2.53.030 - Officers and procedures. 
    Annually, the members will select a chairperson, vice chairperson and secretary from its membership. Four members shall constitute a quorum. Action shall be by a majority of those present and voting. However, termination of the Fire Chief requires five affirmative votes. The committee shall adopt rules and procedures for governing the conduct of its meetings. Such rules shall be fully consistent with Wisconsin State Statutes and this municipal code. The fire advisory committee will have authority to confirm, evaluate and/or discipline the fire chief. The fire advisory committee will have sole authority to terminate the fire chief. The chief will submit to annual performance reviews by the fire advisory committee. 
(Ord. 585, § 3, 12-16-2014; Ord. 546, § 3, 11-19-2013; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 6-25-2017 ) 
2.53.040 - Ex officio members. 
    The fire chief of the Sun Prairie Volunteer Fire Department Company, Inc., the police chief of the City of Sun Prairie, the emergency services director of the City of Sun Prairie and the Sun Prairie City Administrator or their designees shall serve as ex officio, non-voting members not considered as part of a quorum. 
(Ord. 585, § 4, 12-16-2014; Ord. 546, § 4, 11-19-2013; Ord. No. 686, § 1, 6-25-2017 ) 
2.53.050 - Compensation. 
    Committee members shall receive such compensation as shall be determined by council from time to time. 
(Ord. 585, § 5, 12-16-2014; Ord. 546, § 5, 11-19-2013) 
2.53.060 - Meetings. 
    Meetings of the committee shall be at the call of the chairperson and such other times as the committee may determine. All meetings conducted by the committee shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. 585, § 6, 12-16-2014; Ord. 546, § 6, 11-19-2013) 
2.53.070 - Duties. 
A.  Generally to collect information, comments, complaints, suggestions and data to oversee development of a twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven days per week fire standards. 
B.  To collect such information from City of Sun Prairie, Sun Prairie Volunteer Fire Department Company, Inc. and other sources to enable agreement upon metrics for response times and efficient safe suppression of any fire emergency. 
C.  To facilitate transparency between City of Sun Prairie and Sun Prairie Volunteer Fire Department Company, Inc., including monthly accountability reports detailing all fire suppression activities, all training and response activities and financial accountability.
