B.  Consideration of Requests. The mayor and city administration shall consider such departmental requests in consultation with the department head and jointly develop a recommended budget for presentation to the common council. 
C.  Proposed Budget. On or before October 20, the mayor and city administration shall prepare and submit to the committee of the whole a proposed budget presenting a financial plan for conducting the affairs of the city for the ensuing calendar year. The budget shall include the following information: 
1.  The expense of conducting each department and activity of the city for the ensuing fiscal year and corresponding items for the current year and last preceding fiscal year, with reasons for increase and decrease recommended as compared with appropriations for the current year; 
2.  An itemization of all anticipated income of the city from sources other than general property taxes and bonds issued, with a comparative statement of the amounts received by the city from each of the same or similar sources for the last preceding and current fiscal year; 
3.  An estimate of the amount of money to be raised from general property taxes which, with income from other sources, will be necessary to meet the proposed expenditures; 
4.  Such other information as may be required by the common council and by state law. 
D.  Copies of Budget. City administration shall make copies of the budget available for review by citizens through electronic means. The entire fiscal budget shall be available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk during regular office hours. 
E.  Consideration by Council. 
1.  The committee of the whole shall review the proposed budget and submit to the council a recommendation for the approved budget the ensuing fiscal year. 
2.  The committee of the whole shall set a time and place for a public hearing on the budget and shall direct that a notice of the time and place where such budget and detail is available for public inspection and notice of the time and place for holding the public hearing thereon, shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least fifteen (15) days prior to the time of such public hearing. 
3.  Not less than fifteen (15) days after the publication of the proposed budget and the notice of hearing thereon, the public hearing shall be held at the time and place stipulated, at which time any resident or taxpayer of the city shall have an opportunity to be heard on the proposed budget. The budget hearing may be adjourned from time to time. 
4.  A vote of two-thirds of the members of the common council is required to adopt the annual budget and approve the tax levy. 
5.  The common council shall adopt the annual budget and tax levy on or before December 8 in order to allow for the preparation and transfer of the tax roll to the city treasurer as required by state statutes. 
(Ord. 367, 7-1-2008; Ord. 287, § 1, 11-8-2006; prior code § 3-1-3) 
3.08.020 - Changes in budget. 
    The council may at any time by a two-thirds vote of the entire membership transfer any portion of an unencumbered balance of an appropriation to any other purpose or object. Notice of such transfer shall be given by publication within fifteen (15) days thereafter in a newspaper in general circulation in the city. 
( Ord. No. 730, § 1, 4-17-2018 ; Ord. 655, § 1, 8-2-2016; Ord. 367, 7-1-2008; prior code § 3-1-4) 
3.08.025 - Park fund. 
    Funds placed in the park fund shall only be used for the purposes of developing (including the purchase of land), improving, and replacing park and playground facilities as provided for by Section 66.0617, Wisconsin Statutes, and that no monies shall be transferred from the park replacement fund for any other purpose without an affirmative vote of two-thirds of all members of the council. 
(Ord. 316, § 1, 4-17-2007) 
3.08.030 - City funds to be spent in accordance with appropriation. 
    No money shall be drawn from the treasury of the city, nor shall any obligation for the expenditure of money be incurred, except in pursuance of the annual appropriation in the adopted budget or when changed as authorized by Section 3.08.020 of this chapter. At the close of each fiscal year any unencumbered balance of an appropriation shall revert to the general fund and shall be subject to reappropriation but appropriations may be made by the common council, to be paid out of the income of the current year, in furtherance of improvements or other objects or works which will not be completed within such year, and any such appropriation shall continue in force until the purpose for which it was made shall have been accomplished or abandoned. 
(Prior code § 3-1-5) 
Chapter 3.12 - PROPERTY TAXES 
Sections: 

3.12.010 - Preparation of tax roll and tax receipts. 
A.  Aggregate Tax Stated on Roll. Pursuant to Section 70.65(2), Wisconsin Statutes, the clerk shall, in computing the personal tax roll, insert only the aggregate amount of state, county, school and local taxes in a single-column in the roll opposite the parcel or tract of land against which the tax is levied in a single-column opposite the name of the person against whom the tax is levied. 
B.  Rates Stamped on Receipts. Pursuant to Section 74.08(1), Wisconsin Statutes, in lieu of entering on each tax receipt the several amounts paid respectively for state, county, school, local and other taxes, the aggregate amount of such taxes shall be combined in a single-column on the tax receipt issued by the city treasurer. The treasurer shall cause to be printed or stamped on the tax receipt or personal property bills the separate proportion or rate of taxes levied for state, county, school, local or other purposes. (Prior code § 3-1-1) 
3.12.020 - Duplicate treasurer's bond eliminated. 
A.  Bond Eliminated. The city elects not to give the bond on the city treasurer provided for by Section 70.67(1), Wisconsin Statutes. 
B.  City Liable for Default of Treasurer. Pursuant to Section 70.67(2), Wisconsin Statutes, the city shall be obligated to pay, in case the city treasurer shall fail to do so, all state and county taxes required by law to be paid by such city treasurer to the county treasurer. (Prior code § 3-1-2) 
3.12.030 - Payment of taxes-Interest-Penalty. 
A.  All personal property taxes and special assessments shall be paid on or before February 28th. 
B.  All real estate taxes levied pursuant to this code of ordinances and the Wisconsin Statutes may be paid in two installments, the first shall be paid on or before January 31st and the second installment on or before July 31st next succeeding, in accordance with the provisions of Section 74.11, Wisconsin Statutes. If the first installment of the real estate taxes is not paid on or before January 31st, the whole amount of those real estate taxes shall become due and shall be collected, together with unpaid personal property taxes, on or before the last day of February by the city treasurer. 
C.  Overdue or delinquent real estate taxes, personal property taxes and special assessments are subject to an interest charge of one percent per month or fraction of a month. 
D.  In addition to the interest charge, overdue or delinquent personal property taxes are subject to a penalty of one-half percent per month or fraction of a month. The penalty shall apply to any personal property taxes that are overdue or delinquent and shall be calculated from January of the year in which such taxes first become due. 
E.  Immediately upon the sale or transfer of a business the city finance officer shall require advanced payment of all personal property taxes based on the previous year's mill rate multiplied by the premise's, property's or business's current years valuation. (Amended during 2000 codification; prior code § 3-1-16) 
3.12.040 - Nonsufficient fund checks. 
    If any person shall delivery a check to the city for payment for any amount due to the city and such check shall be returned due to nonsufficient funds (NSF), the city shall charge the person a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per NSF check, to reimburse the city for its reasonable costs and expenses in connection with the collection of such check. (Ord. 461 § 1, 1999: prior code § 3-1-17) 
Chapter 3.16 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS 
Sections: 

3.16.010 - Common council may levy special assessments. 
A.  The city by resolution of its common council may levy and collect special assessments upon property in a limited and determinable area for special benefits conferred upon such property by any municipal work or improvement and may provide for the payment of all or any part of the cost of the work or improvement. In addition to other methods approved by law, special assessments for any public work or improvement or any special charge for current services may be levied in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  The amount assessed against any property for any work or improvement which does not represent an exercise of the police power shall not exceed the value of the benefits accruing to the property therefrom, and for those representing an exercise of the police power, the assessment shall be upon a reasonable basis as determined by the common council. 
C.  The favored procedure in the city for proceeding with making specially assessable public improvements as generally set forth in this chapter is not intended in any way to disregard or to bar proceeding under other methods provided by law for making of public improvements and for the levying of assessments therefor. Detailed requirements still require reference to such statutory section and the subsections thereunder. The purpose hereof is to generally define and establish local procedures. (Prior code § 3-2-1) 
3.16.020 - Procedures. 
A.  The city shall pursue exercising its special assessment powers through the authority granted in Wisconsin Statutes 66.62 or pursuant to other authorizing statutes. 
B.  The city may proceed with the special assessment process at any time before, during, or after the construction of the improvements under local ordinance (by authority granted in Wisconsin Statutes 66.62). In the case of petitioned improvements, and/or when a waiver of special assessment notice and hearing (as provided in Wisconsin Statutes Section 66.60(18)) has been filed with the city for specific improvements, the city may proceed with the letting of bids and contracts for the work at anytime in the process. 
1.  The public works committee shall conduct a public informational meeting with the public affected by the proposed work. The engineer shall prepare a preliminary engineering report describing: 
a.  The scope of the work; 
b.  The estimated project costs; 
c.  Those elements of the work which may be specially assessable; and 
d.  A draft of a preliminary resolution for review, modification by the public works committee. The draft of the reviewed or adopted preliminary resolution shall be forwarded to the city council with a recommendation for council adoption. 
2.  The city council shall determine to assess part or all of the costs of a specific public service or improvement to the benefitting properties under the provisions of Wisconsin Statutes 66.62, by declaring its intent in a preliminary resolution. The preliminary resolution shall describe: 
a.  The contemplated purpose; 
b.  The limits of the area to be assessed; 
c.  The estimated cost of the project; 
d.  The estimated assessment amounts (preliminary assessment roll) if available; 
e.  The date for the public hearing; 
f.  Instructions for the city clerk to publish the preliminary resolution as a Class 1 notice and mail the notice (preliminary resolution) to any affected persons. 
3.  The proposed work shall be let out for bidding. 
4.  The engineer shall view the premises of the public improvement or service and determine that benefits will accrue to the affected parcels. The engineer shall prepare a final report of special assessments with project costs determined from the contract bid prices, a preliminary special assessment roll of the affected properties and the estimated amount of the special assessments for each affected property, and an explanation of how the estimated special assessment amounts had been prepared on a fair and equitable basis in accordance with statutes, ordinances, and the provisions of this policy. 
5.  The public works committee shall hold a public hearing to discuss the recommended special assessments with any interested parties. The public works committee shall review the preliminary resolution and preliminary special assessment roll with those affected property owners in attendance at the public hearing in accordance with the guidelines of this policy, and shall determine and recommend to the city council the following: 
a.  The work or service costs, or portions thereof, to be specially assessed for; 
b.  The rates or percentages of the costs to be borne by the city; 
c.  The rates or percentages of the costs to be borne by the affected property owners; 
d.  The types, interest rate, methods, deferments, and numbers of installments for the special assessments. 
    The public works committee recommendation shall be presented to the city council in the form of the recommended final resolution and assessment roll. 
6.  The city council shall approve and adopt, disapprove, modify, or refer the recommended final resolution and assessment roll back to the public works committee with suggested revisions. 
7.  Upon adoption by the city council, the city clerk shall publish the final resolution as a Class 1 notice and mail copies of the final resolution and assessment roll to the affected property owners. 
8.  The property owner may appeal the special assessment to the circuit court in the manner prescribed in Wisconsin Statutes 66.60(12) within forty (40) days of the date of adoption of the final resolution by the city council. 
9.  If the actual special assessment amounts for each affected property owner are substantially greater than the amounts approved in the assessment roll, the special assessment process may be reopened at Step number 1. If the actual special assessment amounts are less than the amounts approved in the assessment roll, the assessments shall be levied at the actual amount of the assessment. If the actual special assessment amounts are substantially greater than the amounts approved in the assessment roll, or if necessary due to errors in the special assessments or the special assessment process, the city may choose to reopen the assessment process. In addition, the city may choose not to reopen the assessment process (in which case the assessments shall be levied at the amount approved in the assessment roll). 
10.  The special assessments shall be collected in accordance with the final resolution. (Prior code § 3-2-2) 
3.16.030 - Costs that may be paid by special assessment. 
    The cost of any work or improvement to be paid in whole or in part by special assessment on property may include the direct and indirect cost thereof, the damages occasioned thereby, the interest on bonds or notes issued in anticipation of the collection of the assessments, a reasonable charge for the services of the administrative staff of the city and the cost of any architectural, engineering and legal services, and any other item of direct or indirect cost which may reasonably be attributed to the proposed work or improvement. The amount to be assessed against all property for any such proposed work or improvement shall be apportioned among the individual parcels in the manner designated by the common council in accordance with the special assessment policies and procedures for the city then in effect. On major projects which benefit the entire community as a whole, a portion of the project cost shall be born by the community as a whole. (Prior code § 3-2-3) 
3.16.040 - Exemptions-Deductions. 
A.  If any property deemed benefited shall by reason of any provision of law be exempt from assessment therefor, such assessment shall be computed and shall be paid by the city. 
B.  A parcel of land against which has been levied a special assessment for the sanitary sewer or water main laid in one of the streets upon which it abuts, shall be entitled to such deduction or exemption as the common council determines in accordance with the special assessment policies and procedures, when a special assessment is levied for the sanitary sewer or water main laid in the other street upon which such corner lot abuts. The common council may allow a similar deduction or exemption from special assessments levied for other public improvements in accordance with the special assessment policies and procedures. 
C.  Intersections. 
1.  For single- and two-family zoning districts, the portion of the street improvements within the limits of the intersection (the right-of-way lines extended), shall be exempt from special assessments and the cost thereof shall be borne by the city. For industrial, commercial, and multi-family (three or more family dwelling units) districts, there shall be no exemptions for street improvements within an intersection since land users in these zoning districts frequently require special features (turning lanes, signalization, etc.) due to the volumes and/or characteristics of the traffic they generate. 
2.  Intersections are sometimes designed with features and fixtures which serve to better accommodate traffic generated from properties which may or may not be immediately contiguous to the intersection. In such instances special assessments may be more fairly and equitably determined through prorations of area, traffic generation or other such methods. In such instances, these methods, or combinations of methods may be utilized so as to result in fair and equitable special assessments. 
3.  The provisions of subsections (C)(1) and (2) of this section do not apply to any special assessment levied as a result of a court order in Dane County circuit court Case No. 93-CV-2168. For any such special assessment, the method of payments, billings, installments, deferred payments, interest, penalties, or discounts shall be set by the council in its discretion as part of the final resolution. (Ord. 361 § 1, 1996; prior code § 3-2-4) 
3.16.050 - Notice of proposed or approved project. 
A.  Notice Requirements. On the completion of the preliminary resolution, the city clerk shall publish the preliminary resolution as a Class 1 notice, which notice shall comply with Chapter 985, Wisconsin Statutes, and state the nature of the proposed or approved work or improvement, the general boundary lines of the proposed assessment district, the place and time at which the preliminary assessment roll may be inspected and the place and time at which interested persons, their agents or attorneys may appear before the public works committee and be heard concerning the matters contained in the preliminary resolution and assessment roll. Such notice shall be signed by the city clerk who shall cause the same to be published at least once in the official newspaper and shall mail a copy of such notice at least ten (10) days before the hearing to every interested person whose post office address is known or can be ascertained with reasonable diligence. The hearing shall commence not less than ten (10) days and not more than forty (40) days after the publication or mailing of such notice. 
B.  Waiver of Notice-Assessments Under. The council may, without any notice of hearing, levy and assess the whole or any part of the cost of any municipal work or whole or any part of the cost of any municipal work or improvement as a special assessment upon the property specifically benefited thereby whenever notice and hearing thereon is in writing waived by all the owners of property affected by such special assessment. In such cases the procedure shall be the same as herein before provided excepting for the noticing and holding of public hearing thereon. (Prior code § 3-2-5) 
3.16.060 - Council actions after hearing. 
A.  After the hearing, the common council: 
1.  Shall approve, disapprove, modify or re-refer a final resolution and roll of assessments to the public works committee with such directions as it deems necessary to change the final resolution and assessment roll so as to accomplish a fair and equitable assessment; 
2.  If the work or improvement has not been previously authorized or approved, the common council shall approve the work or improvement and direct that the same be done and paid for in accordance with the resolution and assessment roll finally approved; 
3.  If the work or improvement has been commenced or completed prior to the adoption of the resolution and assessment rolls or prior to the hearing, then the common council shall by resolution confirm that the work has been authorized and provide for payment in whole or in part by assessment. 
B.  The clerk shall publish the final resolutions as a Class 1 notice. 
C.  After the publication of the final resolution, any work or improvement provided for and not yet authorized, shall be deemed fully authorized and all awards of compensation or damage and all assessments made shall be deemed duly and properly made, subject to the right of appeal by Section 66.60(12), Wisconsin Statutes, or any other applicable provision of law, in accordance with Section 3-2-10 of this chapter. 
D.  The city clerk shall issue respective special assessment certificates for each property affected and specifying the manner in which payment is to be made and shall send copy of the respective final resolution affecting each property to each owner's post office address that is known or can be obtained with reasonable diligence. (Prior code § 3-2-6) 
3.16.070 - Combined assessments. 
    If more than a single improvement is undertaken, the common council may combine the assessments as a single assessment on each property affected except that the property owner may object to any one or more of such assessment amounts. (Prior code § 3-2-7) 
3.16.080 - Council's power to amend, cancel or confirm special assessment. 
    If after completion or after the receipt of bids, the actual cost of any work or improvement is found to be substantially greater than the original assessment roll amount, or the assessment is void or invalid for any reason, or if the common council determines to reconsider an assessment, it is empowered, after giving notice as required in Section 3.16.050 to amend, cancel or confirm any prior assessment and notice of this amending, canceling or confirming be given by the clerk as provided in Section 3.16.050 of this chapter. (Prior code § 3-2-8) 
3.16.090 - Where cost of improvement is less than assessment. 
    If the cost of the work or improvement is less than the assessment levied, the common council without notice or hearing shall reduce each assessment proportionately. If the assessment has been paid either in part or in full the city shall refund the property owner such overpayment. (Prior code § 3-2-9) 
3.16.100 - Appeals-Appealed assessments payable when due. 
A.  Any person against whose property a special assessment is levied under the ordinance codified in this section may appeal therefrom in the manner prescribed by Section 66.60(12) of the Wisconsin Statutes, as amended, within forty (40) days of the date of the final determination of the common council. 
B.  Pursuant to Section 66.60(12)(f), Wisconsin Statutes, it shall be a condition to the maintenance of any appeal that any assessment appealed shall be paid when due and payable and upon default in payment any such appeal shall be dismissed. (Amended during 2000 codification; prior code § 3-2-10) 
3.16.110 - Payment of special assessments-Special assessment a lien on property. 
A.  Payment of Special Assessment. 
1.  Without Interest. Upon receipt of copy of special assessment certificate, any person may pay the same in full, without interest, if paid to the city treasurer within the grace period therein allowed and as allowed in the final resolution. 
2.  After Grace Period. If such special assessment, or any part thereof, remains unpaid following the running of the grace period specified for payment without interest, at time of preparation of the first tax roll thereafter, the same, together with interest computed thereon at the interest rate established in said final resolution and in such certificates computed from date of levy (i.e., date of final resolution) shall be entered in such tax roll in such manner as directed in such final resolution and certificate; thereafter, if the same be payable in installments, subsequent installments together with interest at said rate computed on declining balance shall be entered in subsequent tax rolls until fully paid. This provision is in no way intended to prohibit the prepayment of the balance owing at any time on principal together with interest to date of payment only. 
B.  Assessment a Lien. Pursuant to Section 66.604 and 66.605, Wisconsin Statutes, any special assessment levied under this chapter shall be a lien on the property against which it is levied on behalf of the city. The common council shall provide for the collection of such assessments and may establish penalties for payment after the due date. The common council shall provide that all assessments not paid by the date specified shall be extended upon the tax roll as a delinquent tax against the property and all proceedings in relation to the collection of such delinquent taxes shall apply to such assessment, except as otherwise provided by statute. 
C.  Financial Hardship Situation. The finance officer/treasurer shall be authorized to pay any assessment legally assessed against the real estate of any worthy person resident in the city provided the individual meets the following criteria: 
1.  Owns and resides in a single-family or two-family residence, against which a special assessment has been levied in accordance with existing ordinance; 
2.  Has an annual federal gross income equal to or less than one hundred seventy-five (175) percent of the United States Community Services Administration's poverty guidelines most recently issued prior to the date the special assessment is levied or prior to the specific special assessment being billed; 
3.  Owns and resides in the single-family or two-family residence on a permanent basis for a period of time not less than twenty-four (24) consecutive months prior to the adoption date of the special assessment resolution; 
4.  Certifies to the city finance officer/treasurer in writing that the full payment of the special assessment, or any installment of the special assessment, would create a financial hardship and that the individual qualifies under subsection (C)(1) and (2) of this section; 
5.  Reconfirms annually to the finance officer/treasurer in writing that the full payment of the special assessment or any installment of the special assessment is a financial hardship and that the individual continues to qualify under subsection (C)(1) and (2) of this section; 
6.  The annual assessment payment would be equal to or greater than seven percent of the individual's federal gross income as identified on the individual's most recent federal tax return; 
7.  In the event that an individual fails to requalify under this program, then their required annual payment would be equal to the annual interest charged for the current year, plus five percent of the outstanding balance but not to exceed seven percent of the individual's federal gross income. The outstanding balance would be proportionately extended upon future tax rolls, under the same financial hardship test; 
8.  In the event that a qualified individual makes a partial payment on their account during the year, the payment allocation of principal and interest shall be governed by the rule of 78's. 
D.  Lien in Financial Hardship Situation. 
1.  A copy of the assessment resolution, including a statement of the amount, date paid and description of the real estate, certified by the city clerk, shall be recorded with the register of deeds of Dane County, and the amount shall thereby become a lien upon such real property in favor of the city prior to any other liens hereunder for the amount paid, with interest at a rate which is one percent above the rate applicable to the city for funds borrowed to make the improvement for which the property was assessed, and shall be enforceable upon transfer of title of the property of sale, inheritance or will, in the manner provided by law for the enforcement of mechanic's liens except when such transfer is to a surviving spouse who meets the above requirements. 
2.  The owner of such property, his or her heirs, personal representative or assigns may discharge the lien at any time by paying the amount of such lien, with accrued interest as computed above, to the finance officer/treasurer who shall execute a proper satisfaction piece which shall be recorded with the register of deeds. 
3.  The holder of any other lien against such real estate may purchase with the written consent of both the property owner and the city such lien of payment of the amount thereof, with accrued interest as computed above, to the city finance officer/treasurer, who shall execute and deliver a proper assignment thereof to such payer and, upon recording the assignment, the assignee shall have the same rights which the city had prior to the assignment. 
4.  The finance officer/treasurer will annually notify the property owners of their outstanding debt plus a breakdown of principal and accrued interest. In addition, an annual report will be submitted to the city administrator reporting on the financial impact of the participants. (Prior code § 3-2-11) 
3.16.120 - Special charges permissible. 
A.  In addition to all other methods provided by law, special charges for current services may be imposed by resolution by the common council by allocating all or part of the cost of the property served. Such resolution setting forth the property location, the current service rendered by the city, and the special charge therefore or cost thereof. Such resolution for special charges may include, but not be limited by enumeration to: snow and ice removal, weed elimination, street sprinkling oiling or tarring, repair of sidewalks or curb and gutter, garbage and refuse disposal, sewer service and tree care or removal. The provision for notice of such charges shall be optional with the common council except that in the case of street, sidewalk, curb or gutter repair, twenty (20) days notice published in the official city newspaper, or by posting such notice in three places in the city and a copy of such notice mailed to every affected person whose post office address is known, at least ten (10) days before the hearing or proceeding. Such notice shall specify that on a certain date a hearing will be held by the common council as to whether the service in question shall be performed. 
B.  Special charges for current services shall not be payable in installments. If not paid within the period fixed by the common council in such resolution, such delinquent special charges, pursuant to Section 3.16.110, shall become a lien on such property as of the date of such delinquency and shall automatically be extended upon the current or next tax roll as a delinquent tax against the property, as provided by Section 66.60(16) of the Wisconsin Statutes, and all proceedings in relation to the collection, return and sale of property for delinquent real estate taxes shall apply to such special charge. Notice of special charges for current services need not be given except as required by Section 66.60(16) of the Wisconsin Statutes, as amended. (Prior code § 3-2-12) 
3.16.130 - Miscellaneous provisions. 
A.  If any assessment or charge levied under this chapter is invalid because such statutes are found to be unconstitutional, the common council may thereafter reassess such assessment or charge pursuant to the provisions of any applicable law. 
B.  The common council may, without notice or hearing, levy and assess all or any part of the cost of any work or improvement upon the property benefited if notice and hearing is waived in writing by property owners affected. 
C.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, or this or other ordinance or resolution it is specifically intended and provided by this section that the city may levy special assessments for work or improvement against the property benefited either before or after the approval of the work plans and specifications, contracting for the work or completing the work or improvement. (Prior code § 3-2-13) 
3.16.140 - Payments- Installments- Deferred payments- Interest- Penalties. 
A.  The assessments shall be paid in total in cash or in annual installments as provided by the final assessment resolution. Annual special assessment installment payments shall be due by January 31st of each year. 
B.  Assessments may be deferred by the council if the council determines such deferral is in the best interest of the city. Such deferred assessments shall be deferred for a period of time not to exceed ten (10) years from the date the improvements are installed. If any portion of the improvements are utilized prior to the end of the ten (10) year period, the outstanding principal and interest for the said public improvements shall be paid immediately. 
C.  To encourage prompt payment of assessments, the city will allow property owners a discount of three percent of the total assessment amount for lands located within the city limits if the assessment is paid in full within thirty (30) days of the date of invoice by the city. Deferred payments and installment payments on lands within the city limits shall bear interest at the rates set forth below: 
1.  If an amount equal to sixty (60) percent of the full lump sum amount of the assessment is paid within thirty (30) days of the date of invoice by the city, then the unpaid balance to be paid in equal annual installments, together with interest on the unpaid balance at the rate at which the city can borrow for, plus two percent. 
2.  If the assessment is paid in equal annual installments without any up-front lump-sum payment, then the installment shall incur interest on the unpaid balance at the rate at which the city can borrow for, plus three percent. 
3.  If between, forty (40) percent and sixty (60) percent of the full lump sum of the special assessment is paid within thirty (30) days of the date of invoice by the city, then the unpaid balance shall be paid in a lump sum amount at the end of a period equal to the period allowed for annual installment payments, together with interest on the unpaid interest at the rate at which the city can borrow, plus two percent. 
4.  Any special assessments may be paid in an amount equal to the remaining balance due, together with any interest due, at any time. 
D.  All assessments or installments not paid by the specified date shall be extended on the tax roll as a delinquent tax and collected in the same manner as a delinquent real estate tax. Special assessments, or special assessment installments (when allowed by the levying resolution) which are not paid when due shall be charged fifteen (15) percent of the total late payment as a one-time penalty which, together with the late payment, shall be added to the tax roll as a delinquent tax against the property. Installments or assessments not paid when due shall also bear an additional interest charge in an amount of eight percent per annum for the period of delinquency above and beyond the penalty charge established in this section. (Prior code § 3-2-14) 
3.16.150 - Special assessments outside municipal boundaries. 
A.  Wisconsin Statutes 66.65 provides that special assessments may be levied for municipal work or improvements under Wisconsin Statutes 66.60, upon property in an adjacent city, village or town, if such property abuts upon and benefits from such work or improvements. 
B.  Special assessments to property outside of the city limits of the city may be levied under the authority granted in Wisconsin Statutes 66.60 and not under the provisions of the chapter. The common council of the city shall adopt a resolution requesting the governing body of the property outside the city limits to approve a resolution authorizing the levying of special assessments by the city against the property outside the city limits. Upon approval of a final resolution by the adjacent governing body, the special assessments shall be levied and collected by the adjoining governing body and remitted to the city. 
    When the owner of the property outside the municipal boundaries pays the special assessment, he or she is entitled to the use of the work or improvement upon which the assessment is based and with the same conditions as the owner of property within the municipal boundaries. 
C.  Properties outside the corporate limits of the city which are contemplating annexation to the city shall not be specially assessed, except pursuant to Section 66.65, Wisconsin Statutes. However, any property owner contemplating annexation may, at their option choose to pay their cost sharing amounts minus fifteen (15) percent of the total amount set forth in subsection 3.16.140 of this section and further provided that payment is made to the city and the city adopts an ordinance annexing the property all within six months of the date of adoption of the final assessment resolution. 
D.  Properties outside the corporate limits of the city which are not contemplating annexation to the city or whose owners do not elect the option provided in subsection C of this section shall not be specially assessed unless the governing body of these properties approves the special assessment and levies, collects and remits the special assessment payments to the city. Such special assessment shall be levied under the authority granted in Section 66.65, Wisconsin Statutes. However, the city reserves the right to calculate the prorated costs of the improvements resulting in benefit to the properties located outside the city limits as a cost sharing amount (together with any interest due, to be considered at the time of annexation of the properties to the city). The city reserves the right to determine at the time of annexation what cost sharing amounts should reasonably be paid by the property owner and under what payment terms and conditions. (Prior code § 3-2-15) 
3.16.160 - Petition for improvements-Waiver of assessment procedures. 
A.  Any taxpayer and property owner in the city may petition the city for the installation of public improvements to serve the property owned by such petitioner in the city. 
1.  Petition Requirements. The petition for the installation of public improvements shall state that: 
a.  The petitioner(s) requests public improvements to serve property owned by the petitioner; 
b.  Shall describe such property; 
c.  Shall state the type of public improvements requested; 
d.  Shall contain a waiver of special assessment notice and hearing stating that each petitioner individually shall be responsible and liable for and thereby obligate(s) himself or herself to pay the total direct and indirect costs of the installation of such public improvements; 
e.  Shall state the petitioner's desired term of the special assessments. 
2.  Council Action. In the event a petition for the installation of public improvements is presented to the city council, the council shall have the exclusive discretion to approve, reject or modify (with concurrence of the petitioner) the petition. The council may refer such petition to its standing committees for determinations of project costs, project financing, feasibility and timing of construction, and other matters, or may table it, modify it through negotiation with the petitioner, or may reject it, but shall act on such petition in some manner within six months of receipt of such petition. 
3.  Timing of Petition. Any petition for improvements shall be filed with the city council on or before August 1st of the year preceding the desired installation of the public improvement so as to be considered in the city budget for the following year and so as to permit the necessary engineering of the requested public improvements. Petitions may be filed with the city council at other times of the year, and with other desired installation times. The city council and/or its standing committee shall review these petitions, without commitment or obligation, for consideration of the project costs, project financing, feasibility and timing of construction, and other such matters, and may elect to authorize the installation of the requested public improvements as a special project or as an addition to a previously authorized project. 
(Prior code § 3-2-16) 
Chapter 3.20 - ROOM TAX 
Sections: 

3.20.010 - Definitions. 
    In this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
    "Gross receipts" has the meaning as defined in Section 77.51(4)(a), Wisconsin Statutes, insofar as applicable. 
    "Hotel or motel" means a building or a group of buildings in which the public may obtain accommodations for a consideration, including, without limitation, such establishments as inns, motels, tourist homes, tourist houses or courts, bed and breakfast establishments, lodging houses, rooming houses, summer camps, apartment hotels, resort lodges and cabins, commercial indoor lodging facilities (as defined in Section 17.16.100 of the code of ordinances) and any other building or group of buildings in which accommodations are available to the public, except accommodations, including mobile homes as defined in Section 66.058(1)(d), Wisconsin Statutes, rented for a continuous period of more than one month and accommodations furnished by any hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes or by corporations or associations organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes provided that no part of the net earnings of such corporations and associations inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
    "Transient" means any person residing for a continuous period of less than one month in a hotel, motel, or other furnished, accommodations available to the public. 
(Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-1) 
3.20.020 - Imposition of tax. 
    Pursuant to Section 66.75, Wisconsin Statutes, a tax is imposed on the privilege and services of furnishing, at retail, or rooms or lodging to transients by hotel keepers, motel operators and other persons furnishing accommodations that are available to the public, irrespective of whether membership is required for the use of the accommodations. Such tax shall be at the rate of four percent of the gross receipts from such retail furnishing of rooms or lodgings. However, starting January 1, 2017 such tax rate will be five and one-half percent of gross receipts from such retail furnishing of rooms or lodgings. Starting January 1, 2018 such tax rate will be seven percent of gross receipts from such retail furnishing of rooms or lodgings. Such tax shall not be subject to the selective sales tax imposed by Section 77.52(2)(a), Wisconsin Statutes, and may not be imposed upon sales to the federal government and persons listed under Section 77.54(9a), Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 670, § 1, 12-20-2016; Ord. 665, § 1, 11-15-2016; Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-2) 
3.20.030 - Collection of tax. 
    This section shall be administered by the city treasurer. The tax imposed for the months of January, February and March, 1998, and for each calendar quarter thereafter is due and payable on the last day of the month next succeeding the calendar quarter for which imposed. A return shall be filed with the city treasurer, by those furnishing at retail such rooms and lodging, on or before the same date on which such tax is due and payable. Such return shall show the gross receipts of the preceding calendar quarter from such retail furnishing of rooms or lodging, the amount of taxes imposed for such period, and such other information as the city treasurer deems necessary. Every person required to file such quarterly return shall, with their first return, elect to file an annual calendar year or fiscal year return. Such annual return shall be filed within ninety (90) days of the close of each such calendar or fiscal year. The annual return shall summarize the quarterly returns, reconcile and adjust for errors in the quarterly returns, and shall contain such additional information as the city treasurer requires. Such annual returns shall be made on forms as prescribed by the city treasurer. All such returns shall be signed by the person required to file a return or his duly authorized agent, but need not be verified by oath. The city treasurer may, for good cause, extend the time for filing any return, but in no event longer than one month from the filing date. 
(Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-3) 
3.20.040 - Sale or conveyance of business. 
    If any person liable for any amount of tax under this section sells out their business or stock of goods or quits the business, their successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city treasurer that it has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. If a person subject to the tax imposed by this section fails to withhold such amount of tax from the purchase price as required, they shall become personally liable for payment of the amount required to be withheld by them to the extent of the price of the accommodations valued in money. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-4) 
3.20.050 - Determination of tax by audit. 
A.  The city treasurer may, by office audit, determine the tax required to be paid to the city or the refund due to any person under this chapter. This determination may be made upon the basis of the facts contained in the return being audited or on the basis of any other information within the city treasurer's possession that meets the criteria set forth in Section 66.75(2), Wisconsin Statutes. One or more such office audit determinations may be made of the amount due for anyone or for more than one period. 
B.  The city treasurer may, by field audit, determine the tax required to be paid to the city or the refund due to any person under this chapter. The determination may be made upon the basis of the facts contained in the return being audited or upon any other information within the city treasurer's possession. Whenever the city treasurer has probable cause to believe that the correct amount of room tax has not been assessed or that the tax return is not correct, the city treasurer is authorized to examine and inspect the books, records, memoranda, and property of any person in order to verify the tax liability of that person or of another person. Nothing herein shall prevent the city treasurer from making a determination of tax at any time. (Ord. 416 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-5) 
3.20.060 - Failure to file return. 
    If any person fails to file a return by this chapter, the city treasurer shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts under Section 3.20.020. Such estimate shall be made for the period for which such person failed to make a return and shall be based upon any information which is in the city treasurer's possession or may come into his or her possession. On the basis of this estimate, the city treasurer shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city adding to the sum thus arrived at, a penalty equal to ten (10) percent thereof. One or more such determinations may be made for one or more than one period. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-6) 
3.20.070 - Forfeiture relating to returns not filed timely. 
    A forfeiture of twenty-five (25) percent of the room tax due for the previous year or five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) whichever is less, of the tax imposed, is hereby established and due and owing in the event that the room tax is not paid within thirty (30) days after the due date of the return. In addition to this forfeiture, all unpaid taxes under this section shall bear interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum from the due date of the return until the first day of the month following the month in which the tax is paid or deposited with the city treasurer. All refunded taxes shall bear interest at twelve (12) percent per annum from the due date of the return until the first day of the month following the month in which such taxes are refunded. An extension of time within which to file a return shall not operate to extend the due date of the return for purposes of interest computation. If the city treasurer determines that any overpayment of tax has been made intentionally or by reason of carelessness or neglect, or if the tax which was overpaid was not accompanied by a complete return, it shall not allow any interest thereon. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-7) 
3.20.080 - Delinquent tax returns. 
    Delinquent tax returns shall be subject to a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) late filing fee. The tax imposed by this section shall become delinquent if not paid by the due date of the return. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-8) 
3.20.090 - Filing of fraudulent returns. 
    If a person files a false or fraudulent return with the intent in either case to defeat or evade the tax imposed by this section, a penalty of fifty (50) percent shall be added to the tax required to be paid, exclusive of interest and other penalties. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-9) 
3.20.100 - Posting of security as requested by city treasurer. 
    In order to protect the revenue of the city, the city treasurer may require any person liable for the tax imposed by this chapter to place with him or her such security, not in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) as the city treasurer determines. If any taxpayer is delinquent in the payment of the taxes imposed by this section, the city treasurer may, upon ten (10) days' notice, recover the taxes, interest and penalties from the security placed with the city treasurer by such taxpayer. No interest shall be paid or allowed by the city to any person for the deposit of such security. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-10) 
3.20.110 - Record keeping requirements. 
    Every person liable for the tax imposed by this chapter shall keep or cause to be kept such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the city treasurer requires. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-11) 
3.20.120 - Confidentiality of tax returns. 
A.  All tax returns, schedules, exhibits, writings or audit reports relating to such returns, on file with the city treasurer are deemed to be confidential, except the city treasurer may divulge their contents to the following, and no others: 
1.  The person who filed the return; 
2.  Officers, agents, or employees of the Federal Internal Revenue Service or the State Department of Revenue; 
3.  Officers, employees, or agents of the city treasurer; 
4.  Other persons for use in the discharge of duties imposed by law, or in the discharge of the duties of their office (unless otherwise prohibited by law), or by order of a court. 
B.  No person having an administrative duty under this section shall make known in any manner the business affairs, operations or information obtained by an investigation of records of any person on whom a tax is imposed by this section, or the amount of source of income, profits, losses, expenditures, or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return, or to permit any return or copy thereof to be seen or examined by any person, except as provided in this section. Any person violating this section, or subsequent ordinances or resolutions adopted by the city pertaining to the confidentiality of the information described in this section may be required to forfeit not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-12) 
3.20.130 - Penalties. 
    Any person who is subject to the tax imposed by this chapter who fails or refuses to permit the inspection of this records by the city treasurer after such inspection has been duly requested by the city treasurer, or who fails to file a return as provided in this section, or who fails to post security requested by the city treasurer, or who violates any other provisions of this section, shall be subject to a forfeiture not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Each day, or portion thereof, that such violation continues is deemed to constitute a separate offense. The total forfeiture imposed shall not exceed five percent of the tax imposed by this chapter. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-13) 
3.20.140 - Exemptions. 
    For tax year 1998, any person or business otherwise required to file a return and make payment to the city under this section will be allowed an exemption from the requirement to collect and pay room tax for any signed contract dated prior to November 1, 1997 in which the contract guarantees the lodging rates. This exemption will expire on December 31, 1998. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-14) 
3.20.150 - Creation and duties of tourism promotion and development commission. 
A.  The creation of a tourism promotion and development commission is created under Chapter 2.56, boards, commissions and committees of the municipal code of ordinances. 
B.  Seventy (70) percent of the tax collected by the city under this chapter shall be forwarded to the commission to be spent on tourism promotion and development by the commission. The commission shall have the authority and carry out the duties set forth in Section 66.75(1m)(c) and (d), Wisconsin Statutes, and as otherwise provided by law. Such duties shall include, without limitation, the following: 
1.  Using the room tax revenue that it receives from the city to promote and develop tourism in the city; 
2.  Reporting any delinquencies or inaccurate reporting of room tax to the city; 
3.  Reporting at least annually to the city the purposes for which the room tax revenues it received were spent. 
C.  The commission may not, however, use any of the room tax revenue it receives to construct or develop a lodging facility. (Ord. 417 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 3-4-15) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 5.04 - LICENSES AND PERMITS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

5.04.010 - License fees to be reviewed. 
    All permit fees and license fees found in this title shall be reviewed by the finance committee every two years. 
(Ord. 467, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 7-13-4) 
5.04.020 - Duty of city clerk with regard to issuing licenses-Appeals. 
A.  Duty of City Clerk With Regard to Issuing Licenses. 
1.  The city clerk shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinances relating to issuances of all licenses and permits in this code of ordinances unless other provisions are made by the common council for the enforcement. 
2.  In the event that a license or permit is applied for under this municipal code, the city clerk shall hold and not issue the license or permit until the city finance officer certified that all personal property taxes hereof and all local taxes, assessments, claims and forfeitures resulting from a violation and conviction of any city ordinance due and owing at the time of the grant of the license or permit relating to the individual property, business or corporation are covered by the license or permit are paid in full. 
B.  Appeal Process. An individual, business or corporation wishing to appeal the city clerk's decision not to issue the license or permit may request in writing that the matter be referred to the common council. A public hearing shall be scheduled within fourteen (14) calendar days by the common council. The council shall consider all of the relevant information and shall render a decision which shall be binding. 
(Prior code § 7-14-1) 
Chapter 5.08 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE LICENSES 
Sections: 

5.08.010 - State statutes adopted. 
A.  The provisions of Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, are adopted and incorporated within this chapter. All future amendments to Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, are adopted and incorporated herein as of the effective dates of those amendments. 
B.  This section is subject to the provisions of the penalty section of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 7-2-1) 
5.08.020 - Classes of alcohol beverages licenses. 
    The common council may issue the following licenses. In this chapter, these licenses are hereinafter referred to as alcohol beverages licenses. 
A.  Fermented malt beverages licenses: 
1.  Class "A" licenses; 
2.  Class "B" licenses; 
3.  Wholesalers' fermented malt beverages licenses. 
B.  Intoxicating liquor licenses: 
1.  "Class A" licenses; 
2.  "Class B" licenses, which authorize the sale of intoxicating liquor to be consumed by the glass only on the premises where sold and also authorize the sale of intoxicating liquor in the original package or container, in multiples not to exceed four liters at any one time, and to be consumed off the premises where sold. Wine, however, may be sold for consumption off the premises in the original package or otherwise in any quantity; 
3.  "Class C" licenses, which authorize the sale of wine by the glass or in an opened original container for consumption on the premises where sold. The license may be issued to a person qualified under Section 125.51(3m), Wisconsin Statutes. 
4.  Reserve "Class B" license. A reserve "Class B" license means a license that is not granted or issued on December 1, 1997, and is counted under Section 125.51(4)(br), Wisconsin Statutes, which authorizes the retail sale of intoxicating liquor for consumption on the premises where sold by the glass to be consumed on the licensed premises or in the original package or container in multiples not to exceed four liters at any one time and to be consumed off the licensed premises, except that wine may be sold in the original container or otherwise in any quantity to be consumed off the premises. 
(Ord. 181, § 1, 4-5-2005; Ord. 517, § 1 (part), 2000; prior code § 7-2-3) 
5.08.030 - Alcohol beverages license fees. 
    The annual fees for alcohol beverages licenses shall be as follows: 
A.  Fermented Malt Beverages Licenses: 
1.  Class "A" license: $200.00. 
2.  Class "B" license: $100.00. 
3.  Wholesaler's license: $25.00. 
B.  Intoxicating Liquor Licenses: 
1.  "Class A" licenses: $500.00. 
2.  "Class B" licenses: $500.00. 
3.  "Class C" licenses: $100.00. 
4.  Reserve "Class B" license. 
a.  Subject to the limitations contained herein the fee for a reserve "Class B" license shall be ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in addition to any other fee required under this chapter. The initial fee is not prorated and must be paid prior to issuance of the license. 
b.  Renewal. The annual fee for renewal of a reserve "Class B" license shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
c.  Recognition of Economic Development. 1997 Wisconsin Act 27 provides that reserve "Class B" licenses be required to pay an initial minimum license fee of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). After review of the statutory language and various ordinances enacted throughout the state, the city of Sun Prairie finds that: 
i.  It is in the interests of the public welfare to increase the property tax base, provide employment opportunities, attract tourists and generally enhance the economic and cultural climate of the community by providing additional economic incentives for new businesses with liquor licenses. 
ii.  The present fee greatly exceeds the actual cost the municipality incurs to regulate the reserve "Class B" license. 
iii.  In the absence of action which alleviates the problem outlined above, said fee could deter new businesses from opening and new businesses from reopening in the city of Sun Prairie. 
d.  Alcohol Beverage Development Grant: 
i.  The city of Sun Prairie hereby creates a business development grant (hereafter development grant) to be funded by the fees paid by reserve "Class B" licenses. 
ii.  Thirty (30) days following the granting of any new reserve "Class B" license, the applicant may file an application for a development grant of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with the city clerk. Following the receipt of the application for said Development grant, the city clerk shall determine whether the licensee is operating in compliance with the approved reserve "Class B" license. The city clerk may require the assistance of any other city agency in making said determination. 
iii.  If the city clerk determines the applicant/licensee is operating in compliance with the previously approved reserve "Class B" license, the city clerk shall authorize the approval of the ten thousand dollar ($10,000.00) development grant. If the city clerk determines the applicant/licensee is not in compliance with the approved license, no development grant may be authorized and the city clerk shall make such finding in writing and deliver a copy of the findings to the applicant/licensee. If the applicant/licensee disagrees with the city clerk's determination, the applicant/licensee may file a written notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) calendar days of the delivery of the written notice of the city clerk's findings. upon receiving such notice from the applicant/licensee, the city clerk shall relay said notice to the city of Sun Prairie Council which shall hold a hearing thereon. The city of Sun Prairie Council may affirm or reverse the city clerk's determination. If the city clerk's determination is upheld, appeal thereof may be taken to circuit court pursuant to Title 4 Administrative Determination Review of the Municipal Code of the city of Sun Prairie. If the city clerk's determination is reversed, the city clerk shall authorize the payment of the development grant. 
iv.  In accepting the one-time development grant, the applicant/licensee agrees to waive any claim he/she/it may have against the city of Sun Prairie for refund of any part of the reserve "Class B" license fee paid to the city by the applicant/licensee. This waiver shall be effective whether such license fee be repealed, rescinded or modified by action of the state legislature or by the courts. By accepting this one-time development grant of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), the applicant/licensee also agrees that, in the event any court of competent jurisdiction shall determine the city's development grant program does not serve a public purpose or is otherwise contrary to law, the applicant/licensee will, upon demand by the city, repay the one-time development grant to the city. 
C.  Temporary Liquor Licenses: 
1.  Temporary Class "B"/"Class B" license: $10.00. 
a.  Applications received less than sixty (60) days prior to the event will incur a late fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Payment of the late filing fee shall not relieve any person from any other penalties prescribed in this chapter for failure to obtain the license. Payment of late filing fees with permit fees must be made with a credit card, certified check or cash. 
D.  Late Fees: Alcohol licenses shall be applied for by April 15 and shall be obtained on or before June 30 of each year or be subject to a late filing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Applications submitted May 1 and after, shall be subject to a late filing fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Payment of the late filing fee shall not relieve any person from any other penalties prescribed in this chapter for failure to obtain the license. Payment of fees after June 20 must be made with a credit card, certified check or cash. 
E.  Background Check Fees: In addition to the fees stated, all processed applications will be assessed the actual cost of the background check as incurred by the city for each person listed on the application. 
F.  Change of Agent Fees: A licensee requesting a change of agent shall conform to all provisions of Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, and this section of the city ordinances. In addition, the licensee shall be required to pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), plus the actual cost of the background check incurred by the city. 
G.  Change of Premises Fees: A licensee requesting a change to the permanent or temporary premises description shall conform to all provisions of Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, and this section of the city ordinances. In addition, the licensee shall be required to pay a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), plus the actual cost of the background checks as incurred by the city, for each person listed on the application. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 2016; Ord. 414, § 1, 12-1-2009; Ord. 181, § 2, 4-5-2005; Ord. 2002-26, § 1, 2002) 
5.08.040 - Alcohol beverages license quotas. 
    The common council shall issue no more than the following number of alcohol beverages licenses to be effective at any one time: 
A.  Fermented Malt Beverages Licenses: 
1.  The number of Class "A" fermented malt beverage licenses to be issued hereunder shall not exceed one license for every one thousand (1,000) of population in the city, as determined by the annual Wisconsin Department of Administration population estimate; 
2.  The number of "Class B" licenses shall be equal to the number of "Class B" licenses and Reserve "Class B" licenses. This quota shall not apply to special event Class "B" licenses. 
B.  Intoxicating Liquor Licenses: 
1.  The number of "Class A" liquor licenses to be issued hereunder shall not exceed one license for every 1,000 (one thousand) of population in the city, as determined by the annual Wisconsin Department of Administration population estimate; 
2.  Eighteen (18) "Class B" licenses as of December 1, 1997; 
3.  The number of "Class B" licenses shall be as provided in Section 125.51(4), Wisconsin States. (Ord. 2003-108 § 1, 2003; Ord. 2002-26 § 2, 2002) 
5.08.050 - Qualification of applicants. 
A.  Qualification Requirements. The qualification requirements for applicants for alcohol beverages licenses shall include the qualification requirements adopted from Chapter 125 of the Wisconsin Statutes and the requirements prescribed in this section. 
B.  Right to Premises. To be eligible to receive or retain any alcohol beverages license, an applicant must have the right to possess, during the time period that the license would be or is effective, the premises described in the application. 
C.  Citizenship of Natural Persons. To be eligible to receive or retain any alcohol beverages license, natural persons must be citizens of the United States and residents of Wisconsin. 
D.  Qualifications of Corporate Applicants. To be eligible to receive or retain any alcohol beverages license, a corporation shall not have more than fifty percent (50%) of the stock interest, legal or beneficial, of such corporation held by any person or persons not eligible for an alcohol beverages license under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 7-2-6) 
5.08.060 - Application requirements. 
A.  General Application Requirements. The application requirements and procedures for an alcohol beverages license shall include the requirements and procedures adopted from Chapter 125 of the Wisconsin Statutes and the requirements and procedures prescribed in this section. 
B.  Corporate Applicants. Each corporate applicant shall file with its application a statement showing the names and addresses of the persons who have been its officers, directors and stockholders, and the amount of stock held by each such stockholder, during the previous twelve (12) months. Each corporate applicant or licensee shall file with the city clerk a statement describing any transfers of stock within five business days of each such transfer. 
C.  Applications for Premises Which Include an Outdoor Area. If an application for an alcohol beverages license includes an outdoor area as a part of the description of the proposed premises: 
1.  The applicant shall accurately describe the outdoor area which applicant proposes to be a part of the premises; 
2.  The applicant shall describe the nature of the fencing or other measures intended to provide control over the operation of the outdoor area; 
3.  The city clerk, or designated department shall notify, by first class mail, all property owners within one hundred fifty (150) feet of the outdoor area of the pendency of the application. Such notices shall state the date, time and place the plan commission will consider the application. Such notices shall be mailed at least ten (10) days prior to such plan commission. These notice provisions shall not apply to any application for the renewal of a license unless such application is for premises which would include an outdoor area, or a portion of an outdoor area, which was not a part of the premises previously licensed to the licensee. A publication will also be made in the official newspaper for the notice of the public hearing held by the common council and plan commission. 
D.  Applications for Temporary Class "B" Fermented Malt Beverages and "Class B" Wine Licenses. 
1.  Each application for a temporary Class "B"/ "Class B" license: 
a.  Shall correctly state the identity of the applicant; 
b.  Shall state the hours and dates for which such license is requested. No such license shall be valid for more than four consecutive calendar days; 
c.  Shall, if the event for which the license is requested is proposed to take place on city park property, identify the exact location and size of the area or areas proposed to be fenced in and shall identify the proposed main point of sale facility. The area or areas shall be proposed by the applicant and shall be subject to the approval of the director of recreation and the public works director or the directors designee; 
d.  Shall, if the event for which the license is requested is proposed to take place on city-owned property other than park property, identify the exact location and size of the area or areas proposed to be fenced in and shall identify the proposed main point of sale facility. The area or areas shall be proposed by the applicant and shall be subject to the approval of the chief of police or the chief's designee; 
e.  Shall, if the applicant is some type of group, identify the group. The application shall be signed by the president of the group making such application. or if there is no president. by the person who holds the highest position of leadership within the group. If any other person signs an application on behalf of a group, that person is in violation of this paragraph. If any person or group applies for a license as a front for some other person or group, the person or group which applied for the license is in violation of this paragraph; 
f.  Shall be accompanied by the following, if any portion of the proposed premises includes part of a city street, sidewalk, or park or part of any other area owned, controlled or maintained by the city: 
i.  A signed agreement to protect the city and others from claims relating to such license. Such agreements shall include an agreement to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the city and the city's common council, committees, officials, officers, employees and agents against any and all claims relating to any matter or incident which is in any way related to such license or is in any way related to acts or omissions related to such license, the issuance of such license or the use of such license. Such agreement shall include any other terms required by the city administrator, 
ii.  Written confirmation of the existence of a liability insurance policy issued to the applicant and approved, as to the policy's form and limits, by the city finance officer; 
g.  Shall be filed with the city clerk at least sixty days (60) prior to the granting of any such license. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Ord. 517 § 1 (part), 2000; Ord. 426 § 1, 1998; prior code § 7-2-7) 
5.08.070 - Review of applications and issuance of licenses. 
A.  Departments Review. The city clerk shall provide copies of each application for an alcohol beverages license, including each application for renewal of an existing license, to the chief of police, the chief of the fire department the building inspector, city planner, public works director, EMS director, and finance director or designees. 
1.  The chief of police, the chief of the fire department, building inspector, city planner, public works director, EMS director, and finance director or designees shall review each application and conduct any other appropriate investigation for the purpose of determining whether, consistent with the department's responsibilities to the city, if the department has any objection to issuance of the requested license. A written report shall be submitted to the city clerk which states whether the department has any such objection and, if it does, the basis for the objection. 
B.  Public Works Director and the Director of Recreation. If the application is for a special event Class "B" license for an area which is outdoors which includes city park property, the city clerk shall provide a copy of the application to the director of recreation and public works director. The director or the director's designee shall review the application and conduct any other appropriate investigation and then submit a written report to the city clerk which states whether the director has any objection to the application and, if he or she does, the basis for the objection. 
C.  Reports to Council. The city clerk shall provide to the common council all reports and recommendation received from the chief of police, the chief of the fire department, the building inspector, director of recreation, city planner, public works director, EMS director, and finance director or designees. 
D.  Discretion of Council. The common council shall review and act upon each application for an alcohol beverages license on the basis of the particular merits of each such application. Nothing in this chapter limits the factors the common council may consider when reviewing or acting upon each such application. 
E.  Issuance of Licenses. If the common council approves an alcohol beverages license, the city clerk shall issue the appropriate license to the applicant upon payment of the license fee. 
F.  Information on Licenses. All alcohol beverages licenses shall be numbered in the order in which they are issued and each shall state clearly the specific premises for which the license has been issued, the date of issuance, the date the license fee was paid and the name of the licensee and the conditions approved by the common council. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Prior code § 7-2-8) 
5.08.080 - Standards for premises. 
A.  Definitions. Except as otherwise provided, in this section: 
1.  "Convenience store" means a retail store featuring an incomplete assortment of food, food preparation materials and household items characterized by daily extended hours of operation, i.e., fifteen (15) to twenty-four (24) hours, seven days a week, where the average customer stay is short and parking turnover is high. Convenience stores are utilized by customers as quick-stop grocery stores usually selling beverages and food items. 
2.  "Grocery store" means a retail store of ten thousand (10,000) square feet or greater whose principal business is the sale of a complete line of food for off-premises consumption. 
3.  "Immediate supervision" means that the supervisor must be able to see at all times the activities of those persons selling the fermented malt beverages and/or intoxicating liquors. 
4.  "Liquor store" means a retail store whose principal business is the sale of intoxicating liquor, fermented malt beverages and related items such as cups, ice, mixers and snacks. 
5.  "Mixed retail store" means a retail store whose principal business includes the sale of such things as various lines of food for off-premises consumption and/or the sale of common necessaries like household goods, clothes or pharmacy items. Examples of such stores include what are commonly called "big box" stores, and which are not otherwise included in other defined businesses within this section. 
6.  "Specialty food store" means a retail store under ten thousand (10,000) feet whose principal business is the sale of fresh meats, seafood, cheeses, produce, candies or other similar food items. 
7.  "Premises" means the area described in a license or permit. 
8.  "Principal business" means the primary activity as determined by analyzing the amount of capital, labor, time, attention and floor space devoted to each business activity and by analyzing the sources of net income and gross income. The name, appearance and advertising of the entity may also be taken into consideration. 
B.  Terms and Conditions. The following standards are conditions precedent to issuance of any alcohol beverages license and are terms and conditions of every alcohol beverages license issued under this chapter. 
C.  General Standards. The general standards are: 
1.  Compliance with Law. The premises shall comply with all city, state and federal ordinances, regulations, codes, rules, statutes and laws, including those which become effective after issuance of an alcohol beverages license. 
2.  Houses. The premises shall not consist of or be in any dwelling house, flat or residential apartment. 
3.  Unpaid Assessments. The premises shall not have any delinquent or unpaid city taxes, assessments or other financial claims of the city. There shall not be any equipment on the premises which has delinquent or unpaid city taxes, assessments or other financial claims of the city. 
D.  Standards for Premises Licensed with a Class "A" Fermented Malt Beverage License. Only the following premises may be granted a Class "A" Fermented Malt Beverage license: 
1.  A liquor store with access to the public only provided directly from a public way. Sales and displays of fermented malt beverages or displays of merchandise may only take place in the licensed premises. 
2.  A convenience store provided: 
a.  A separate area is provided for the sale of fermented malt beverages and said area is surrounded by solid or gated walls at least seven feet six inches in height that restrict access to the fermented beverage area by the general public directly from a public way. A checkout to serve both sides of the business may be employed if it can be secured to prohibit access by the general public to the licensed premises when closed after permitted hours. One access for the general public may also be provided from the convenience store, however, such access shall be restricted in width to five feet wide and shall be able to be securely closed by use of a locked door or gate during those hours when sales are prohibited. Upon entering the licensed premises from the convenience store, customers may not return to the convenience store through the connecting doorway but must exit directly to a public way. 
b.  Fermented beverage sales are prohibited in the nonlicensed portion of the business.
