c.  Fermented malt beverages or displays of merchandise may only take place in the licensed premises. 
d.  During all hours that fermented beverage sales are permitted, no less than two employees shall be working at the convenience store location and all sales of fermented beverages must occur in the licensed premises and the sales transaction must be handled by a person licensed or directly supervised by a person licensed for the sale of fermented malt beverages as required by state law. 
3.  A grocery store or mixed retail store provided: 
a.  The area containing alcoholic beverages is only open to the public between the hours of eight a.m. and nine p.m. If the store continues in operation beyond those hours, a separate area for containing alcoholic beverages shall be provided, secured and located as follows: 
(i)  That the separate area provided for the display of fermented malt beverages is either enclosed by solid walls at least seven feet six inches in height, or in a separate aisle with solid shelving structures on each side at least seven feet six inches in height, so as to not allow access either through or over the adjoining structure into the fermented beverage area by the general public during hours of closure. 
(ii)  The through way that opens to the general store area may not exceed eight feet in width and must be capable of being locked and secured during the hours of closure with doors or gates so as to prevent a person from entering as required by state law. 
b.  An additional display of fermented malt beverages of up to five hundred (500) square feet shall be permitted throughout the general store area between the hours of eight a.m. and nine p.m. In the event the store holds both a "Class A" intoxicating liquor license and a Class "A" fermented malt beverage license, the combined display of both wine and fermented malt beverages shall be limited to five hundred (500) square feet or less. The display must be removed from the general store area and placed in a secure area between nine p.m. and eight a.m. 
c.  Sales may occur in the licensed premises or at the store checkout lines by a person licensed or directly supervised by a person licensed for the sale of fermented malt beverages. 
d.  If the fermented malt beverages are not kept in a separate clearly defined area, the applicant shall submit a security plan for loss prevention and present it for approval by the Sun Prairie Police Department for the issuance of any license. Issuance of the license is contingent upon approval of the security plan. 
4.  A specialty food store provided: 
a.  The store is only open to the public between the hours of eight a.m. and nine p.m. 
b.  The display of the fermented malt beverage is limited to one hundred (100) square feet or less. In the event the specialty food store holds both a "Class A" intoxicating liquor license and a Class "A" fermented malt beverage license the combined display of both intoxicating liquor and fermented malt beverages is limited to one hundred (100) square feet or less. 
c.  All sales transactions must be handled by a person licensed or directly supervised by a person licensed for the sale of fermented malt beverages as required by state law. 
E.  Standards for Premises Licensed with a "Class A" Intoxicating Liquor License. Only the following premises may be granted a "Class A" Intoxicating Liquor License: 
1.  A liquor store with access to the public only provided directly from a public way. Sale and displays of intoxicating liquor or displays of merchandise may only take place in the licensed premises. 
2.  A convenience store provided: 
a.  A separate area is provided for the sale of intoxicating liquor beverages and said area is surrounded by solid or gated walls at least seven feet six inches in height that restrict access to the fermented beverage area by the general public directly from a public way. A checkout to serve both sides of the business may be employed if it can be secured to prohibit access by the general public to the licensed premises when closed after permitted hours. One access for the general public may also be provided from the convenience store, however, such access shall be restricted in width to five feet wide and shall be able to be securely closed by use of a locked door or gate during those hours when sales are prohibited. Upon entering the licensed premises from the convenience store, customers may not return to the convenience store through the connecting doorway but must exit directly to a public way. 
b.  Intoxicating liquor sales are prohibited in the nonlicensed portion of the business. 
c.  Intoxicating liquor beverages or displays of merchandise may only take place in the licensed premises. 
d.  During all hours that intoxicating liquor sales are permitted, no less than two employees shall be working at the convenience store location and all sales of fermented beverages must occur in the licensed premises and the sales transaction must be handled by a person licensed or directly supervised by a person licensed for the sale of intoxicating liquor as required by state law. 
3.  A grocery store or mixed retail store provided: 
a.  The area containing alcoholic beverages is only open to the public between the hours of eight a.m. and nine p.m. If the store continues in operation beyond those hours, a separate area for containing alcoholic beverages shall be provided, secured and located as follows: 
(i)  That the separate area provided for the displays of intoxicating liquor is either enclosed by solid walls at least seven feet six inches in height, or in a separate aisle with solid shelving structures on each side at least seven feet six inches in height, so as to not allow access either through or over the adjoining structure into the intoxicating liquor area by the general public during hours of closure. 
(ii)  The throughway that opens to the general store area may not exceed eight feet in width and must be capable of being locked and secured during the hours of closure. 
b.  An additional display of wine of up to five hundred (500) square feet shall be permitted throughout the general store area between the hours of eight a.m. and nine p.m. In the event the store holds both a "Class A" intoxicating liquor license and a Class "A" fermented malt beverage license the combined display of both wine and fermented malt beverages is limited to five hundred (500) square feet or less. The display must be removed from the general grocery area and placed in a secure area between nine p.m. and eight a.m. 
c.  Sales may occur in the licensed premises or at the store checkout lines by a person licensed or directly supervised by a person licensed for the sale of intoxicating liquor as required by state law. 
d.  If the intoxicating liquor is not kept in a separate clearly defined area, the applicant shall submit a security plan for loss prevention and present it for approval by the Sun Prairie Police Department for the issuance of any license. Issuance of the license is contingent upon approval of the security plan. 
4.  A specialty food store provided: 
a.  The store is only open to the public between the hours of eight a.m. and nine p.m. 
b.  The display of the intoxicating liquors is limited to one hundred (100) square feet or less. In the event the specialty food store holds both a "Class A" intoxicating liquor license and a Class "A" fermented malt beverage license, the combined display of both intoxicating liquor and fermented malt beverages is limited to one hundred (100) square feet or less. 
c.  All sales transactions must be handled by a person licensed or directly supervised by a person licensed for the sale of intoxicating liquors as required by state law. 
F.  Standards for Premises Which Include an Outdoor Area. 
1.  Unless an alcohol beverages license contains express language to the contrary, premises licensed under this chapter include only areas within buildings and do not include any outdoor area. 
2.  The premises shall not include any outdoor area unless: 
a.  All parts of the outdoor area are more than one hundred (100) feet from all structures used for residential purposes, except the outdoor area does not have to be any distance from residential uses located in a structure which would be part of the licensed premises. 
b.  The outdoor area is less than fifty percent (50%) of the gross floor area of the portion of the proposed premises which is inside a building. 
c.  The outdoor area is completely enclosed with a fence not less than five feet high. 
d.  The outdoor area does not comply with subsections F.2.a.-c. above, but is authorized by permit under Sections 17.16.140(24) or 17.16.140(25) of the Zoning Ordinance, regulations pertaining to private outdoor cafes and sidewalk cafes, respectively. 
G.  Standard for Premises Licensed with a Special Event Class "B" License. Premises inside a building which are licensed with a special event Class "B" license shall have suitable exits and open spaces and adequate sanitary facilities to accommodate the number of people it is anticipated will attend the event. 
H.  Additional Standards for Class B Premises. 
1.  No Class "B", "Class B", reserve "Class B", or special event Class "B" licensee, shall suffer or permit any person to appear on licensed premises in such manner or attire as to expose to view any portion of the pubic area, anus, vulva, or genitals, or any simulation thereof, nor shall suffer or permit any female to appear on licensed premises in such a manner or attire as to expose to view any portion of the breast below the top of the areola, or any simulation thereof. 
2.  Any licensee who shall violate the preceding paragraph shall be subject to revocation, suspension or refusal to renew the license as set forth in Section 5.08.100 and the procedures in such section shall govern. 
(Ord. 622, § 1, 11-3-2015; Ord. 610, § 1, 6-16-2015; Ord. 491, § 1, 3-6-2012; Ord. 374, § 1, 8-19-2008; Ord. 323, § 1, 8-7-2007; Ord. 201, § 1, 6-21-2005; Ord. 2002-26, § 2, 2002) 
5.08.090 - Use of licenses. 
A.  Terms and Conditions. The following standards are terms and conditions of every alcohol beverages license issued under this chapter. 
B.  General Standards. The general standards are: 
1.  Compliance with Law. The licensee shall comply with all city, state and federal ordinances, regulations, codes, rules, statutes and laws, including those which become effective after issuance of an alcohol beverages license. 
2.  Hours. 
a.  Premises with a Fermented Malt Beverages License. Hours for premises for which a Class "A" or Class "B" license has been issued are as established by the Wisconsin Statutes except as provided below. The following provisions do not apply to businesses which are exempt from their application under state law: 
i.  Class "A" Licenses. Between nine p.m. and eight a.m., no person on premises for which a Class "A" license has been issued may sell any alcohol beverage. Between the same hours, the premises may not be open for the conduct of any type of business. 
ii.  Class "B" Licenses. Between nine p.m. and eight a.m., no person on premises for which a Class "B" license has been issued may sell any alcohol beverage in an original unopened package, container or bottle or for consumption away from the premises. 
b.  Premises with an Intoxicating Liquor License. Hours for premises for which a "Class A," "Class B," or "Class C" license has been issued are as established by the Wisconsin Statutes except as provided below. The following provisions do not apply to businesses which are exempt from their application under state law: 
i.  "Class A" Licenses. Between nine p.m. and eight a.m., no person on premises for which a "Class A" license has been issued may sell any alcohol beverage. Between the same hours, the premises may not be open for the conduct of any type of business. 
ii.  "Class B" Licenses. Between nine p.m. and eight a.m., no person on premises for which a "Class B" license has been issued may sell any alcohol beverage in an original unopened package, container or bottle or for consumption away from the premises. 
iii.  "Class C" License. Between nine p.m. and eight a.m., no person on premises for which a "Class C" license has been issued may sell any alcohol beverage in an original unopened package, container or bottle or for consumption away from the premises. 
C.  Standards Which Apply to Certain Premises. 
1.  Clubs. No club shall sell or give away any alcohol beverages except to bona fide members or guests invited to be members. 
2.  Temporary Class "B"/"Class B" Premises. 
a.  Fences. The applicant shall specify on their application what type of fencing they request for approval for the serving and consumption area. Fencing requirements shall meet one of the standards as listed below. All licenses shall comply with fencing requirements as approved by the common council. 
1.  A single eight-foot chainlink fence may be used to meet the fence requirements There shall be only one point of ingress and egress; or 
2.  A double fence with one point of ingress and egress. The double fence shall be a minimum of four feet high and minimum of six feet between fences. 
3.  A single four-foot vinyl fence with one point of ingress and egress; or 
4.  The applicant may request no fencing used, customers are allowed to consume in the designated event area. Signs shall be used to define the area. 
i.  Customers allowed to leave the sales area with no more than two cups of alcohol which were consumed in the consumption area. 
ii.  Volunteers stationed at the perimeter to enforce the alcohol containment in the area. 
b.  Signs. The licensee shall post at a conspicuous location at the main point of sale and at all remote points of sale, signs stating that no fermented malt beverages shall be served to any underage person. The licensee shall post all required signs designated in their permit. 
c.  Underage Persons at Point of Sale or Distribution. No underage person shall assist in the sale or distribution of fermented malt beverages at any point of sale. No underage person shall be inside the fenced area at any point of sale unless accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or spouse who has attained the legal drinking age. 
d.  Underage Person On-Premises. The licensee shall station a licensed operator or security guard at the entrance of each point of sale for the purpose of determining whether each person who attempts to enter the fenced area is the legal drinking age or older. 
1.  An underage person may enter and remain on-premises for which a temporary Class "B" license is issued under Section 125.26(6) Wisconsin Statutes, if the licensee permits underage persons to be on the premises and is authorized by the common council. 
e.  Licensed Operators. A licensed operator shall be stationed at all points of sale at all times. 
f.  Permitted Containters. Alcohol beverages shall be sold and served in approved containers. Serving containers shall meet the standards as listed below: 
1.  Alcohol beverages may be served in the following containers which has been opened with the cap removed by the server: 
-  paper, 
-  foam, 
-  aluminum, or 
-  plastic containers. 
g.  Exemptions. The city council may exempt an applicant from requirement(s) of subsections C.2.a. through f. upon a finding that such exemption is not contrary to the safety and well being of the public. When making such a finding the council shall review a site plan of the area in which the fermented beverage and/or wine will be sold or distributed, the hours of operation, the ability to maintain a secure perimeter around the premises, the method by which underage persons will be identified, the number of points of sale, and the provision of security. The council may require additional security at the applicants costs and add additional conditions to the license, (i.e., wristbanding, time limits, etc.) to provide for the safety and well-being of the public. 
3.  Outdoor Premises. If the premises include an outdoor area: 
a.  No amplified sound or music is permitted in the outside area unless approved by the common council. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Ord. 317, § 1, 6-5-2007; Ord. 517, § 3, 2000; prior code § 7-2-10) 
5.08.095 - Non-use of license. 
    Any Class "A", Class "B", "Class A", "Class B", or "Class C", fermented malt and/or intoxicating liquor and/or wine license granted under this chapter may be revoked by the city council following a public hearing for the following reasons: 
A.  The subject premises is not open for business within one hundred fifty (150) days of the granting of such license; or 
B.  The subject premises is not open for business for a period of one hundred fifty (150) consecutive days or more. 
(Ord. 271, § 1, 9-19-2006) 
5.08.100 - Suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of alcoholic beverages licenses. 
A.  Alcohol and Licensing Review Board. The city shall use the alcohol and licensing review board, hereinafter referred to in this section as the board, for all purposes for which the Wisconsin Statutes allow a committee of the common council to be used in proceedings relating to the possible suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of an alcohol beverages license. 
B.  Alcohol Beverages License Point System. 
1.  Purpose. The purpose of the alcohol beverages license point system, hereinafter referred to as the point system, is to create a demerit point system which will establish a standard for determining whether an alcohol beverages license shall be suspended or revoked. The point system is not intended to provide the only such standard, and such licenses may be suspended or revoked under other provisions of this code, including provisions adopted from the Wisconsin Statutes. 
2.  Assessment of Demerit Points. 
a.  The police chief or designee shall make point assessment recommendations to the board when it has been determined that a demerit point violation has occurred in accordance with the alcohol and license review board guidelines. A point violation occurs when a violation which is described within the demerit point schedule occurs on premises which are licensed with an alcohol beverages license. The alcohol license review by the alcohol and licensing review board may decrease the total demerit points assessed when the owner/bartender takes action to prevent/control the violation, including by initiating contact with the police. The violation may also be assessed when it occurs on properties adjacent to the licensed premises or in parking lots serving the licensed premises. 
b.  The issue of whether a point violation has occurred may be determined by a court or judge or, if it has not been so determined at the time the matter is before the board or the common council, it shall be determined by the board and/or the common council, as necessary. 
c.  If it is determined that a point violation has occurred, points shall be assessed against the licensee of the premises where the point violation occurred. Points shall be assessed in accordance with the demerit point schedule. 
d.  If it is determined that a point violation has occurred, points shall be assessed against the licensee of the premises where the point violation occurred regardless of whether the licensee or some other person or entity committed the point violation, and regardless of whether such point violation was committed with licensee's approval or knowledge. 
e.  If a point violation continues from one calendar day to the next calendar day, each calendar day that the point violation exists is a separate point violation. 
3.  Demerit Point Schedule. The demerit point schedule is as follows: 
Violations Demerit 
Points Commission of any act on the premises which requires a license which the premises does not have. 100  Failure to use license, as that offense is described in this chapter. 100  Failure to make the premises available for entry and inspection as required by ordinance. (These points are assessed one time for any one incident, regardless of the number of people who committed the violation.) 100  Illegal transfer of an alcohol beverage to an underage person on the premises. 50 Illegal transfer of an alcohol beverage by licensee or licensee's agent or employee to an intoxicated person on the premises. 50 Underage person on the premises illegally. 50 Commission of any act on the premises which is defined as a crime. (This does not require a criminal charge or criminal conviction.) 50 Violation of any ordinance relating to hours. 50 Failure to have licensee, agent or operator on the premises as required. 50 Improper exhibition, as that offense is described in this chapter. 50 Any violation of any other city, state or federal ordinance, regulation, code, rule, statute or law. 25  
4.  Suspension or Revocation. If a licensee has an activity that could be considered a violation at any one premises within any twelve-month period, the alcohol license review board may issue a letter of warning as an alternative to point assessment. The violation would be listed on file. If a licensee has [an] activity that could be considered a violation at any one premises within any twelve-month period, the alcohol license review board may issue a letter of concern and point assessment up to one hundred (100) points. If a licensee is assessed one hundred (100) or more points for one or more point violations which occurred at any one premises within any twelve-month period, all of the licensee's alcohol beverages licenses for such premises may be suspended or revoked. The alcohol license review board, as an alternative, may issue a formal letter of reprimand as an alternative to suspension and/or revocation, to a licensee who has been assessed one hundred (100) or more points but less than two hundred (200) points for one or more point violations which occurred at any one premises within any twelve-month period. If the licensee is assessed additional demerit points following the issuance of the formal letter of suspension or revocation within the same twelve-month period, all of the licensee's alcohol beverages licenses for such premises shall be suspended or revoked. If a licensee is assessed two hundred (200) or more points for one or more point violations which occurred at any one premises within any twelve-month period, all of the licensee's alcohol beverages licenses for such premises shall be suspended or revoked. If a license is suspended, it shall be suspended for not less than ten (10) days and not more than ninety (90) days. Licenses may be suspended or revoked during a certain license year regardless of whether point violations occurred during that same license year or during one or more previous license years. 
5.  Initiation of Proceedings Under the Point System. 
a.  The alcohol and licensing review board shall initiate proceedings to determine whether an alcohol beverages license must be suspended or revoked under the point system if: 
i.  The board deems it appropriate; or 
ii.  The board receives notice from anyone that a licensee has been assessed one hundred (100) or more points for one or more point violations which occurred at any one premises within a twelve-month period; or 
iii.  The board receives notice from the city attorney that it is the city attorney's opinion that one or more point violations have occurred which would cause a licensee to be assessed one hundred (100) or more points and that such point violations occurred at one premises within a twelve-month period. The city attorney's opinion may be based, in whole or in part, upon determinations made by a court or judge. 
b.  If the alcohol and licensing review board initiates proceedings under the point system, it shall proceed as it would if a sworn, written complaint against a licensee alleging that the licensee had violated this chapter had been filed with the city clerk by a city resident. 
C.  Hearing Procedures. During any hearing before the alcohol and licensing review board relating to the possible suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of an alcohol beverages license: 
1.  All parts of the hearing shall be audio recorded. If any party requests a stenographic recording and transcription, the city shall make the necessary arrangements but the expenses shall be borne by the requesting party. 
2.  The rules of evidence which apply during hearings of contested cases under Wisconsin's administrative procedure chapter of the Wisconsin Statutes shall be followed, so far as practicable, at any hearing before the committee. 
3.  The city clerk shall serve as secretary to the board. 
4.  Charges against a licensee must be proved to a reasonable certainty by the greater weight of the credible evidence. 
5.  The board's report to the city council shall be by majority vote of the board members present. 
D.  Common Council Review Procedures. 
1.  The city clerk shall provide each member of the common council with a copy of the alcohol and licensing review report, copies of all exhibits from the hearing and a copy of the transcript of the alcohol and licensing review hearing, if such a transcript is prepared and is made available to the city clerk prior to the council's consideration of the matter. 
2.  Only those members of the common council who have certified to the city clerk that they have read all of the materials provided to them about the matter by the city clerk shall be permitted to vote on the matter. The city clerk shall make such certifications a part of the record. 
3.  If the common council decides to suspend, revoke or not renew an alcohol beverages license, the licensee subject to that action shall pay the city an amount equal to the total of all expenses the city incurred in connection with the suspension, revocation or nonrenewal proceeding. 
E.  Issuance of Licenses After Revocation or Nonrenewal. 
1.  If the common council revokes a licensee's alcohol beverages license: 
a.  The city shall not issue any alcohol beverages license to that licensee within twelve (12) months of the date of revocation. 
b.  The city shall not issue any alcohol beverages license to any successor of that licensee within twelve (12) months of the date of revocation. 
i.  "Successor of that licensee" includes any corporation in which that licensee is an officer or director or in which that licensee has a financial interest. 
ii.  If the licensee whose license has been revoked is a corporation, "successor of that licensee" also includes: any individual who was an officer or director of that corporation at any time during the twelve (12) months prior to revocation; any individual who had a financial interest in the corporation at any time during the twelve (12) months prior to revocation; and any corporation which has an officer, director or stockholder that was, at any time during the twelve (12) months prior to revocation, an officer, director or stockholder of the corporation whose license has been revoked. 
2.  If the common council decides to not renew a licensee's alcohol beverages license: 
a.  The city shall not issue any alcohol beverages license to that licensee which would be effective within twelve (12) months of the expiration date of the license which was not renewed. 
b.  The city shall not issue any alcohol beverage operator license to that licensee which would be effective within twelve (12) months of the expiration date of the license which was not renewed. 
c.  The city shall not issue any alcohol beverages license to any successor of that licensee which would be effective within twelve (12) months of the expiration date of the license which was not renewed. 
i.  "Successor of that licensee" includes any corporation in which that licensee is an officer or director or in which that licensee has a financial interest. 
ii.  If the licensee whose license has been revoked is a corporation, "successor of that licensee" also includes: any individual who was an officer or director of that corporation at any time during the twelve (12) months prior to revocation; any individual who had a financial interest in the corporation at any time during the twelve (12) months prior to revocation; and any corporation which has an officer, director or stockholder that was, at any time during the twelve (12) months prior to revocation, an officer, director or stockholder of the corporation whose license has been revoked. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Ord. 498, § 1, 6-5-2012; Ord. 426, § 1, 12-15-2009; Ord. 182, § 1, 4-5-2005; Ord. 2003-122, § 1 (part), 2003; prior code § 7-2-11) 
5.08.105 - Security plan. 
A.  Security Plan. In addition to any other conditions placed upon a license by the common council at the time of approval, renewal or after a suspension/revocation or nonrenewal hearing pursuant to Chapter 5 of these ordinances, the police chief or designee is hereby authorized to impose additional conditions on such license, subject to the limits on authority in subsection B of this section. The clerk is directed to issue a new license that includes such additional conditions when notified in writing of such additional conditions by the police chief or designee. The previously issued license is declared void upon the clerk's preparation of the new license. 
B.  Limits on Authority. The police chief or designee is only authorized to formulate additional conditions that comprise a security plan in response to frequent or severe incidents requiring police intervention. No condition that is part of a security plan may be contrary to or inconsistent with any statute or ordinance regulating alcohol beverages or any other condition authorized to be placed upon the license by the common council. The police chief or designee shall consult with the city attorney in regards to the security plan. 
C.  Elements of Plan. A security plan may only include, but is not limited to the following elements: 
1.  Provision for licensed security guards. 
2.  Monitoring of interior and exterior areas by licensee. 
3.  Regulating traffic flow in parking areas. 
4.  Exterior and interior lighting. 
5.  Regular meetings with the police chief or designee and/or police department personnel. 
6.  The posting of regulatory signage to aid enforcement efforts. 
7.  Limitations on the number of patrons allowed on the premises at certain times. 
8.  Video surveillance. 
D.  Procedures. The chief of police or designee are encouraged to meet with license holders to develop a security plan but the elements of the plan are to be solely determined by the chief of police or designee. The chief of police or designee shall provide notice of the contents of the security plan in writing to the licensee. Implementation of the security plan shall commence within thirty (30) days of the delivery of the notice to the licensee and complete adherence to the plan shall be achieved within ninety (90) days of the delivery of the notice to the licensee. 
E.  Appeal. If the licensee objects to the security plan, the licensee shall so notify the city clerk within ten (10) days of the date of the plan. If the clerk receives an objection from the licensee, the clerk shall notify the alcohol and licensing review then shall schedule a hearing. The chief of police or designee and the licensee shall both be allowed to present evidence and make arguments. The alcohol and licensing review board may consider any probative evidence without regard to the rules of evidence. The hearing shall be audio recorded. The alcohol and licensing review board may accept, reject or modify the security plan as presented by the chief of police or designee. If the licensee is aggrieved by the action of the alcohol and licensing review board, the licensee has ten (10) days from the date of the decision by the alcohol and licensing review board to seek review by the common council. Review before the common council shall be upon a transcript of the proceeding before the alcohol and licensing review board. The common council may accept, reject or modify the decision of the ALRB. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Ord. 302, § 1, 2-20-2007) 
5.08.110 - Operators' licenses. 
A.  The common council may issue operators' licenses to applicants who are of the age eighteen (18) or older, and in accordance with state statutes. 
B.  The city clerk shall prepare a form which applicants for operator's licenses must complete and sign. 
C.  The clerk shall deliver each issued license to the applicant upon payment of the operator's license fee. 
D.  The city clerk may issue provisional operator's licenses in accordance with Wisconsin Statutes. The city clerk may issue a provisional operator's license only to someone who has applied for an operator's license and who appears qualified to obtain an operator's license. A provisional license may not be renewed or reapplied for within six months. 
E.  The city clerk may issue temporary operator's licenses in accordance with Wisconsin Statutes. 
1.  The city clerk may issue a temporary operator's license only to persons employed by or donating their services to nonprofit corporations. 
2.  A person is limited to only one such license in a year. 
3.  The license is valid for any period from one to fourteen (14) days, and the period must be indicated on the license. 
(Ord. 577, § 1, 2001; Ord. 368, § 1 (part), 1996; prior code § 7-2-12) 
5.08.120 - Fees. 
A.  The annual fee for an operator's license shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
B.  The fee for a provisional operator's license shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
C.  The fee for a temporary operator's license shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
D.  In addition to the fees stated, all processed applications will be assessed the actual cost of the background check as incurred by the city. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Ord. 415, § 1, 12-1-2009; Ord. 2001-22, § 4, 2001) 
5.08.130 - Information on licenses. 
    The city clerk shall number the operator's licenses in the order they are issued. Each such license shall state the operator's name and address and the date the license expires. 
(Prior code § 7-2-14) 
5.08.140 - Display. 
    Each license issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be available for inspection. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Prior code § 7-2-15) 
5.08.150 - Denial, suspension or revocation of operator's license. 
    Licenses issued under this chapter may be denied, suspended or revoked as provided by the provisions adopted from the Wisconsin Statutes. 
A.  Police Department. The city clerk shall provide copies of each application for an operator's license, including each application for renewal of an existing license to the chief of police or designee. 
1.  The chief of police or the chief's designee shall review each application and conduct any other appropriate investigation for the purpose of determining whether, consistent with the police department's responsibilities to the city, the department has any objection to issuance of the requested license. The chief or designee shall then submit a written report and recommendation to the city clerk. 
2.  If the chief or designee determines that the application may be denied, a report and recommendation shall be submitted to the city clerk which states the department has an objection and the basis for the objection. 
3.  The city clerk shall follow the denial procedure as set forth in "Sun Prairie Alcohol License and Review Board Procedural Guidelines". 
4.  The alcohol and licensing review board shall review the report provided by the city clerk, provide an opportunity to the applicant to respond to the report and prepare a report to the common council with a recommendation regarding the application. 
B.  Reports to Council. The city clerk shall provide to the common council all reports pertaining to the applicant. 
C.  Discretion of Council. The common council shall review and act upon each application for denial, suspension or revocation for an operator's license on the basis of the particular merits of each such application in accordance with alcohol and licensing review board guidelines. Nothing in this chapter limits the factors the common council may consider when reviewing or acting upon each such application. 
D.  Suspension, Revocation or Nonrenewal of Operator's Licenses. 
1.  The procedures and penalties set forth in Section 5.08.100 shall be applied to proceedings seeking suspension, revocation or nonrenewal of operators' licenses. 
2.  The alcohol and licensing review board shall serve for all purposes for which the Wisconsin Statutes allow a committee of the common council to be used in proceedings relating to the possible suspension and revocation of an operator's license. 
(Ord. 628, § 1, 1-19-2016; Ord. 2003-122, § 1 (part), 2003; Ord. 414, § 1 (part), 1997; prior code § 7-2-16) 
5.08.160 - Penalties. 
A.  Continuing Violations. If a violation of this chapter continues from one calendar day to the next calendar day, each calendar day that the violation exists is a separate violation. 
B.  Adopted Penalties. 
1.  Fines Treated as Forfeitures. Any provision adopted from Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, which provides that a person is subject to a fine shall be deemed to provide that the person is subject to a forfeiture. The amount or range of the forfeiture shall be the amount or range of the fine prescribed by the statute. 
2.  Penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this chapter which is adopted from the Wisconsin Statutes is subject to the penalty or penalties prescribed by the Wisconsin Statutes for violation of the Wisconsin Statute which has been adopted. 
3.  Limitation on Statutory Penalties. Notwithstanding the provisions of any adopted section of Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, to the contrary, no person is subject to imprisonment for violating any portion of this chapter. This provision does not limit the remedies available to the city if a judgment-debtor does not pay money awarded to the city in a judgment. 
C.  Penalty for Violation of Section 5.08.060(D)(1)(e). Notwithstanding any other provision in this chapter, any person who violates Section 5.08.060(D)(1)(e) shall be subject to a forfeiture of two hundred dollars ($200.00) and costs and will be ineligible to apply for any license under this chapter for one year from the date of the offense. 
D.  Other Penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this chapter who is not subject to a penalty or penalties under this chapter shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of this Code. 
(Prior code § 7-2-17) 
5.08.170 - Social hosting. 
A.  Purpose and Findings. The city of Sun Prairie intends to discourage underage possession and consumption of alcohol, even if done within the confines of a private residence, and intends to hold persons civilly responsible who host events or gatherings where persons under twenty-one (21) years of age possess or consume alcohol or consume alcohol regardless of whether the person hosting the event or gathering supplied the alcohol. The city of Sun Prairie finds: 
1.  Events and gatherings held on private or public property where alcohol is possessed or consumed by persons under the age of twenty-one (21) are harmful to those persons and constitute a potential threat to public health requiring prevention or abatement. 
2.  Prohibiting underage consumption acts to protect underage persons, as well as the general public, from injuries related to alcohol consumption, such as alcohol overdose or alcohol-related traffic collisions. 
3.  Alcohol is an addictive drug which, if used irresponsibly, could have drastic efforts on those who use it as well as those who are affected by the actions of an irresponsible user. 
4.  Often, events or gatherings involving underage possession and consumption occur outside the presence of parents. However, there are times when the parent(s) is/are present and condone the activity, and in some circumstances, provide the alcohol. 
5.  A deterrent effect will be created by holding a person responsible for hosting an event or gathering where underage possession or consumption occurs. 
B.  The provisions of Section 125.07(1)(a)(3), Wisconsin Statutes are hereby adopted by reference. The penalty or violation of the statute adopted by this section shall be as provided in Section 125.07(b), Wisconsin Statutes, except that there shall be no imprisonment. 
1.  Should any portion of this section be declared unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this section shall not be affected. 
2.  This section shall take effect and be in force from and after its passage and publication. 
( Ord. No. 725, § 1, 4-3-2018 ) 
Chapter 5.10 - NIGHTCLUB LICENSE 

5.10.010 - Nightclub license. 
A.  Nightclub License Required. No holder of a "Class B" and/or Class "B" intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverage license with a patron capacity of more than one hundred (100) shall offer or allow live entertainment without first obtaining a nightclub license from the city clerk. 
B.  Temporary Nightclub License. A licensed establishment may obtain a nightclub license on an event basis. Such license shall authorize live entertainment during a particular seventy-two-hour period. No such license shall be required for New Year's Eve and live entertainment will be permitted in all licensed establishments on New Year's Eve. No more than three temporary nightclub licenses shall be issued for the same premises in any license year. Fees paid for temporary nightclub licenses will not be credited against the fee for a subsequent application for a nightclub license. 
1.  Temporary nightclub licenses shall be issued by the city clerk. The issuance and review provisions contained in Chapter 5.08 shall govern the issuance and review of this event nightclub license. 
2.  The fee for each temporary nightclub license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). Applications received less than sixty (60) days prior to the event will incur a late fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Payment of the late filing fee shall not relieve any person from any other penalties prescribed in this chapter for failure to obtain the license. Payment of late filing fees with permit fees must be made with a credit card, certified check or cash. 
C.  Live Entertainment Defined. A licensed establishment that has a designated dance floor area shall be deemed to offer or allow live entertainment if any of the following activities are offered, permitted or allowed that are open to the public either free of charge or with a cover charge: 
1.  Live musical performances. 
2.  Disc jockeys. 
D.  Designated Dance Area Defined. An identified area of at least one hundred (100) square feet that is devoted to dancing. No dancing shall be permitted on top of a bar at which patrons are directly served. 
E.  Under Age on Premises. An establishment holding a Class "B" and/or "Class B" license and a restaurant permit and who meets the definition of a "restaurant" in Section 254.61(5), Wisconsin Statutes, shall, for times when its primary business is entertainment, submit a plan to the Sun Prairie Police Department and the Alcohol License Review Board (ALRB) that details the establishment's plan for identifying patrons under the age of twenty-one (21) and a specific plan as to how they will enforce drinking-age requirements. When the establishment's principal business, as that term is defined in Section 125.02(15m), Wisconsin Statutes, is entertainment, no patrons under the age of eighteen (18) shall be allowed on the licensed premises unless they are accompanied by a parent, legal guardian, or spouse who is of legal drinking age. 
F.  Identification of Patrons Twenty-One (21) Years of Age and Older. Any licensed establishment that meets the exceptions contained in Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, and Chapter 5.08 of the Sun Prairie Municipal Code of Ordinances for allowing underage patrons on the licensed premises, must have a means of visually and conspicuously identifying patrons who are twenty-one (21) years of age and older. It shall be the sole responsibility of the license holder to determine whether any of the exceptions contained in Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, and Chapter 5.08 of the Sun Prairie Municipal Code of Ordinances apply to their establishment. An establishment whose principal business is that of a tavern may not have underage patrons on the premises at any time unless an exception contained in Chapter 125, Wisconsin Statutes, and/or Chapter 5.08 of the Sun Prairie Municipal Code of Ordinances applies to their situation. 
G.  Security and Door Personnel. All security personnel and door personnel (e.g., ID checkers) shall wear clothing that readily identifies them as security personnel or door personnel. 
H.  Security/Operational Plan. All nightclub license applicants shall submit a security/operational plan at the time of application. The plan shall indicate what type of live entertainment the establishment will offer. The plan shall indicate if the applicant will employ security personnel and how they will be utilized. The security plan shall also set forth how the applicant will handle issues regarding: control and clearance of the parking lot during hours of operation and at closing time; unruly patrons; patrons who are intoxicated; patrons presenting false IDs; control and supervision of patrons under the age of twenty-one (21); the circumstances under which the police should be called and how physical disturbances (including fights) will be handled. The security plan shall also identify by name, date of birth, and driver's license or state identification, individuals who are employed by the establishment in a management capacity. 
I.  Control of Premises. At no time may licensee relinquish control of the licensed premises or the service of alcohol to any other person or entity. The licensee must remain in control of the premises and must continue to be in control of the alcohol and service thereof during all events, including private parties. The licensee and its employees will be held responsible for all conduct taking place on its premises at all times including conduct taking place during private parties. 
J.  Application. Upon application to the city clerk, the city clerk shall refer the nightclub license application to the police department, planning department, building inspector, EMS, city attorney, finance department, the fire chief and to the ALRB for a public hearing. The ALRB shall make a determination and recommendation to the common council regarding the issuance of the nightclub license. The ALRB may recommend, and the common council may impose, restrictions on the nightclub license hours relating to presentation of live entertainment if the information or evidence available to and considered by the ARLB and/or common council reasonably establish that such restriction is necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the designated neighborhood or necessary to prevent underage patrons from purchasing, possessing or consuming alcohol beverages on the licensed premises. 
K.  Fee. The annual license fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus the cost of publication and the license shall expire on June 30 following its issuance, this fee shall not be prorated. In addition to the fee stated, all processed applications will be assessed the actual cost of the background check, for each person listed on the application, as incurred by the city. 
L.  Renewal. Nightclub licenses shall be applied for by April 15th and shall be obtained on or before June 30th of each year or be subject to a late filing [fee] of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Payment of the late filing fee shall not relieve any person from any other penalties prescribed in this chapter for failure to obtain the license. Payment of fees after June 20th must be made with a credit card, certified check or cash. 
M.  Change in Operation. If, after the license has been granted or issued, the licensee wishes to make any substantial deviations from its original plan of operation, the licensee shall file a written request with the city clerk which states the nature of the change. No change shall take place until the request has been considered by the ALRB and approved by the common council. 
N.  Modification/Suspension/Revocation. A complaint for revocation, suspension or nonrenewal of a nightclub license may be made by an alderperson, the police chief, the city administrator, the city attorney, and/or any resident of the city of Sun Prairie. Complaints shall be made in writing and filed with the city clerk who shall then refer the complaint to the ALRB for a hearing. The city clerk shall also forward the complaint to the police department, planning department, building inspector, EMS, city attorney, finance department, and the fire chief. The ALRB may recommend to the common council that a nightclub license be modified or suspended for cause after notice to the licensee and a hearing. The city clerk shall notify the licensee within seventy-two (72) hours of the receipt of a complaint and shall provide a copy of the complaint to the licensee upon request. If a nightclub license is revoked, no other nightclub license shall be issued to the same person or the same premises unless there is a change in ownership and the new owner has no connection or relationship to the old owner for at least twelve (12) months. Nightclub licenses may be suspended or revoked or not renewed for any of the following causes: 
1.  Violation of any conditions or restrictions placed on the license by the common council; 
2.  Repeated violations of any provisions of the Sun Prairie Municipal Code of Ordinances and/or state statutes determined by a court or judge or, if it has not been so determined at the time the matter is before the board, it shall be determined by the board, as necessary; 
3.  The licensed premises is operated in such a manner that it has a substantial adverse effect upon the health, safety and welfare of the immediate neighborhood; 
4.  Frequent or severe incidents requiring police intervention; 
5.  Any other reasonable cause which shall be in the best interests and good order of the city. 
The licensee shall be notified in writing of the charges against her or him at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing. At the hearing, the complainant and the licensee will have an opportunity to produce witnesses, cross examine witnesses and be represented by counsel. The proceedings shall be tape recorded. Within ten (10) days of the hearing, the ALRB shall issue a written decision and recommendation stating the reasons therefor and forward such decision to the common council. If the common council rejects the recommendation of the ALRB, the matter shall be dismissed without costs to either party. If ordered, suspension shall be for a period not to exceed six months; revocation shall be for a period of one year. 
O.  Temporary Closing of Premises. In the event that the city administrator or his/her designee determines that a premises granted a nightclub license has violated its security/operational plan or has created an atmosphere placing the public and/or its patrons in imminent danger, the premises may be closed or patrons may be removed to restore the premises to its established occupancy for the evening and cleared upon order of the city administrator or his/her designee who shall refer the incident to the ALRB for review. If it is believed that a premises has exceeded its occupancy, the police department may clear the establishment and allow patrons to return to the premises as long as the total number of patrons allowed to return is counted as they re-enter. 
P.  Judicial Review. The decision of the common council shall be a final determination and shall be subject to review in court as may be provided by law. Any person aggrieved by the decision may seek review thereof within thirty (30) days after the date of the final determination. 
Q.  Licenses shall be required as of June 30, 2007. 
(Ord. 625, § 1, 12-15-2015; Ord. 416, § 1, 12-1-2009; Ord. 361, § 1, 5-20-2008; Ord. 301, § 1, 2-20-2007) 
Chapter 5.12 - BILLIARD ROOMS AND BOWLING ALLEYS 
Sections: 

5.12.010 - Amusement machines-Entertainment machines-Pool and billiard rooms. 
A.  License. No person shall within the city keep, operate or engage in the operation of an amusement machine, entertainment machine, pool hall, or billiard parlor to be used or patronized by others for hire or fee, without a license therefor. 
B.  License Application. Application for license to own or operate an amusement machine(s), entertainment machine(s), billiard table(s), pool table(s), or shuffleboard table(s) or similar device(s) within the city shall be made to the city clerk, giving the applicant's name, residence, a description of the operation for which a license is requested to include a description of the device for which the license is requested, description of the premises and location of device on premises upon which such device shall be operated and maintained, the name of the owner of the device(s), and whether or not such device(s) are situated upon any premises licensed for the sale of either intoxicating liquors or fermented malt beverages, or both, and if so, the exact nature of such business and the license under which it is operated. At the time of filing such application with the clerk, the applicant shall pay the clerk the proper license fee as stated in subsection E of this section. 
C.  Late Filing Fee. Renewal licenses shall be applied for on or before April 15th of each year or be subject to a late filing fee of five dollars ($5.00) per machine. Payment of the late filing fee shall not relieve any person from any other penalties prescribed in this chapter for failure to possess or obtain a license. 
D.  Transfer of License. Every license issued pursuant to this section may be transferred by the city clerk from the licensee to another person but no license issued pursuant to this section may be transferred from the licensed premises to another within the city. 
E.  License Fees. The fees for licenses granted under this section are: 
1.  For each pool or billiard table, twenty dollars ($20.00) per year; 
2.  For each shuffleboard table, twenty dollars ($20.00) per year; 
3.  For each amusement and entertainment machine, twenty dollars ($20.00) per year; 
4.  For each karaoke or jukebox, twenty dollars ($20.00) per year. 
F.  Late Fees: Licenses under this section shall be applied for by April 15th and shall be obtained on or before June 30th of each year or be subject to a late filing fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per machine. Applications submitted May 1st or after shall be subject to a late filing fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) per machine. Payment of the late filing fee shall not relieve any person from any other penalties prescribed in this chapter for failure to obtain the license. Payment of late filing fees and license fees after June 20th must be made with a credit card, certified check or cash. 
G.  Definition. "Amusement and entertainment device" means any table, platform, machine, electronic device, apparatus, or mechanical device operated or intended to be operated for amusement, pleasure, gain, test of skill, competition, or sport, the use or operation of which is conditioned upon payment of consideration either by insertion of a coin or token in a slot or otherwise. 
(Ord. 625, § 1, 12-15-2015; Ord. 420, § 1, 12-1-2009; Ord. 467 § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 7-13-2) 
Chapter 5.16 - BILL POSTERS 
Sections: 

5.16.010 - License required. 
    No person shall carry on the business of bill posting or of distributing along or upon the streets, sidewalks or public grounds or thoroughfares of the city advertisements or handbills, or post any handbills or advertisements without a license therefor. 
(Prior code § 7-13-1(a)) 
5.16.020 - Bond required. 
    A person desiring a bill poster's license shall execute a bond to the city conditioned for the faithful observance of the ordinances of the city, in the penal sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Prior code § 7-13-1(b)) 
5.16.030 - License fees. 
    The fee for a bill poster's license is ten dollars ($10.00) per year. 
(Prior code § 7-13-1(c)) 
5.16.040 - Prohibited places. 
    No person shall paste, post, paint, print, nail or otherwise fasten or append any handbill, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind on or to any sidewalk, tree, lamp post, utility pole, bridge, hydrant or upon any other article or property of the city, or over which the city has control, or upon any billboard, wall, door, gate or fence, or other private property without the consent in writing of the owner thereof. 
(Prior code § 7-13-1(d)) 
5.16.050 - Mutilation of bills. 
    No person shall destroy, tear, mutilate, cover over or otherwise deface or injure any bill or poster, posted in such place as may be permitted, without the consent of the person on whose behalf it has been posted. 
(Prior code § 7-13-1(e)) 
Chapter 5.20 - BLASTING AND ROCK CRUSHING 
Sections: 

5.20.010 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
    "Blasting" means a method of loosening, moving or shattering masses of solid matter by use of explosive compounds to prepare stone for crushing, to prepare stone for building and/or ornamental use, or to prepare property for development. 
    "Person" means any individual, partner, corporation, company, trustee or association, together with the respective servants, agents and employees thereof. 
    "Rock crusher" means any device, machine, apparatus or equipment used either individually or in conjunction with any other device, machine, apparatus or equipment for the purpose of crushing, grinding, breaking or pulverizing rock or stone. 
(Prior code § 7-11-1(a)) 
5.20.020 - Operation. 
    No person within the city shall operate a rock crusher or do blasting in such a manner so that any dust, dirt or vibration from such operation shall, in any way, damage or injure any person or property within the city. All blasting within the city shall be performed according to the requirements of Chapter Comm 7, Explosive Materials, Wisconsin Administrative Code, and all subsequent amendments thereto. 
(Ord. 190, § 1, 5-3-2005; prior code § 7-11-1(b)) 
5.20.030 - Permit. 
A.  Permit Required. No person within the city shall operate a rock crusher or perform blasting who does not possess a proper permit therefor from the city. 
B.  Applications. All applications for permits hereunder shall be made in writing upon the written form provided by the city and distributed by the city clerk. All applications for permits hereunder shall be signed by the applicant and filed with the city clerk at least sixty (60) days prior to the licensing period. The city clerk shall immediately refer all applications for permits hereunder to the city engineer. The city administrator may shorten the filing period after consulting with the city engineer. The city clerk shall issue a permit hereunder only after first receiving the approval of the city engineer, the duly executed certified check for the permit fee as hereinafter provided, and the submittal of the plan of operation, if required, as approved by the city engineer. 
C.  Certified Check. Each application for a permit hereunder shall be accompanied by a certified check in the sum of the required permit fee as hereinafter provided, or a renewal thereof, the same to be payable to the city. 
D.  Plan of Operation. Each application to operate a rock crusher hereunder or renewal thereof, shall be accompanied by a plan of operation which shall include: methods of screening from adjacent properties, hours of operation, hours of blasting and operation of rock crusher, dust and noise control, blasting procedures, location and height of stock piles, whether a rock crusher will be needed and how often, water supply, drainage course, maximum depth, legal description of property in question and other information the city engineer deems pertinent to the proposed operation. Such plan of operation shall be approved by the city engineer. 
E.  Each application for a blasting permit shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance identifying the city as a party insured in the amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for damage to property, and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injury to one person and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for injury to more than one person caused by the blasting. 
(Ord. 190, § 1, 5-3-2005; prior code § 7-11-1(c)) 
5.20.040 - Renewals. 
    All requests for renewals of permits hereunder shall be made at least sixty (60) days prior to the expiration date of the permit and must comply with all requirements of Section 5.20.030. 
(Prior code § 7-11-1(d)) 
5.20.050 - Blasting procedures and controls. 
A.  Energy Ratio. The allowable vibration of any blast at the nearest occupied or used building off the subject premises, shall not exceed an energy ratio of 0.5 or resultant particle velocity of 1.35? per second based on the following formula: 
Energy ratio = 0.5 = 10.823 f 2 A 2 
Where: 
f = frequency in cycles per second 
A = amplitude or displacement in inches 
Energy ratio = .274 V 2 
V = resultant particle velocity expressed in inches per second 
B.  Measurement of Blasts. The operator of the quarry operation, when requested to do so by the director of public works/city engineer, shall measure and submit data to substantiate compliance with the above formula and the operator of the quarry operation, when requested to do so by the director of public works/city engineer, shall measure air blast. This verification shall be performed by a seismological engineering firm acceptable to the city or by the director of public works/city engineer. Instrumentation shall be by seismograph similar to VEME Seismolog Model "B" and approved seismograph sound measuring equipment or approved equivalents. All expenses for these tests shall be paid by the quarry operator. 
C.  Blasting Log. A log in duplicate shall be kept of each blast on forms similar to the one on file with the city clerk. The original copy of this blasting log shall be filed with the clerk within forty-eight (48) hours after the blast, and a copy shall be kept on file at the quarry office. 
D.  Cover Material. Operators of quarries for building and/or ornamental stone removal shall cover Primacord, other detonating cord or surface laid blasting devices with at least one foot of dirt or other suitable cover material. 
(Prior code § 7-11-1(e)) 
5.20.060 - Permit fee. 
    The permit fee for any permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be as set forth below. No permit fee shall be prorated. All permits issued hereunder shall expire on December 31st following the date of issue: 
A.  Quarries using blasting to supply buildings and/or ornamental stone, ten dollars ($10.00) per blasting period; 
B.  Gravel crushing operation using portable or fixed crushing equipment less than thirty (30) days per year, ten dollars ($10.00) per year. 
(Prior code § 7-11-1(f)) 
5.20.070 - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a penalty as provided in Section 1.24.010 of this Code of Ordinances. However, upon conviction for the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter by the holder of a permit issued hereunder, and in addition to the forfeiture provided, such permit shall thereupon be cancelled, revoked, rescinded and terminated. 
(Prior code § 7-11-1(g)) 
5.20.080 - Enforcement. 
    Before renewal of any license issued under this chapter is refused or any license is revoked, cancelled, rescinded or terminated, the licensee shall be given written notice of any charges or violations against him or her or the reasons proposed for nonrenewal or revocation and shall have an opportunity to be heard before the common council. 
(Prior code § 7-11-1(h)) 
Chapter 5.24 - CABLE TELEVISION FRANCHISES 
Sections: 

5.24.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the cable telecommunications franchise enabling ordinance. (Ord. 405 § 4 (part), 1997: prior code § 9-4-1) 
5.24.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and the words in the singular number, include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory: 
    "Additional service" means a subscriber service provided by the grantee for which a special charge is made based on program or service content, time or spectrum space usage. 
    "Annual gross subscriber revenues" means those revenues derived from the supplying of regular subscriber service, that is, the installation fees, disconnect and reconnect fees, and fees for regular cable benefits including the transmission of broadcast signals and access and origination channels and revenues derived from per-program or per-channel charges, leased channel revenues, advertising revenues, or any other income derived from the system. 
    "Basic service" means all subscriber services provided by the grantee, including the delivery of broadcast signals and programming originated over the cable system, covered by the regular monthly charge paid by all subscribers. 
    "BTN channel capacity" means the highest total number of cable television channels on which television signals from separate sources may be delivered downstream simultaneously to every subscriber in the network. The network may have additional channel capacity for specialized or discrete purposes, but the technical performance specified shall not be materially degraded thereby. 
    "Cable telecommunications networks" means any network of cables, optical, electrical, or electronic equipment, including cable television systems, used for the purpose of transmission of electrical impulses of television, radio and other intelligences, either analog or digital for sale or use by the inhabitants of the city. 
    "Cable television system" means a system of antennas, cable, wires, lines, towers, waveguides, or any other conductors, converters, equipment or facilities by which the signals of one or more television or radio stations (or satellite transmission) are received directly or indirectly over the air and are amplified or otherwise modified and distributed primarily by wire or cable to subscribing numbers of the public who pay for such service. 
    "City" means the city of Sun Prairie in the state of Wisconsin. 
    "Class I cable television channel" means a signaling path provided by a cable television system to relay to subscriber terminals television broadcast programs that are received off-the-air or are obtained by microwave or by direct connection to a television broadcast station. 
    "Class II cable television channel" means a signaling path provided by a cable television system to deliver to subscriber terminals television signals that are intended for reception by a television broadcast receiver without the use of an auxiliary decoding device and which signals are not involved in a broadcast transmission path. 
    "Class III cable television channel" means a signaling path provided by a cable television system to deliver to subscriber terminals signals that are intended for reception by equipment other than a television broadcast or receiver by a television broadcast receiver only when used with auxiliary decoding equipment. 
    "Class IV cable television channel" means a signaling path provided by a cable television system to transmit signals of any type from a subscriber terminal to another point in the cable television system. 
    "Council" means the city council of the city of Sun Prairie and any legally appointed or elected successor or agency. 
    "FCC" means the Federal Communications Commission, Washington, DC 20554. 
    "Full network service" means all "basic services" and additional services offered by the grantee. 
    "Grantee" means all persons including, but not limited to, subsidiaries, parents, or affiliate companies, associations or organizations having any rights, powers, privileges, duties, liabilities or obligations, under the ordinance codified in this chapter, and under the franchise ordinance, collectively called the franchise, and also includes all persons having or claiming any title to or interest in the system, whether by reason of the franchise itself directly or by interest in a subsidiary, parent or affiliate company association or organization or by any subcontract, transfer assignment, mortgage security agreement, management agreement, or operating agreement or whether otherwise arising or created. 
    "Head end" means the land, electronic processing equipment, antennas, tower, building and other appurtenances normally associated with and located at the starting point of a cable telecommunications network, excluding the studio. 
    "Hub configuration" means a BTN design technology where in all transmission paths either originate or terminate at a central location within the community. 
    "Local distribution center" means a facility within the community remote from but connected to the hub which distributes signals from the hub to a specified area in the cable telecommunications network. 
    "Local distribution system" means that portion of the network that originates from a local distribution center as opposed to the hub. 
    "May" is permissive. 
    "Network noise" means that combination of undesired and fluctuating disturbances within a cable television channel, exclusive of undesired signals of discrete frequency which degrade the reproduction of the desired signal and which are due to modulation processes, thermal effects and other noise producing effects, not including hum. Network noise is specified in terms of its rms voltage, or its means power level as measured in a 4 MHz band above the lower channel boundary of a cable telecommunications network. 
    "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    "Physical mile of plant" means messenger strand as measured from pole to pole without taking into consideration sag or down guys, and for buried plant, actual trench feet. 
    "Reasonable notice" means the provision of notice of contemplated action delivered at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to such action. 
    "Sale" means any sale, exchange, barter or offer for sale. 
    "Service area" means that geographical area within the incorporated limits of the city. 
    "Street" means all streets, roadways, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, place squares, curbs, sidewalks, easements, rights-of-way or other public ways in the city which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated by law. 
    "Studio" means the land, electronic processing equipment, towers, building, cameras, lights and other appurtenances normally associated with and located at the grantee's local origination and/or public access points of a cable telecommunications network, excluding the head end. 
    "Subscriber" means a purchaser of any service delivered over the CATV system and includes those persons who are not required to pay any fee because of their exemption from fees by this chapter. 
    "Subscriber terminal" means the cable telecommunications network's 75 ohm cable terminal to which the subscriber's equipment is connected. Separate terminals may be provided for the delivery of cable television signals, FM broadcast, or other signals of differing classifications. 
    Substantially Completed. Operation will be considered "substantially completed" when sufficient distribution facilities have been installed so as to permit the offering of full network service to at least ninety (90) percent of the dwelling units in the service area to which access is legally and reasonably available. 
    "Terminal isolation" means at any subscriber terminal, the attenuation between that terminal and any other subscriber terminal in that network. 
    "Upstream" means the direction of transmission over the BTN from a subscriber terminal to the network's head end of hub. 
    "Video grade" means transmission, primarily analog in nature, including the picture phase of a television broadcast. (Ord. 579 §7 (part), 2001; Ord. 405 § 4 (part), 1997: prior code § 9-4-2) 
5.24.040 - Cable telecommunications franchise. 
A.  Franchise Required. No person, firm, company, corporation or association shall construct, install, maintain or operate within any public street in the city, or within any other public property of the city, any equipment or facilities for the distribution of television signals or radio signals or other intelligences, either analog or digital, over a cable telecommunications network to any subscriber unless a franchise authorizing the use of the streets or properties or areas has first been obtained pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, and unless such franchise is in full force and effect. 
B.  Review of Qualifications. Specific permission to operate a cable telecommunications network under the provisions of this chapter may be granted by the common council of the city to any grantee, provided that there has been conducted a public proceeding concerning the grantee's application for the franchise herein granted, which proceeding afforded all interested parties an opportunity to participate in, and comment upon, the legal, character, financial, technical, and other qualifications of the company and the adequacy and feasibility of its arrangements for the construction of a cable television system in the city. 
C.  Duration of Franchise. The franchise shall take effect upon filing by the grantee of the proper acceptance, the bond and the required insurance, and shall continue in full force and effect for a term of fifteen (15) years. It will be subject to renewal on the same terms or conditions as contained herein, or on such different or additional terms and conditions as may be lawfully specified by the council and as are consistent with the requirements of the FCC. No renewal hereof shall be granted unless authorized by the council following an appropriate public proceeding involving public notice and an opportunity for interested parties to participate, during which proceeding the grantee's past performance, the adequacy of the franchisee's provisions, and the consistency of those provisions with applicable FCC Rules have been considered. 
D.  Review of Franchise Prior to Expiration. 
1.  Public Meeting to be Scheduled. At least six months prior to the expiration of the franchise, the city shall schedule a public meeting or meetings with the grantee to review the performance of the grantee, including the results of the previous franchise reviews. The city may require the grantee to make available specified records, documents and information for this purpose, and may inquire in particular whether the grantee is supplying a level and variety of services equivalent to those being generally offered at that time in the industry in comparable market situations. 
2.  Determination on Reissue. The city shall, within thirty (30) days of the conclusion of such meetings, as determined by the city, make a decision as to whether the CATV franchise or franchises will be reissued and when such decision is made, shall establish the public proceedings leading to a final decision. Such public proceedings shall include but not to be limited to, a public hearing providing opportunity for the public and applicant(s) for the renewal franchise to appear and be heard. (Ord. 579 § 7 (part), 2001; Ord. 405 § 4 (part), 1997: prior code § 9-4-4) 
5.24.050 - Significance of franchise. 
A.  Franchise Nonexclusive. Any franchise granted hereunder by the city shall not be exclusive and the city reserves the right to grant a similar franchise to any person, firm, company, corporation or association at any time. 
B.  Franchise Amendable. The scope of any franchise granted hereunder shall be deemed amendable from time to time to allow the grantee to innovate and implement new services and developments; provided, however, that no such services or developments be implemented without the expressed prior approval of the common council. 
C.  Privileges Must be Specified. No privilege or exemption shall be inferred from the granting of any franchises unless it is specifically prescribed. Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to require the granting of a franchise when in the opinion of the council it would not be in the public interest to do so. 
D.  Authority Granted. Any franchise granted hereunder shall give to the grantee the right and privilege to construct, erect, operate, modify and maintain, in, upon, along, above, over and under streets, which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use in the city, towers, antennas, poles, cables, electronic equipment, and other network appurtenances necessary for the operation of a cable telecommunications network in the city; subject to the requirements of Section 5.24.250 of this chapter. 
E.  Consent Prior to Transfer of Franchise. Any franchise granted hereunder shall be a privilege to be held for the benefit of the public by the grantee. Such franchise cannot in any event be sold, transferred, leased, assigned or disposed of in whole or in part, either by forced or voluntary sale, merger, consolidation, mortgage, trust, receivership or any other means without the prior consent of the city expressed by a council resolution and then only under such conditions as the council may establish. Such consent shall not be withheld by the city without showing of cause. 
F.  Consent Prior to Change of Control. Prior approval of the common council shall be required where ownership or control of more than five percent or more of such right of control, singly or collectively. Transfer from a subsidiary to a parent corporation or vice-versa shall not be considered as a change of control. Prior approval of the common council shall also be required for all changes in ownership or control by a person or group of persons acting in concert, who already own or control five percent or more of such right of control, singly or collectively. Such approval shall be withheld by the city only upon a showing of cause. 
G.  Mortgage or Pledge of Network. Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit the mortgage or the pledge of the network or any part thereof. However, any such mortgagor pledge shall be subject to and subordinate to the right of the city under this franchise or applicable laws. 
H.  Previous Rights Abandoned. A franchise granted hereunder shall be in lieu of any and all other rights, privileges, powers, immunities, and authorities owned, possessed, controlled, or exercisable by a grantee or any successor pertaining to the construction, operation, or maintenance of a cable communications system in the city.
