A.  Each user discharging industrial wastes into a public sewer shall construct and maintain one or more control manholes or access points to facilitate observation, measurement and sampling of his or her wastes, including domestic sewage. 
B.  Control manholes or access facilities shall be located and built in a manner acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment. If measuring devices are to be permanently installed they shall be of a type acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment. 
C.  Control manholes, access facilities, and related equipment shall be installed by the establishment discharging the waste, at its expense, and shall be maintained by it so as to be in safe condition, accessible, and in proper operating condition at all times. Plans for installation of the control manholes or access facilities and related equipment shall be approved by the superintendent of wastewater treatment prior to the beginning of construction. 
(Ord. 504, § 1, 2000; prior code § 9-3-53) 
13.12.370 - Measurement of flow. 
    The volume of flow used for computing the sewer service for nonseptage disposal shall be based upon the water consumption of the person as shown in the records of meter readings maintained by the utility. 
(Prior code § 9-3-54) 
13.12.380 - Provisions for deductions-Exemption meters. 
A.  In the event that a commercial, industrial or public authority unit discharging wastes into the public sewers produces evidence satisfactory to the superintendent of wastewater treatment that significant amounts of the total annual volume of water used for all purposes does not reach the sanitary sewer, the commercial, industrial or public authority unit may be permitted to have an exemption water meter(s) installed. Residential units covered by the residential summer sewer averaging program, shall not be permitted to have an exemption meter nor shall they be permitted to have a second water meter installed in their residence for the purpose of measuring water used outdoors. 
1.  Exemption meter(s) will be charged a monthly service fee at the rate of fifty percent (50%) of the wastewater service charge for that size meter to compensate for furnishing, reading, bill preparation and periodic calibration of meter(s). This charge shall be in addition to the wastewater service charge. 
B.  The superintendent of wastewater treatment or his or her designee shall determine the type of meter to be installed and shall inspect the location requested for such meter(s). All costs associated with the inspection, installation, including any piping revision required to insure that only water not reaching the sanitary sewer is metered by the exemption meter, shall be at the owner's expenses. The city does reserve the right to periodically inspect and calibrate the exemption meter to insure conformity of use and accuracy of meters. All water meters shall be purchased from Sun Prairie Utilities. 
C.  The amount of exemption water meter shall be subtracted from the total amount of water used by the person to determine the applicable wastewater service charge. 
(Ord. 483, § 1, 12-20-2011; Ord. 2003-99, § 6, 2003; prior code § 9-3-55) 
13.12.390 - Metering of waste. 
    Devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required by the wastewater superintendent if this volume cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption records. Metering devices for determining the volume of waste shall be installed, owned, and maintained by the discharger. A maintenance schedule must be accepted by the wastewater superintendent. Following approval and installation such meters may not be removed without the consent of the wastewater superintendent. 
(Prior code § 9-3-56) 
13.12.400 - Waste sampling. 
A.  1.  Industrial wastes and septage discharged into the public sewers shall be subject to periodic inspection and analysis of character and concentration of such wastes. The initial inspection and analysis of BOD, total suspended solids, phosphorus, and ammonia nitrogen, shall be made by the water pollution control department at no cost to the discharger. The frequency of inspection and analysis of such wastes shall be determined by the wastewater superintendent. Additional tests so required by the superintendent to determine compliance with this chapter, shall be performed by a certified laboratory. Such laboratory shall be designated by the wastewater superintendent. All costs associated with the additional testing shall be at the expense of the industry or licensed disposer. 
2.  The water pollution control department shall sample for a period not to exceed two months to determine compliance with Sections 13.12.250 through 13.12.520 of this title which regulates the discharge of high strength and toxic wastes. 
3.  Extensions for the purpose of sampling beyond the two-month period may be requested by the discharger. The request shall be submitted in writing to the wastewater treatment plant superintendent within fifteen (15) days of the completion of the initial two month sampling period. The superintendent shall have the authority to grant or deny the extension. Extensions may be granted for a period not to exceed two months. The analysis of the wastewater shall be performed by a certified laboratory and shall be acceptable to the wastewater superintendent. All costs associated with the collection and analysis shall be at the expense of the discharger. 
4.  Industries who continue to exceed the definition of normal strength waste, shall be subjected to a surcharge as enumerated in Section 13.12.300. The industry shall be notified in writing by the wastewater superintendent and will be given three months to install the necessary equipment for the industrial sampling program. 
B.  Sampling shall be conducted in such a manner as to be representative of the composition of the wastes. The sampling may be accomplished either manually or by the use of mechanical equipment acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment. 
C.  Installation, operation, and maintenance of the sampling facilities shall be the responsibility of the establishment discharging the waste or septage and shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent of wastewater treatment. Access to sampling locations for the purposes of observation, inspection and sampling, shall be granted to the superintendent of wastewater treatment or his or her duly authorized representative(s) at all times. Samples shall be collected and preserved as per the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published by the American Public Health Association and Chapter NR 219, Wisconsin Administrative Code. 
(Ord. 244, § 1, 2-21-2006; prior code § 9-3-57) 
13.12.410 - Analyses. 
A.  All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association and Chapter NR 219, Wisconsin Administrative Code. Sampling methods, location times, durations, and frequencies are to be determined on an individual basis subject to approval by the superintendent of wastewater treatment. 
B.  Determination of the character and concentration of the industrial wastes and septage shall be made, as required, by the water pollution control department or by a certified laboratory so designated by the wastewater superintendent. The analysis made by the water pollution control department shall be binding as a basis for charges. If the person discharging the wastes contests the determination, the wastewater superintendent may elect to have an independent certified laboratory determine the character and concentration of the waste. Such independent laboratory shall be acceptable to both the wastewater superintendent and the person discharging the waste. All costs incurred by the water pollution control department or independent laboratory in making the determination shall be assumed by the discharger. 
(Prior code § 9-3-58) 
13.12.420 - Pretreatment. 
    Where required, in the opinion of the superintendent of wastewater treatment, to modify or eliminate wastes that are harmful to the structures, processes or operation of the wastewater treatment works, the person shall provide at his or her expense such preliminary treatment or processing facilities as may be determined required to render his or her wastes acceptable for admission to the public sewers. If a person discharging the waste contests the determination, the superintendent of wastewater treatment may elect to have an independent laboratory determine the character and concentration of the waste. Such independent laboratory shall be acceptable to both the superintendent of wastewater treatment and the person discharging the waste. All costs incurred by the independent laboratory in making the determination shall be assumed by the discharger. 
(Prior code § 9-3-59) 
13.12.430 - Submission of information. 
    Plans, specifications, any other pertinent information relating to proposed flow equalizations, pretreatment or processing facilities shall be submitted for review of the superintendent of wastewater treatment prior to the start of their construction if the effluent from such facilities is to be discharged into the public sewers. The superintendent of wastewater treatment may require a user of sewer services to provide information needed to determine compliance with this chapter. These requirements may include: 
A.  Wastewater discharge peak rate and volume over a specified time period; 
B.  Chemical analyses of wastewaters; 
C.  Information on raw materials, processes, and products affecting wastewater volume and quality; 
D.  Quantity and disposition of specific liquid, sludge, oil, solvent, or other materials important to sewer use control; 
E.  A plot plan of sewers for the user's property showing sewer and pretreatment facility location; 
F.  Details of wastewater pretreatment facilities; of materials; 
G.  Details of systems to prevent and control the losses of materials through spills to the municipal sewer. 
(Prior code § 9-3-60) 
13.12.440 - Grease and/or sand interceptors. 
    Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the building inspector, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing floatable grease or other substances specified in Section 13.12.250, or any flammable wastes, sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the building inspector and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. In the maintaining of these interceptors, the discharger shall be responsible for the proper removal and disposal by appropriate means of the captured material and shall maintain records of the dates and means of disposal which are subject to review by the building inspector. Any removal and hauling of the collected materials not performed by the discharger(s) personnel, must be performed by currently licensed disposal firms. 
(Prior code § 9-3-61) 
13.12.450 - City approval required for discharge of decontaminated water. 
    No one shall discharge decontaminated water into the city's sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system without first obtaining the approval of the city in accordance with this chapter. The city shall have sole discretion over whether any approved discharge shall be discharged into the city's sanitary system or storm sewer system. (Prior code § 9-3-62) 
13.12.460 - Application. 
    Any person who wishes to obtain the city's approval to discharge decontaminated water into the city's sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system must first submit an application in writing to the city, together with an application fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00), for review and approval in accordance with this chapter. The application shall be in such form as is prescribed for that purpose and shall include the following information: 
A.  The name of the person who wishes to discharge decontaminated water; 
B.  The location from which the decontaminated water is to be discharged; 
C.  The anticipated date of commencement of the discharge and the expected duration of the discharge; 
D.  The estimated volume of the discharge; 
E.  A copy of all analytical testing data or other information establishing the content of the discharge; 
F.  For all proposed discharges that the city determines shall be discharged into its storm sewer system, a copy of the WPDES application, any supporting materials submitted by the applicant to the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources to obtain a WPDES permit and a copy of the WPDES permit, draft permit, or other correspondence between the applicant and the DNR demonstrating the status of the applicant's efforts to obtain a WPDES permit; 
G.  A copy of any treatment plan approved or required by the DNR in connection with the issuance or future issuance of the applied for WPDES permit, or otherwise required in connection with the proposed discharge; 
H.  Any other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the city. (Prior code § 9-3-63) 
13.12.470 - City approval. 
    No discharge of decontaminated water to the city's sanitary sewer system or storm sewer system shall receive final approval from the city, unless all of the following requirements have been satisfied: 
A.  In the case of a proposed discharge to the city's storm sewer system, the applicant has received a WPDES Permit from the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources approving the discharge; 
B.  The city has determined that the discharge of decontaminated water will not pose a significant risk to public health or safety, city property, or result in the city being exposed to liability from any third party as a result of such discharge; 
C.  The applicant has agreed to abide by all conditions imposed by the city in connection with the approval of the discharge of the decontaminated water and all other conditions set forth in this chapter; 
D.  The applicant has provided the city proof of liability insurance, acceptable to the city, insuring the city against liability arising from the proposed discharge of decontaminated water. In lieu of such liability insurance, the city, in its discretion may accept a letter of credit or other security acceptable to the city for the purpose of holding the city harmless against such liability. (Prior code § 9-3-64) 
13.12.480 - Inspection. 
    Every approved discharger of decontaminated water to the city's public sewer system shall permit the city's superintendent of wastewater treatment or his or her duly authorized agent, at all reasonable hours of the day, to enter their premises or building to examine the pipes, fixtures and other facilities that pertain to the discharge of decontaminated water and to take such samples, tests or other measurements as they deem necessary. Each approved discharger of decontaminated water must, at all times, fully and honestly answer any questions put to them relative to the use and operation of their facilities for the treatment and discharge of decontaminated water. (Prior code § 9-3-65) 
13.12.490 - Metering. 
    Devices for measuring volume of decontaminated water discharged may be required by the superintendent of wastewater treatment if this volume cannot otherwise be determined. Metering devices for determining the volume of decontaminated water discharged into the city's public sewer system shall be installed, owned and maintained by the discharger. Following installation such meters may not be removed without the consent of the superintendent of wastewater treatment. (Prior code § 9-3-66) 
13.12.500 - Sampling. 
    Decontaminated water discharged into the city's public sewers shall be subject to periodic inspection and analysis of character and concentration of any hazardous substances that may be contained in such decontaminated water. The frequency of inspection and analysis of such discharged decontaminated water shall be determined by the superintendent of wastewater treatment. Any tests required by the superintendent of wastewater treatment to determine compliance with this chapter, shall be performed by a certified laboratory acceptable to the superintendent of wastewater treatment. All costs associated with any testing required by the city shall be at the expense of the discharger of the decontaminated water. Installation, operation and maintenance of any required sampling facilities shall be the responsibility of the discharger of the decontaminated water and shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent of wastewater treatment. Access to sampling locations shall be granted to the superintendent of wastewater treatment or the city's duly authorized representative at all times. Samples shall be collected and preserved in accordance with the analytical test methods and procedures set forth in Chapter NR 219, Wis. Adm. Code, and any amendments or replacements thereof. (Prior code § 9-3-67) 
13.12.510 - Costs and expenses. 
    All costs and expenses incident to the discharge of the decontaminated water shall be borne by the person discharging such water. The person discharging such water shall reimburse the city for any and all costs and expenses incurred by the city incident to any such discharge, including but not limited to, any consultant's fees incurred by the city plus one and five tenths (1.5) times the hourly rate for city staff time devoted in any way to the discharge or application for discharge of such water. The person discharging such water shall reimburse the city in full within thirty (30) days of receipt of an invoice from the city. (Prior code § 9-3-68) 
13.12.520 - Violations. 
    Whenever any of the terms and conditions of this chapter or of any permit issued by the city pertaining to the discharge of decontaminated water by any person shall have been violated, the city may undertake any of the following measures: 
A.  Immediately take steps to prohibit the continued discharge of contaminated water by the person or facility in violation, including without limitation disconnecting any connections to the city's public sewer system for such purpose; or 
B.  Seek injunctive relief to immediately prohibit the discharge of such decontaminated water; or 
C.  Take any other measures provided under this chapter; or 
D.  Take any other enforcement measures or seek any other relief available at law or in equity. (Prior code § 9-3-69) 
13.12.530 - Payment and penalty. 
    The sewerage service charge shall be for the corresponding period of the water bills, and shall be payable to the city not later than twenty (20) days after each period. A penalty of three percent of the net billing shall be added to all bills not paid by the date fixed for final payment. (Prior code § 9-3-70) 
13.12.540 - Charges a lien. 
    All sewage charges shall be a lien upon the property service pursuant to Section 66.076(7), Wisconsin Statutes, and shall be collected in the manner therein provided. (Prior code § 9-3-71) 
13.12.550 - Disposition of revenue. 
    The amounts received from the collection of charges authorized by this chapter shall be credited to a sanitary sewerage account which shall show all receipts and expenditures of the sewerage system. Charges collected for replacement expenses shall be credited to a segregated, non-lapsing replacement account. These funds are to be used exclusively for replacement. When appropriated by the city, the credits to the sanitary sewerage account shall be available for the payment of the requirements for operation, maintenance, repairs, and depreciation of the sewerage consistent with 40 CFR 35.929. Any surplus outside the preview of 40 CFR 35.929, in such account, shall be available for the payment of principal and interest of bonds issued and outstanding, or which may be issued, to provide funds for such sewerage system, or part thereof, and all or a part of the expenses for additions and improvements and other necessary disbursement or indebtedness, and the common council may resolve to pledge each surplus or any part thereof for any such purpose. All present outstanding sewer system general obligation bonds, including the refunding bonds, shall be paid from this fund as to both principal and interest. (Prior code § 9-3-72) 
13.12.560 - Additional charges. 
    Additional charges shall be imposed upon each lot, parcel of land, building, or premises served by public sewer and wastewater facilities located outside the boundaries of the city to equalize local capital costs. Such additional charges shall result in a minimum charge for each user according to the schedule for debt repayment from utility revenues. Such additional charges shall be added to the sewer bill for each billing period. (Prior code § 9-3-73) 
13.12.570 - Industrial waste pretreatment. 
    In the event the department provides pretreatment of industrial wastes, the entire cost of such pretreatment shall be charged to the person producing the industrial wastes. The costs shall include but not be limited to capital expenditures, operation and maintenance expenses, labor, chemicals, heat and power. (Prior code § 9-3-74) 
13.12.580 - Remedies from failure to pay service charges. 
A.  Each wastewater service charge levied by, or pursuant to this chapter, is made a lien upon the corresponding lot, land, or premises served by a connection to the sanitary sewer system of the city and if the same is not paid within the period allotted for such payment, such charge shall constitute a lien on the property served and be inserted in the city tax roll as provided in Section 66.076(7) of the Wisconsin Statutes in the same manner as water rates are taxed and collected under the provisions of Section 66.069(1) or 66.07 1(1)(e) of the Wisconsin Statutes as same has been, and from time to time may be amended or recreated, so far as applicable. 
B.  The wastewater service charges taxed or levied pursuant to this chapter shall be collected by the Water Utility at 125 West Main Street. The sewer department shall make and enforce such bylaws and regulations as may be deemed necessary for the safe, economical and efficient operation, management and protection of the city sewer system, the wastewater treatment plant and the sewer department. (Ord. 505 § 1, 2000: prior code § 9-3-75) 
13.12.590 - Biannual audit. 
    An audit of the department's financial standing shall be made biannually. This audit will be used to review the adequacy of the then existing rates and such rates shall be adjusted if necessary to provide sufficient revenues to adequately finance the department's operation in accordance with the original intent of the rate structure. The biannual audit and review shall also be used to insure that each recipient of sewage service (or user class) is charged in proportion to the cost of providing such recipient (or user class) with sewage service. (Prior code § 9-3-76) 
13.12.600 - Damages. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure or appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewerage system. Any person violating this provision shall upon conviction be subject to the general penalty provision of Section 1.24.010. (Prior code § 9-3-80) 
13.12.610 - Written notice of violation. 
    Any person connected to the sewerage system found to be violating a provision of this chapter shall be served by the city with a written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within a period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. (Prior code § 9-3-81) 
13.12.620 - Accidental discharge. 
A.  The accidental discharge of any prohibited waste into any sewer shall be reported to the wastewater superintendent by the person responsible for the discharge, or by the owner or occupant of the premises where the discharge occurs, immediately upon obtaining knowledge of the fact of such discharge so that steps may be taken to minimize its effect on the treatment plant. Within forty-eight (48) hours of the discharge, the person responsible shall file a written report on a form as provided by the wastewater superintendent. 
B.  Any person found to be responsible for accidentally allowing a deleterious discharge into the sewer system which causes damage to the treatment facility and/or receiving body of water shall, in addition to a forfeiture, pay the amount to cover damages, both values to be established by the common council. (Prior code § 9-3-82) 
13.12.630 - Continued violations. 
    Any person, partnership, or corporation, or any officer, agent, or employee thereof, who shall continue any violation beyond the aforesaid notice time limit provided shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to the general penalty of this code of ordinances found in Section 1.24.010, together with the costs of prosecution. In default of payment of such forfeiture and costs, such violator shall be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not to exceed five days. Each day in which any violation is continued beyond the aforesaid notice time limit shall be deemed a separate offense. (Prior code § 9-3-83) 
13.12.640 - Liability to city for losses. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned by reason of such violation which the city may suffer as a result thereof. (Prior code § 9-3-84) 
13.12.650 - Damage recovery. 
    The city shall have the right of recovery from all persons, any expense incurred by such system for the repair or replacement of any sewer pipe damaged in any manner by any person by the performance of any work under their control, or by any negligent acts. (Prior code § 9-3-85) 
13.12.660 - Penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or rules or regulations of the city or who shall connect a service pipe or discharge without first having obtained a permit therefor; or who shall violate any provisions of the Wisconsin Statutes, Wisconsin Administrative Code, or any other materials which are incorporated by reference, shall upon conviction thereof forfeit an amount as provided in the general penalty section of this code of ordinances in Section 1.24.010 and costs of prosecution. This, however, shall not bar the city from enforcing the connection duties set out in the provisions of this chapter for mandatory hookup. (Prior code § 9-3-86) 
13.12.670 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
    "Approved" means approved by the common council's public works committee or its designated agent. 
    "Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter in five days at twenty (20) degrees Centigrade, expressed as milligrams per liter. Quantitative determination of BOD shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods." 
    "Building" means a structure having walls and a roof erected or set upon an individual foundation or slab-constructed base designed or used for the housing, shelter, enclosure or support of persons, animals or property of any kind. For purposes of this chapter, each structure abutting another structure which does not have an approved ingress-egress doorway through the basement foundation walls, or structures which separate exterior or exterior abutting walls, or public use structures separated by an unpierced firewall, shall be considered as a separate or individual building. 
    "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer by gravity flow. 
    "Building inspector" means the building inspector of the city of Sun Prairie or such person's appointed assistant, agent, or representative. 
    "Building sewer" means that portion of the plumbing system beginning at the immediate outside foundation or proposed foundation wall to its connection with the main of a public sewer, private sewers, private sewage system or other point of disposal. 
    "City" means the city of Sun Prairie, Wisconsin. 
    "Committee or public works committee" means the public works committee for the city of Sun Prairie or such person's appointed agent or representative. 
    "Compatible pollutants" means biochemical oxygen demand, suspended solids, phosphorus, or pH, plus additional pollutants identified in the WPDES permit for the publicly owned treatment works receiving the pollutants if such works were designed to create such additional pollutants to a substantial degree. 
    "Connection charge" means a one time charge to a new sanitary sewer user, the proceeds of which shall be placed in a special escrow account to offset future plant expansion costs. 
    "Debt service" mean costs to the sewer department for the retirement of debts incurred in the provision of wastewater facilities, including both principal and interest. 
    "Decontaminated water" means groundwater or surface water that has been contaminated by one or more "hazardous substances" as defined in Chapter 292, Wisconsin Statutes, and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, but which subsequent to such contamination has been treated in accordance with a plan of treatment approved by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources and approved for discharge following such treatment pursuant to a WPDES permit, pursuant to a remedial action plan, or otherwise. 
    "Floatable oil" means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater or septage shall be considered free of floatable fat if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system. 
    "Garbage" means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking, and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage, and sales of meat, fish, fowl, fruits, vegetables and condemned food. 
    "Industrial user" means: 
1.  a.  Any nongovernmental, nonresidential user of a publicly owned treatment works which discharges more than the equivalent of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gallons per day (gpd) of sanitary waste and which is identified in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1972, Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented under one of the following divisions: 
    Division A. Agriculture, forestry, and fishing; 
    Division B. Mining; 
    Division D. Manufacturing; 
    Division E. Transportation, communications, electric, gas and sanitary services; 
b.  Division I. Services. 
i.  The city will exclude domestic waste or discharges from sanitary conveniences for determining industrial wastes. 
ii.  After applying the sanitary waste exclusion in subsection 1.a.i., of this section, discharges in the above divisions that have a volume exceeding twenty-five thousand (25,000) gpd or the weight of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) or suspended solids (SS) equivalent to that weight found in twenty-five thousand (25,000) gpd of sanitary waste are considered industrial users. Sanitary waste, for purposes of this calculation of equivalency, shall be wastes of normal concentration as defined in this chapter. 
2.  Any nongovernmental user who discharges wastewater to the city's sewers, which wastewater contains toxic pollutants or poisonous solids, liquids, or gases in sufficient quantity either singly or by interaction with other waste, to contaminate the sludge of the municipal sewer systems, or to injure or to interfere with any sewage treatment process, or which constitutes a hazard to humans or animals, creates a public nuisance, or creates any hazard in or has an adverse effect on the waters receiving any discharge from the treatment works. 
3.  All commercial users or an individual system constructed with grant assistance under Section 201(h) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act and this section. 
    "Industrial wastes" means wastes discharged by "industrial users." 
    "Licensed disposer" means a person holding a license under Section 281.48(3)(a), Wisconsin Statutes. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet, including storm sewers, into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    "Normal concentration" means: 
1.  Five-day twenty (20) degrees C., BOD of not more than two hundred (200) mg/l; 
2.  A suspended solids content of not more than two hundred fifty (250) mg/l. 
3.  A phosphorus concentration of not more than eight mg/l. 
    "Normal wastewater" means wastewater in which BOD, suspended solids, or phosphorus concentrations do not exceed normal concentrations. 
    "Nuisance". A nuisance under this section is referred to as any source of filth or probable human health hazard pursuant to the provisions of Section 254.59, Wisconsin Statutes. 
    "Operation and maintenance" means costs to the sewer department for the provision of labor, utilities, supplies, equipment maintenance, and other normal costs necessary for the provision of sewage service. Operation and maintenance includes replacement. 
    "Person" means any and all persons, including any individual, firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society, institution, enterprise, government agency, or other entity. 
    "pH" means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration. The concentration is the weight of hydrogen ions, in grams per liter of solution. Neutral water, for example, has a pH value of seven and a hydrogen ion concentration of 10 -7 . 
    "Pretreatment" means treating industrial wastes to remove or reduce the quantity or rate of discharge of one or more pollutants prior to discharge to the public sewer system, when required by governmental regulation. 
    "Phosphorus" is an element that is detected as phosphates in natural waters and wastewaters. Excessive quantities contribute to both detrimental and nuisance plant and aquatic life. Quantitative determination of phosphorus shall be made in accordance with one of the available procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods." 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    "Public sewer" means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
    "Replacement" means expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories, or appurtenances which are necessary to maintain the capacity and performance during the service life of the treatment works for which such works were designed and constructed. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer that carries liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with small quantities of ground, storm and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
    "Service pipe" is the lateral connection pipe. 
    "Sewage" is the spent water of a community. The preferred term is "municipal wastewater." 
    "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for carrying wastewater. 
    "Sewer department" or "department" means the Sun Prairie water pollution control department. 
    "Slug" means any discharge of water or wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period longer than fifteen (15) minutes more than five times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater treatment works. 
    "Standard methods" means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water, Sewage, and Industrial Wastes" published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Pollution Control Federation. 
    "Storm sewer" means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water or decontaminated water discharged pursuant to the approval of the city, granted in accordance with this chapter. 
    "Suspended solids" means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in water, wastewater, or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
    "Unpolluted water" is water of quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefited by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
    "User charge" or "wastewater service charge" means a charge levied on users of wastewater treatment works and the sanitary sewer system for the cost of operation and maintenance and debt service for such facilities. The term "operation and maintenance" include replacement. 
    "Wastewater" means the spent water of a community. From the standpoint of sources, it may be a combination of the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any groundwater, surface water, and storm water that may be present. 
    "Wastewater facilities" means the structures, equipment, and processes required to collect, carry away, and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent. 
    "Wastewater treatment works" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating wastewater, industrial wastes, and sludge. Sometimes used as synonymous with "waste treatment plant" or "wastewater treatment plant" or "water pollution control plant." 
    "Watercourse" means a natural or artificial channel for the passage of water, either continuously or intermittently. 
    "Wisconsin Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (WPDES) Permit" means a permit issued by the Wisconsin State Department of Natural Resources to any person pursuant to Chapter 283, Wisconsin Statutes, to permit the discharge of a pollutant into the waters of the state of Wisconsin. The city's WPDES permit shall mean the WPDES permit that established effluent limitations and monitoring requirements for the city's wastewater treatment work. 
(Ord. 245, § 1, 2-21-2006; Ord. 506, § 1, 2000; prior code § 9-3-90) 
Chapter 13.14 - STORMWATER UTILITY 
Sections: 

13.14.010 - Purpose and necessity-Authorization. 
    The city council of the city finds that the management of stormwater and other surface water discharges within the Upper Koshkonong Creek, Yahara River and Lake Mendota Watershed (Token Creek) and Maunesha River watersheds is a matter that affects the health, safety and welfare of the city, its citizens and businesses and others in the surrounding area. Failure to effectively manage stormwater affects the sanitary sewer utility operations of the city by, among other things, increasing the likelihood of infiltration and inflow into the sanitary sewer system. Surface water runoff may cause erosion of lands, threaten residences and businesses with water damage, and create environmental damage to the rivers, streams and other bodies of water within and adjacent to the city. A system for the collection and disposal of stormwater provides services to all properties within the city and surrounding areas including those properties not currently serve by the systems. The cost of operating and maintaining the city stormwater management system and financing necessary repairs, replacements, improvements and extensions thereof should, to the extent practicable, be allocated in relationship to the services received from the system. In order to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public, the city council hereby exercises its authority to establish a stormwater utility and establish the rates for stormwater management services adopting and publishing as required by law the regulations contained in this chapter, the city is acting pursuant to authority granted by Chapters 62 and 66, Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 70, § 1, 2002) 
13.14.020 - Creation. 
    There is hereby established a stormwater utility in the city. The operation of the stormwater utility shall be under the supervision of the city council. The city administrator or his/her designee will oversee and be in charge of the utility. 
(Ord. 70, § 2, 2002) 
13.14.030 - Authority of the stormwater utility. 
    The city, acting through the stormwater utility, may acquire, construct, lease, own, operate, maintain, extend, expand, replace, clean, dredge, repair, conduct, manage and finance such facilities, operations and activities, as are deemed by the city to be proper and reasonably necessary for a system of storm and surface water management. These facilities may include, without limitation due to enumeration, surface and underground drainage facilities, sewers, watercourses, retaining walls, ponds, basins, streets, roads, ditches and such other facilities as will support a stormwater management system. 
(Ord. 70, § 3, 2002) 
13.14.040 - Definitions. 
    In this chapter: 
    "Duplex" means a residential dwelling having two dwelling units. 
    "Dwelling unit" means a room or group of rooms providing or intended to provide living quarters for not more than one family. 
    "Equivalent runoff unit (ERU)" means the basic unit by which the stormwater utility charge is calculated under this chapter and is based upon the average impervious area of single family homes in the city on the date of adoption of this ordinance codified in this chapter. One ERU is three thousand four hundred sixty-eight square feet. 
    "Impervious area" or "impervious surface" mean a surface, measured on a horizontal plane, which has been compacted or covered with a layer of material so that it is highly resistant to infiltration by rainwater or the runoff from snow melt. It includes, but is not limited to, streets, roofs, sidewalks, parking lots and other similar surfaces, and semi-impervious surfaces such as highly compacted clay or gravel. 
    "Multifamily unit" means any residential property comprised of three or more dwelling units. 
    "Nonresidential property" means any developed lot or parcel not exclusively residential as defined herein, including, but not limited to, transient rentals (such as hotels and motels), commercial, industrial, institutional, governmental property and parking lots. 
    "Residential property" means any lot or parcel developed exclusively for residential purposes including, but not limited to, single family homes, manufactured homes, multifamily apartment buildings and condominiums. 
    "Single family unit" means any residential property, including manufactured homes, consisting of one dwelling unit. 
    "Stormwater conveyance system" refers to the system of streets, curbs, gutters, berms, swales, landscaping, detention and retention ponds or basins, pipes, outfalls, inlets, and other components of city infrastructure owned and/or maintained by the city for the purpose of managing, gathering, transmitting or conveying stormwater. This term includes tributaries, creeks, rivers and streams improved by the city to enhance their ability to convey stormwater. 
    "Stormwater utility" refers to the utility established under this chapter for the purpose of managing stormwater and imposing charges for the recovery of costs connected with such stormwater management. 
    "Stormwater utility charge" means the fee imposed under this chapter for the rendering of stormwater utility services by the city. 
    "Undeveloped Property" means property that is not developed by the addition of an improvement such as a building, structure, change in grade, addition of impervious surface, or substantial landscaping. A property shall be considered developed if: 
1.  A certificate of occupancy has been issued for a building or structure on the property or, if no certificate of occupancy has been issued, upon substantial completion of construction or final inspection; or 
2.  Construction of an improvement on a property is at least fifty percent (50%) completed and such construction has ceased for a period of at least three (3) months, whether consecutive or not. 
(Ord. 349, § 1, 12-18-2007; Ord. 70, § 4, 2002) 
13.14.050 - Connection. 
    Whenever public mini-storm sewers or storm laterals are laid along and within any public street, alley or place in the city and ready for use, property owners shall, upon notice from the city, connect to the facility provided to their particular property. All connections shall be in a manner in accordance with the State Plumbing Code. Failure of the property owner to connect within the time period specified in said notice shall result in said connection being made by the city and all charges being assessed against the property as a special charge. 
(Ord. 70, § 5, 2002) 
13.14.060 - Stormwater utility rates. 
A.  Introduction. The basis for computation of the charge for stormwater services and facilities provided by the stormwater utility to lots and parcels of land within the city is established under this section. The actual rate of charges to be imposed and any future changes in those rates may be made by resolution. All rates established pursuant to this chapter shall be fair and reasonable. A schedule of current charges shall be maintained and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
B.  1.  Exemptions. Exemptions to the charges comprising the stormwater utility charge are established in recognition that, in limited circumstances, properties may not benefit directly from all services and facilities provided by the stormwater utility. Owners of property satisfying the following criteria may apply to the city for an exemption from the equivalent runoff unit as described in this section. 
a.  Discharges to Surface Water Bodies. If more than half, as determined by the city engineer, of a customer's property drains directly into the Upper Koshkonong Creek downstream from the Koshkonong Stormwater Management Facility, Yahara River and Lake Mendota Watershed (Token Creek), Maunesha River or any tributaries draining to these water bodies, the city may, upon customer request, exempt the customer from a portion of the charge, provided that (i) the discharge is direct and not through any portion of the stormwater conveyance system owned or operated by the stormwater utility, and (ii) the drainage is not in violation of any environmental code or federal, state or local surface water drainage requirements and all required permits for said discharges have been granted. 
b.  From time to time the public works committee may adopt additional criteria under which owners may be eligible for exemptions to the charges comprising the stormwater utility charge. 
2.  Credits. Credits may be granted to owners of properties who have significantly reduced the impacts of stormwater discharge on the stormwater utility system. Owners of property which discharge all or a portion of their stormwater into privately owned and maintained stormwater facilities shall receive a prorated credit to the number of ERUs assigned to their property as determined by the city engineer. No owner may be given a credit in excess of sixty-five percent (65%) of their total number of ERUs. 
3.  Prior to receiving a credit or exemption, the city engineer or designee shall be allowed access to the property to determine the amount of credit or exemption to be granted. 
(Ord. 349, § 2, 12-18-2007; Ord. 70, § 6, 2002) 
13.14.070 - Billing. 
A.  The city department of finance is hereby appointed as the collection agency for the city stormwater utility. The city department of finance may contract for the billing and collection of stormwater fees. The department of finance shall allocate the actual cost incurred of billing and collecting to the expense of systemwide management and administration of the stormwater utility. 
B.  The bills for stormwater utility charges shall be mailed to the designated utility bill recipient, but this mailing shall not relieve the owner of the property from liability for rental property in the event payment is not made as required in this article. The owner of any property served which is occupied by tenants shall have the right to examine collection records of the city for the purpose of determining whether such rates and charges have been paid for such tenants, provided that such examination shall be made at the office at which the records are kept and during the hours that such office is open for business. 
C.  Stormwater utility charges shall not be payable in installments. If stormwater utility charges remain unpaid after a period of twenty (20) days from the date of utility bill, such bill shall become a delinquent special charge and shall become a lien as provided in Sections 66.0821(4)(d), 66.0703 and 66.0809, Wisconsin Statutes. These charges shall automatically be extended upon the current or next tax roll as delinquent against the property, and all proceedings in relation to the collection, return and sale of property for delinquent real estate taxes shall apply to such special charges. Charges not paid within twenty (20) days of issuance shall be assessed a one-time three percent (3%) late payment charge. 
D.  All delinquent special charges shall be subject to a ten percent (10%) penalty in addition to all other charges and prior penalties or interest when the delinquent special charge is extended upon the tax roll. 
(Ord. 158, § 1, 8-3-2004; Ord. 70, § 7, 2002) 
13.14.080 - Customer classification. 
A.  For the purposes of imposing the stormwater utility charge, all lots and parcels within the city are classified into the following customer classes: 
1.  Residential - single-family home and mobile home; 
2.  Residential - duplex; 
3.  Residential - multifamily and condominium; 
4.  Nonresidential; or 
5.  Undeveloped. 
B.  The city engineer or designee shall prepare a list of lots and parcels within the city and assign one of the classifications provided in subsection A.1. through 5. to each lot or parcel. 
C.  The average square footage of impervious area for an average single-family home in the city equal to one ERU shall be three thousand four hundred sixty-eight (3,468) square feet. 
D.  The charges imposed upon single-family and mobile home residential properties shall be the rate for one ERU. 
E.  The charges imposed upon duplex residential properties and condominiums of two units shall be the rate for sixty-five percent (65%) of one ERU (.65) for each unit. 
F.  The charges imposed upon multifamily and condominiums with three units or more shall be the minimum rate of four-tenths (0.4) of one ERU multiplied by the number of individual dwelling units existing on the property. Upon the owner's request, multifamily or mixed use properties may be treated as nonresidential properties as described in Section 13.14.080.G., provided the owner takes responsibility for the charge. 
G.  The charges imposed upon nonresidential property shall be determined by a rate for one ERU times a factor obtained by dividing the total impervious area of the nonresidential property by the square footage equivalent for one ERU. Such impervious area shall be determined based on the best information reasonably available. The result shall be rounded down to the nearest one-tenth (0.1). 
Actual Square Footage Charge = of Impervious Surface x rate for 1 ERU 3468 Square Feet  
H.  The charges imposed for undeveloped properties as defined herein shall be the rate for one ERU multiplied by a factor established by resolution. 
I.  The city engineer or designee shall be responsible for determining the impervious area based on the best available information including, but not limited to, data supplied by the city assessor, aerial photography, the property owner, tenant or developer. The city engineer or designee may require additional information as necessary to make the determination. The city engineer or his designee shall be allowed access on reasonable notice to the property owner in order to conduct measurements in order to determine impervious area. If access is denied, impervious area shall be presumed to be ninety-five percent (95%) of the total square footage of the property. The billing amount shall be updated by the city engineer or designee based on any additions to the impervious area as approved through the building permit process. 
J.  The minimum charges for any nonresidential unit and multifamily unit shall be equal to the rate for four-tenths (0.4) of one ERU, unless it contains no impervious surface. 
K.  All unoccupied developed lots and parcels with impervious surfaces shall be subject to a stormwater utility charge. 
(Ord. 349, § 3, 12-18-2007; Ord. 70, § 8, 2002) 
13.14.090 - New construction. 
A.  Except for single-family units, all new buildings shall be charged a portion of the established charge once a temporary electric meter has been installed or as determined by the city engineer. The established charge shall begin once the water meter has been installed or as determined by the city engineer. 
B.  On new single-family units, the stormwater fee shall be charged at the time an application is made for water and light service. 
(Ord. 349, § 4, 12-18-2007; Ord. 70, § 9, 2002) 
13.14.100 - Method of appeal. 
A.  The stormwater utility charge may be appealed as follows: 
1.  A written appeal shall be filed with the city clerk prior to the stormwater utility charge due date; or 
2.  Within thirty (30) days of payment, a written challenge to the stormwater utility charge must be filed with the city clerk on behalf of the customer, specifying all bases for the challenge and the amount of the stormwater utility charge the customer asserts is inappropriate. Failure to file a challenge within thirty (30) days of payment waives all right to later challenge the charge. 
3.  The disputed charge shall be held in abeyance until the public works committee has made a determination pursuant to subsection B. of this section. 
B.  The public works committee will determine whether the stormwater utility charge is fair and reasonable, or whether a refund is due the customer. The committee may act with a hearing and will inform the customer in writing of its decision. The committee may, at its discretion, require access to the property to assist in its determination. 
C.  The customer has thirty (30) days from the decision of the public works committee to file a written appeal to the common council. 
D.  If the council or the public works committee determines that a refund is due the customer, the refund will be applied as a credit on the customer's next monthly stormwater billing, if the refund will not exceed the customer's next quarterly stormwater billing, or will be refunded at the discretion of the city treasurer. 
(Ord. 70, § 10, 2002) 
13.14.110 - Special charge authority. 
    In addition to any other method for collection of the charges established pursuant to this chapter for stormwater utility costs, the common council finds that these charges may be levied on property as a special charge pursuant to Section 66.0627, Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 70, § 11, 2002) 
13.14.120 - Budget excess revenues. 
    The stormwater utility finances shall be accounted for in a separate stormwater special revenue fund and upon the completion of a detailed accounting of all assets in a separate stormwater enterprises fund maintained by the city. The utility shall prepare an annual budget, which is to include all administration, management operation, maintenance, debt service, capital improvement and other costs related to the operation of the stormwater utility. The budget is subject to approval by the city council. The costs shall be spread over the rate classifications as determined by the council. Any excess of revenues over expenditures in a year will be retained by the separate stormwater special revenue fund and ultimately the separate stormwater enterprise fund for subsequent years' needs. 
(Ord. 2004-124, § 1; Ord. 70, § 12, 2002) 
13.14.130 - Transfer of assets and outstanding debt. 
A.  The land rights and improvements of the city, or such rights determined to exist, for the following components of the public stormwater system are hereby transferred to the land assets of the Sun Prairie stormwater utility. 
1.  Stormwater sewers; 
2.  Inlets, catchbasins, retention ponds and related stormwater control features; 
3.  Access structures; 
4.  Greenways; 
5.  Fees collected for stormwater management and fees collected in lieu of land dedication. 
B.  Upon adoption of this ordinance codified in this chapter, the stormwater utility shall assume the responsibility for debt obligation on all outstanding general debt issued for storm drainage purposes including, but not limited to the city's 2001A issue dated February 26, 2001, and payable February 1, 2004. 
(Ord. 70, § 13, 2002) 
13.14.140 - Penalty. 
    A person violating Section 13.14.090 shall, upon conviction, pay a forfeiture not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, in addition to the costs of prosecution which are allowed by law. Each day during which a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 70, § 14, 2002) 
13.14.150 - Severability. 
    If any provision of this chapter is found to be illegal, the remaining provisions shall remain in effect. 
(Ord. 70, § 15, 2002) 
13.14.160-13.14.250 - Reserved. 
(Ord. 70, § 16, 2002) 
Chapter 13.16 - UTILITY FACILITIES RELOCATION 
Sections: 

13.16.010 - Purpose and scope. 
    The purpose of this chapter is: 
A.  To establish the city's procedures for implementing Section 66.047, Wisconsin Statutes, and to prevent delays to proposed city public improvements projects, and prevent contractor delay and expense due to uncertain scheduling of utility relocations. 
B.  To define a process and scheduling procedure to deal with utility conflicts with city public improvements projects, and arrange for their timely resolution. 
C.  To integrate the utility relocation process and the obligation of utilities to pay the cost of protection or changes to utility facilities in order to accommodate city public improvements projects under Section 66.047, Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-1) 
13.16.020 - Applicability. 
    This section applies to public improvement projects, engineered by the city or their consultant, which projects have utility facilities located on property controlled by the city and are let for construction after the ordinance codified in this chapter has been adopted and for which the city has mailed the notification and plans prescribed in Sections 13.16.040 through 13.16.060. 
A.  The city shall begin sending the notification and plans prescribed in Sections 13.16.040 through 13.16.060 for all public improvement projects engineered by the city or their consultant for which the design process is initiated after the ordinance codified in this chapter is adopted by the city. 
B.  This section does not apply to the alteration or relocation of railroad facilities. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-2) 
13.16.030 - Definitions. 
    The definition specific of words and phrases applies to this chapter: 
    "Business day" means any calendar day of the year exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. 
    "Calendar day" means any day of the year; if more than one day, it means any consecutive days of any year or years. 
    "City" means the incorporated city of Sun Prairie, Wisconsin and all lands within the boundaries thereof. 
    "Compensable work" means utility facility alteration or relocation work for which the city will reimburse the utility facility owner. 
    "Contractor" means the person or entity that enters into an improvement project contract with the city, and subcontractors or suppliers to the contractor. 
    "Mail" means a written transmittal, currently dated and sent to the addressee by regular or certified, return receipt requested United States postal service mail or other means. 
    "Noncompensable work" means utility facility alteration or relocation work which the owner must carry out without cost to the city. 
    "Owner" means the owner of a utility facility. 
    "Project plan" means a plan for a public improvement suitable for the design of utility facility alterations or relocations which the city sends to the owner. 
    "Utility facility" includes cable services. 
    "Work plan" means a plan of the owner to carry out utility facility alteration or relocation work to accommodate an improvement project of the city. 
    "Working day" means a business day on which weather and other conditions not under the control of the owner will permit utility facility alteration and relocation work to proceed for at least eight hours of the day with normal working force of the owner engaged in performing the controlling item of work in accordance with the owner's approved work plan. In determining the normal working force of the owner, consideration shall be given for any diversion of the owner's working force that is required to respond to an emergency involving restoration of critical utility service. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-3) 
13.16.040 - Notification. 
    The city shall make a reasonable effort to identify the utility facilities which are located within the street right-of-way and public lands and notify the affected utility of a proposed public improvements project. In addition, the city shall take the following steps: 
A.  Prior to November 15 of each year, the director of public works and or the city engineer shall prepare and recommend to the public works committee a list of public improvement projects for the next calendar year. A list of the public improvement projects shall be mailed to the owners with utility facilities in areas of the city affected by the proposed public improvement projects. The city may include a receipt of mailing form with the notification, in which case the owner shall complete the form and mail it back to the city within seven calendar days of receipt. 
B.  On or before December 31st of each year, the common council shall by resolution declare its intention to construct such public improvements in the next calendar year. The resolution shall include a general description and location of the construction and set forth the time within which there shall be removed or relocated all utility facilities that conflict with any of the proposed public improvements projects. A list of the public improvement projects shall be mailed to the owners with utility facilities in areas of the city affected by the proposed public improvement projects. The city may include a receipt of mailing form with the notification, in which case the owner shall complete the form and mail it back to the city within seven calendar days of receipt. 
C.  Within thirty (30) calendar days of the date the city mails the list of proposed public improvements projects to the affected owners, the affected owners shall notify the city, in writing, of whether it has any utility facilities in the path of the proposed public improvements projects. If yes, then each affected utility should supply to the city a description and the location of each utility facility that conflicts with the location of any of the proposed public improvement projects. 
D.  If the city wishes to construct a public improvements project that is not on the list of public improvements projects mailed to owners, then the city shall notify the affected owners and the city and the affected owners shall agree upon a schedule for relocating or removing the utility improvements found to be in conflict with the planned public improvements. If the owner fails to honor the agreed upon relocation/removal schedule, the owner shall be liable to the city for the forfeitures and other liability provided for in this chapter, in the agreement with the city (if any), and as is otherwise provided by applicable law. 
E.  Any owner who feels aggrieved by reason of the notification may, within twenty (20) days of the date of mailing of the notification, file its written objections thereto with the city engineer. Such objections shall state with specificity the nature and basis of the owner's objections. Such objection shall be referred to the public works committee for review of their merits. Unless the public works committee notifies the objecting owner within thirty (30) days after receipt of such objections that it finds them meritorious, the objections shall be deemed to have been denied, and the owner shall be obligated to provide the city, within ten (10) days after the expiration of such thirty (30) day period, the reply required under Section 13.16.030. The public works committee may, in its discretion, agree to enlarge the thirty (30) day review period, by providing notice thereof to the affected owner. Nothing in this section shall be construed to deprive such affected owner of any rights to administrative determination review to which they may be entitled under applicable city ordinances. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-4) 
13.16.050 - Project plan. 
    After the owner responds with the information required in subsection C of Section 13.16.040, the city shall mail the owner at least one set of project plans. The project plan: 
A.  Shall be mailed at least sixty (60) calendar days in advance of the date in which the utility facility is to be removed or relocated. The project plan shall show all existing utility facilities known to the city that are located in the right-of-way, easements and or public lands granted to the city; 
B.  May be sent by the city with a receipt of mailing form. If a receipt of mailing form is sent, the owner shall complete the form and mail it back to the city within seven calendar days of receipt; 
C.  Shall show those portions of improvements which give the project location, the planned public improvements, and the owner's existing utility facilities. The city, when requested, shall provide duplicate plan information needed by the owner to design and layout the removal, relocation, or additional facilities within the project limits; 
D.  Shall be reviewed by the owner to verify that the owner's utility facilities are shown, and are shown accurately. The owner shall notify the city in writing within thirty (30) calendar days after the date of mailing by the city if corrections or revisions are necessary to the project plan. If corrections or revisions are significant as determined by the city, an extension of time may be granted for providing of the work plan. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-5) 
13.16.060 - Work plan. 
    Upon receipt of the city's project plan, the owner shall submit a work plan. 
A.  The work plan shall: 
1.  Be provided to the city within thirty (30) days after the date of mailing of the project plan by the city. Upon owner request or its own initiative, when the city determines there is potential for conflict between work plans, the city will schedule a meeting that the owners are required to attend to coordinate the work. Additional calendar days may be granted to furnish the work plan if coordination is required with other utility owners. 
2.  For noncompensable work, shall include a narrative description of what work will be done: Whether the work is dependent on work by another owner: Whether the work will be done prior to the public improvements construction and which work will be necessary to coordinate with the work of the city's contractor: When the work will be started and the length of time in working days required to complete the work. 
3.  For compensable work, in addition to the items specified in subsection (A)(2) of this section, include an estimate of cost for utility facilities relocation including appropriate credits for betterments, used life and salvage. An executed conveyance of rights or quit-claim deed to the property occupied by the owner's facilities, if one is required by the city's project, may be submitted at this time. 
B.  The owner shall notify the city in writing prior to starting work identified in the work plan. The owner shall complete its work within the time frame described in its work plan. The owner shall notify the city when the work is completed. 
C.  If prior to the bidding date of a public improvements project, the city changes its project plan for that project, so as to require the removal or relocation of additional facilities, the city shall furnish the affected owners a revised project plan in accordance with the procedures and requirements of Section 13.16.050. All affected owners shall thereafter revise their work plans, in accordance with the requirements and procedures of this section, except that the revised work plans shall be submitted to the city within fifteen (15) days after the date of mailing by the city. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-6) 
13.16.070 - Responsibilities. 
A.  If the city requires relocation or adjustment of a noncompensable utility facility that was originally determined, per the work plan, to not need relocation or adjustment, the owner shall bear the cost of the relocation or adjustment. 
B.  If the city requires relocation or adjustment of a compensable utility facility that was originally determined, per the work plan, to not need relocation or adjustment, the city shall bear the reasonable cost of the relocation or adjustment. 
C.  The owner shall bear the cost of additional work to any portion of its facilities, after the facilities have been relocated or adjusted in accordance with a work plan approved by the city if the additional work is required by the city due to error by the owner in preparation of work plans for, field location of, or construction of the relocation or adjustment of its facilities. 
D.  The contractor shall be responsible for compliance with Section 182.0175(2), Wisconsin Statutes, with respect to precautions to be taken to avoid and prevent damage to utility facilities. 
E.  The owner shall complete alteration or relocation of its utility facilities in accordance with the work plan approved by the city and within the approved time frame. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-7) 
13.16.080 - Penalty. 
    In the event any affected owner fails to provide a work plan as required by Section 13.16.060, or fails to complete the relocation or alteration of its facilities in accordance with the work plan approved by the city, or otherwise fails to comply with the provisions of this title, then such affected owner shall be liable to the city, and the city shall be able to enforce the terms of this title, by taking one or more following courses of action: 
A.  Citing such affected owner for failing to comply with such provisions and imposing a forfeiture of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), with each continuing day that such owner fails to comply constituting a separate violation; 
B.  Obtaining an injunction, requiring the affected owner to comply with its obligations under this title, including relocating and/or altering its facilities; 
C.  Recovering all of the city's costs incurred as the result of the affected owner's failure to comply with its obligations under this title, including without limitation, all increased construction costs, contract damages, attorneys and engineering fees, and other costs arising in any way as the result of the affected owner's noncompliance. 
(Ord. 466, § 1 (part), 1999; prior code § 9-5-8) 
Title 14 - OFFICIAL MAP 
Chapters: 
Chapter 14.04 - OFFICIAL MAP 
Sections: 

14.04.010 - Intent. 
    It is the intent of the common council to establish an official map for the purpose of serving and promoting the public health, safety, convenience, economy, orderliness, and general welfare of the community; to further the orderly layout and use of land; to stabilize the location of real property boundary lines; to insure proper legal descriptions and proper monumenting of land; to facilitate adequate provision for transportation, parks, playgrounds, and stormwater drainage; and to facilitate the further subdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land. The official map referred to in this section differs from the "Official Zoning Map," referred to in Title 17; the "Official Traffic Map," referred to in Title 10; and the "Official Child Safety Zones Map," referred to in Title 9. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.020 - Authority. 
    This chapter is enacted under the authority granted by Section 62.23(6), Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.030 - Jurisdiction. 
    The jurisdictional area of this chapter shall include all lands within the corporate limits of the city of Sun Prairie and those areas outside the city within the extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.040 - Official map. 
    There is hereby established, as the official map of the city of Sun Prairie, the map which accompanies and is made a part of this chapter bearing the date of November 3, 2009. This map is hereby designated as the "Official Map of the City of Sun Prairie," and all notations, references, and other information shown thereon shall be as much a part of this chapter as though the matters and information thereon were fully described herein. The official map may show the location and extent of all planned new streets, highways, historic districts, parkways, railroad rights-of-way, public transit facilities, drainageways, parks or playgrounds, and other public facilities as authorized by state statutes, within the corporate limits of the city of Sun Prairie and its extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction as heretofore laid out, adopted and established by law. 
    Such official map consists of four sheets with the following titles: 
A.  Sheet 1 of 4 "Official Map Street and Roadway Classification City of Sun Prairie". 
B.  Sheet 2 of 4 "Official Map Street and Roadway Classification City of Sun Prairie ETJ Area". 
C.  Sheet 3 of 4 "Official Map Future Bicycle Routes/Paths City of Sun Prairie". 
D.  Sheet 4 of 4 "Official Map Potential Future Parks". 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.050 - Changes and additions. 
A.  Change or Add to the Official Map. The common council may change or add to the official map so as to establish the exterior lines of; widen; narrow; extend; or close any platted, existing, proposed, or planned streets, highways, drainageways, parkways, and parks or playgrounds, or other public facilities as authorized by state statutes. 
B.  Initiation of Request for Amendment to Official Map. Proceedings for amendment of the official map may be initiated by any one of the following four methods: 
1.  A petition by any member of the general public; 
2.  A recommendation of city staff; 
3.  A recommendation of the plan commission; 
4.  By action of the city council. 
C.  Refer for Review of Changes or Additions. The common council shall refer any change or addition to the official map to the plan commission for review and report thereon prior to adoption. The plan commission shall report its recommendation to the common council within sixty (60) days. 
D.  Public Hearing. A public hearing of parties in interest and citizens before the committee of the whole shall be required before any changes or additions to the official map are effective. Notice of the public hearing shall be published as a Class 2 notice pursuant to Chapter 985, Wisconsin Statutes. 
E.  When Public Hearing Not Required. Changes and additions made by duly approved subdivision plats shall not require a public hearing if the changes or additions do not affect any land outside the area being platted. 
F.  Periodic Revision of Map. The official map shall be revised periodically to reflect changes and additions approved by the common council in accordance with subsections (A) or (E) above. The city planner shall be responsible for keeping the official map current. A note shall be included on the official map to provide the date of the latest change or addition that is represented on the map. Other revisions may be made to correct drafting or other errors and omission in the earlier versions of the map, but shall not have the effect of amending the official map except for those amendments as adopted by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.060 - Building permits. 
A.  For the purpose of preserving the integrity of the official map, a building permit shall be required for any structure or part thereof that shall hereafter be located, erected, moved, reconstructed, extended, enlarged, converted, or structurally altered. No permit shall hereafter be issued for any building in the bed of any existing or proposed street, highway, drainageway, or parkway shown on the official map. No permit for the erection of any building shall be issued unless a street or highway giving access to such proposed structure has been duly placed on the map. 
B.  The building inspector may require each applicant for a building permit to submit a plan, prepared and certified by a registered land surveyor, showing accurately the location of any proposed building with reference to any street, highway, drainageway, or parkway shown on the official map. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.070 - Municipal improvements. 
    No public sewer or other municipal street utility or improvement shall be constructed in any street, highway, or parkway within the jurisdictional area of this chapter until such street, highway, or parkway is duly placed on the official map. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.080 - Appeals. 
    The board of zoning appeals shall have the power to review any administrative decision of the city building inspector to deny a permit for the erection of a structure under this chapter and to grant relief from the requirements of this chapter under the provisions of Section 62.23(6)(e), (f), and (g), Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.090 - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the city building inspector to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 432, § 5, 4-20-2010) 
14.04.100 - Penalties.
