15.16.020 - Monies owed city. 
A.  Applications Deemed Incomplete. Any application for a permit required by Title 15 from a person, firm or corporation having unpaid and overdue property taxes, special assessments, sanitary sewer hookup fees, park fees, impact fees, building permit fees, erosion control and stormwater management fees, any fees and/or charges owed pursuant to a predevelopment agreement, development agreement or an outstanding judgment owed to the City of Sun Prairie shall be deemed incomplete and shall not be reviewed by staff. This section does not apply to fees paid in installments pursuant to a development agreement if made within thirty (30) days of the issuance of an invoice by the city. 
B.  Hearing Request. Upon receipt of such an application from a person, firm or corporation having unpaid fees or accounts due to the City of Sun Prairie the person, firm or corporation shall be notified the application will not be accepted and that they may request a hearing before the finance committee regarding the unpaid fees. The request for a hearing must be made within thirty (30) days of the issuance of the notice. 
C.  Appeal. The applicant has a right to appeal the decision of the finance committee to the city council within thirty (30) days of issuance of a denial of their appeal. 
(Ord. 2002-57 § 1, 2002) 
Chapter 15.20 - ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

15.20.010 - Penalties and violations. 
A.  Any building or structure hereafter erected, enlarged, altered or repaired, or any use hereafter established, in violation of the provisions of this shall be deemed an unlawful building, structure or use. The building inspector shall promptly report all such violations to the common council and city attorney, who shall bring an action to enjoin the erection, enlargement, alteration, repair or moving of such building or structure of the establishment of such use, or to cause such building, structure or use to be removed and may also be subject to a penalty as provided in general penalty provisions, Section 1.24.010 of the city of Sun Prairie code of ordinances. In any such action, the fact that a permit was issued shall not constitute a defense, nor shall any error, oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of the building inspector constitute a defense. compliance with the provisions of this chapter may also be enforced by injunctional order at the suit of the owner or owners of any real estate within the jurisdiction of this chapter. 
B.  1. If an inspection reveals a noncompliance with this chapter or the Uniform Dwelling Code, the building inspector shall notify the applicant and the owner, in writing, of the violation to be corrected. All cited violations shall be corrected within thirty (30) days after written notification unless an extension of time is granted pursuant to Section ILHR 20.10(1)(c), Wis. Adm. Code. 
2.  If, after written notification, the violation is not corrected within thirty (30) days, a stop-work order may be served on the owner or his or her representative and a copy thereof shall be posted at the construction site. Such stop-work order shall not be removed except by written notice of the building inspector after satisfactory evidence has been supplied that the cited violation has been corrected. 
3.  Each day each violation continues after the thirty (30) day written notice period has run shall constitute a separate offense. Nothing in this chapter shall preclude the city from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of any provision of this chapter or the Uniform Dwelling Code. 
4.  If any construction or work governed by the provisions of this chapter or the Uniform Dwelling Code is commenced prior to the issuance of a permit, double fees shall be charged. 
C.  Any person feeling aggrieved by an order or a determination of the building inspector may appeal from such order or determination to the board of appeals. Those procedures customarily used to effectuate an appeal to the board of appeals shall apply. 
D.  Except as may otherwise be provided by the statute or ordinance, no officer, agent or employee of the city charged with the enforcement of this chapter shall render himself or herself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his or her duties under this chapter. Any suit brought against any officer, agent, or employee of the city, as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his or her duties under this chapter, shall be defended by the legal representative of the city until the final determination of the proceedings therein. (Prior code § 15-1-51) 
Chapter 15.24 - HANDICAPPED ACCESS TO PUBLIC BUILDINGS 
Sections: 

15.24.010 - Grievance procedures regarding access to public buildings by handicapped persons. 
A.  Statement of Purpose. The city is committed to providing adequate access by handicapped or visually impaired persons to public buildings financed in part by federal revenue sharing. This section provides for a grievance procedure providing for prompt and equitable resolution of complaints alleging any action prohibited by the Office of Revenue Sharing's (ORS) regulations (31 C.F.R. 51.55(d)(2)) implementing Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, as amended (29 U.S.C. 794), Section 504 states, in part, that "no otherwise qualified handicapped individual...shall, solely by reason of his handicap, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any program or activity receiving federal financial assistance..." 
B.  Complaint Procedure. 
1.  Complaints should be filed with the city administrator, who has been designated to coordinate Section 504 Compliance. 
2.  A complaint should be filed in writing or verbally, contain the name and address of the person filing it, and briefly describe the alleged violation of the regulations. 
3.  A complaint should be filed within thirty (30) days after the complainant becomes aware of the alleged violation. (Processing of allegations of discrimination occurring before this grievance procedure was in place will be considered on a case-by-case basis.) 
4.  An investigation, as may be appropriate, shall follow a filing of a complaint. The investigation will be conducted by an appropriate person designated by the city administrator who should review the Handicapped Requirements Handbook published by the Federal Programs Advisory Service. 
5.  A written determination as to the validity of the complaint and description of resolution, if any, shall be issued by the designated person and a copy forwarded to the complainant no later than thirty (30) days after its filing. 
6.  The Section 504 coordinator shall maintain the files and records of the city relating to the complaints filed. 
C.  Appeals. 
1.  The complainant may appeal the decision of the Section 504 coordinator where he or she is dissatisfied with the resolution. The appeal request shall be made within seven days to the city administrator. 
2.  The grievance shall be heard by the common council within ten (10) working days after the filing of an appeals request. The grievance shall be heard at the municipal building at a convenient time fixed by the council. The city clerk shall give at least three days written notice to the applicant by first class mail of any such grievance hearing. 
3.  Either party to the grievance may be represented, present evidence by testimony or otherwise, cross-examine witnesses and make argument either in person or by an agent of his or her choosing. Proceedings may and, upon request of the applicant, shall be recorded. 
4.  The decision of the common council on the grievance appeal shall be in writing and shall state the reasons for the decision. The decision of the council shall be rendered within three working days of the close of the hearing and the common council shall immediately upon rendering the decision mail a copy thereof by first class mail to the applicant at the current post office address given in his or her application and record a copy of its determination with the city clerk. 
D.  Other Remedies. The right of a person to a prompt and equitable resolution of the complaint filed hereunder shall not be impaired by the person's pursuit of other remedies such as the filing of a Section 504 complaint with the Office of Revenue Sharing, U.S. Department of the Treasury. Utilization of this grievance procedure is not a prerequisite to the pursuit of other remedies. However, the city believes that resolution of the complaint will be more promptly achieved if the city is able to provide a remedy before the complaint is brought to an external organization. 
E.  Due Process. This section shall be construed to protect the substantive rights of interested persons, to meet appropriate due process standards and to assure that the city complies with Section 504 and the ORS regulations. 
(Prior code § 15-3-1) 
Chapter 15.28 - EROSION CONTROL 
Sections: 

15.28.010 - Authority. 
    This chapter is adopted pursuant to the authority of and in accordance with the standards set forth in Sections 62.23, 62.234, 101.1205, 101.653 and 281.33, Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-1) 
15.28.020 - Findings and purpose. 
A.  Findings. The common council finds as follows: 
1.  Stormwater runoff from construction sites and from lands after development carries a significant amount of sediment and other pollutants to the waters of the state and the City of Sun Prairie. 
2.  The city has had in place an erosion control ordinance since at least December 17, 1991 (when it adopted Ordinance No. 204) to regulate land disturbing and land developing activities on lands within the boundaries and jurisdiction of the city and the public and private lands subject to extraterritorial review under Chapter 236, Wisconsin Statutes. 
3.  Recent developments in erosion control practices suggest a substantial need to incorporate current best practices into the city's erosion control ordinance. 
4.  This ordinance is intended to achieve an eighty percent (80%) reduction in sediment load rates to Dane County waters in all new developments, forty percent (40%) reduction in all redevelopments, and twenty percent (20%) reduction in existing developments. 
5.  This ordinance is intended to ensure no increase in temperature of stormwater runoff in order to protect cold water communities. 
B.  Purpose. It is the purpose of this chapter to promote public health, safety and general welfare and to protect natural resources; to further the maintenance of safe and healthful conditions; to prevent and control water pollution; to protect spawning grounds, fish and aquatic life; to control building sites, placement of structures and land uses; to preserve ground cover and scenic beauty; and to promote sound economic growth. 
(Ord. 2002-51 § 1, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-2) 
15.28.030 - Applicability. 
    This chapter applies to any land disturbing activity occurring on lands within the territorial limits and jurisdiction of the city and publicly-owned or privately-owned lands within the extraterritorial land division review jurisdiction of the city pursuant to Chapter 236, Wisconsin Statutes, which lands involve any of the following: 
A.  A subdivision of land or a land division by certified survey, as those terms are defined in Wisconsin Statutes Chapter 236 and Title 14 of the Sun Prairie Code of Ordinances; 
B.  An area of four thousand (4,000) square feet or greater that will be disturbed by grading, removal of protective ground cover or vegetation, excavation, land filling or other land disturbing activities, or activities on a slope steeper than twelve percent (12%); 
C.  Excavation, filling or a combination of excavation and filling thereof exceeds four hundred (400) cubic yards or more of dirt, sand or other excavation or fill material; 
D.  Any public street, highway, road or bridge is to be constructed, enlarged, relocated or substantially reconstructed; 
E.  Any public or private utility laying, repairing, replacing or enlarging an underground pipe or facility for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more; 
F.  Ingress or egress of property using areas which are not constructed as driveways or roadways when such activities will disturb existing vegetation, site stabilization, and/or erosion control measures; 
G.  Activities which may be unrelated to actual building construction such as, but not limited to, land disturbing activity prior to excavation for foundation work, landscaping, auxiliary buildings, garages, patios or decks, installation of driveways, parking areas and sidewalks, extensive earth work on sites not directly related to structural concerns, development of ponds and channelized water courses, commercial parks and landing strips or airport runways. 
H.  Land disturbing that disturbs more than one hundred (100) lineal feet of road ditch, grass waterway, or other land area where surface drainage flows in a defined open channel; including the placement, repair, or removal of any underground pipe, utility, or other facility within the cross-section of the channel. 
I.  Any new public or private road or access drive longer than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet. 
J.  Land disturbing activity that disturbs less than four thousand (4,000) square feet of land, including the installation of access drives, that the city determines to have a high risk of soil erosion or water pollution, or that may significantly impact a lake, stream, or wetland area. 
(Ord. 259, § 1, 6-20-2006; Ord. 2002-51 § 2, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-3) 
15.28.035 - Exemptions and clarifications. 
    The following activities are exempt from this chapter: 
A.  Any activity directly related to the planting, growing and harvesting of agricultural crops. 
B.  One-family and two-family dwelling units regulated under the Wisconsin Uniform Dwelling Code. Land-disturbing activities in excess of one acre, or not associated with the constriction of a dwelling, are not exempt from this chapter. 
C.  Projects specifically exempted from this chapter under state and federal statute. It is the responsibility of the landowner to demonstrate such exemption with documentation acceptable to the city engineer. 
D.  Projects subject to an approved shore land erosion control permit under Chapter 11, Wisconsin Statutes. 
E.  Agricultural development not subject to Section 15.30.030 A.6. 
F.  Municipal or county highway projects not exempted under subsection C., above, are exempt from Section 15.30.070 C.3. where all of the following conditions are met: 
1.  The purpose of the project is only to meet current state or federal design or safety guidelines; 
2.  All activity takes place within the existing right-of-way; 
3.  All other requirements of Chapter 15 are met; and 
4.  The project does not include the addition of new driving lanes. 
(Ord. 259, § 2, 6-20-2006) 
15.28.040 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Administering authority" means the city employee, or department(s), agent, or designee empowered to administer this chapter. 
    "Affected" means that a regulated activity has significantly: 
a.  Caused negative impacts on water quality or the use or maintenance of land or business; or 
b.  Endangered health, safety, or general welfare. 
    "Agricultural land use" means use of land for planting, growing, cultivating and harvesting of crops for human or livestock consumption and pasturing or yarding of livestock. 
    "Applicant" means any person who applies for a permit to undertake activities governed by this chapter. 
    "Average annual rainfall" means measured precipitation in Madison, Wisconsin, between March 12 and December 2, 1981. 
    "Bank erosion" means the removal of soil or rock fragments along the banks or bed of a stream channel resulting from high flow after rain events. 
    "Best management practices" means a practice, technique, or measure that is an effective, practical means of preventing or reducing soil erosion or water pollution, or both, from runoff both during and after land development activities. These can include structural, vegetative, or operational practices. 
    "Board of appeals" means the board of zoning appeals for the city. 
    "Business day" means a day which the city's offices are routinely and customarily open for business. 
    "Chapter" means Chapter 15.28 of the Sun Prairie Code of Ordinances. 
    "City" means the incorporated city of Sun Prairie, Wisconsin and all lands within the boundaries thereof. 
    "Cold water community" means surface waters capable of supporting a community of cold water fish and other aquatic life, or serving as a spawning area for cold water fish species (NR 102.04(3)(a) Wisconsin Administrative Code). 
    "Commercial land use" means use of land for the wholesale or retail sale of goods or services. 
    "Common plan of development or sale" means all lands included within the boundary of a certified survey or subdivision plan created for the purpose of development or sale of property where multiple separate and distinct land developing activity may take place at different times and on different schedules. 
    "Connected imperviousness" means an impervious surface that is directly connected to a separate storm sewer or water of the state via an impervious flow path. 
    "Construction period" means the span of time from the initial groundbreaking until permanent vegetation is established. 
    "Control measure" means practice or combination of practices to control erosion and attendant pollution. 
    "Control plan" means the written description of the number, locations, sizes, and other pertinent information of control measures designed to meet the requirements of this chapter submitted by the applicant for review and approval by the city. 
    "Design rainfall event" means discrete rainstorm characterized by a specific duration, rainfall intensity, return frequency, and, total depth of rainfall. 
    "Effective infiltration area" means the area of the infiltration system that is used to infiltrate runoff and does not include the area used for site access, berms or pretreatment. 
    "Erosion" means the detachment and movement of soil, sediment or rock fragments by water, wind, ice or gravity. 
    "Existing development" means buildings and other structures and impervious area existing prior to August 22, 2001. 
    "Gross aggregate area" means the total area, in acres, of all land located within the property boundary containing the land development activity. 
    "Irrevocable letter of credit" means an agreement with a bank or other institution to pay money or extend credit to honor the term of the permit with the city. 
    "Impervious surface" means a surface that releases the rainfall as surface runoff during a large portion of the design rainfall event. Rooftops, sidewalks, gravel and pavement parking lots, and street surfaces are examples of impervious surfaces. 
    "Industrial land use" means exterior storage areas, loading and unloading areas, equipment washing areas or other area or surface directly associated with an industrial process, or a land use activity covered under the Wisconsin Pollutant Discharge Elimination System. 
    "Infiltration" for the purpose of this chapter, refers to any precipitation that does not leave the site as surface runoff. 
    "Karst feature" means an area or surficial geologic feature subject to bedrock dissolution so that it is likely to provide a conduit to groundwater, and may include caves, enlarged fractures, mine features, exposed bedrock surfaces, sinkholes, springs, seeps or swallets. 
    "Land development activity" means any activity which changes the volume or peak flow discharge rate of rainfall runoff from the land surface, or means the construction of buildings; roads; pavement or gravel parking lots and/or storage areas; and similar facilities, excluding agricultural land use. 
    "Land disturbing construction activity" means any man-made change of the land surface including removing vegetative cover, excavating, filling, and grading, but not including agricultural land uses. 
    "Landowner" means any person holding title to or having an interest in land. 
    "Land user" means any person operating, leasing, renting or having made other arrangements with the landowner by which the landowner authorizes use of his or her land. 
    "Major project" means land-disturbing activities covering an area twenty thousand (20,000) square feet or larger, or an area four thousand (4,000) square feet or larger with any slopes of twelve percent (12%) or steeper, or an area draining directly into any sensitive area not including construction or modification of a one or two family home or multifamily dwellings of four units or fewer. 
    "Manuals of practice" means the Wisconsin Construction Site Best Management Practice Handbook and Wisconsin Stormwater Manual of Practice published by the Department of Natural Resources. 
    "Maximum extent practicable (MEP)" means a level of implementing best management practices in order to achieve a performance standard specified in this chapter which takes into account the best available technology, cost effectiveness and other competing issues such as human safety and welfare, endangered and threatened resources, historic properties and geographic features. MEP allows flexibility in the way to meet standards and may vary based on the performance standard and site conditions. 
    "Minor project" means land-disturbing activities covering an area less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet, or an area less than four thousand (4,000) square feet with any slopes of twelve percent (12%) or steeper, or for construction or modification of a one or two family home or multifamily dwellings of four units or fewer. 
    "Nonstructural measure" means a practice, technique, or measure to reduce the volume, peak flow rate, or pollutants in stormwater that does not require the design or installation of fixed stormwater management facilities. 
    "Off-site" means located outside the property boundary described in the permit application for land development activity. 
    "On-site" means located within the property boundary described in the permit application for the land development activity. 
    "Permit" means written authorization made by the building inspection or engineering department to the applicant to conduct building construction, land disturbing, or land development activities. 
    "Permit administration fee" means a sum of money paid to the building inspection or engineering department by the permit applicant for the purpose of recouping the city-related expenses incurred by the authority city in administering the permit. 
    "Person" means any individual, corporation, partnership, limited liability company, association, trust or other entity. 
    "Post-development condition" means the extent and distribution of land cover types anticipated to occur under conditions of full development that will influence rainfall runoff and infiltration. 
    "Principal responsible party" means an individual person assigned by property owner to be responsible for installing and maintaining erosion control measures. 
    "Runoff" means the rainfall, snowmelt or irrigation water flowing over the ground surface. 
    "Sensitive area" means lakes, ponds, perennially flowing and intermittent streams or wetlands, environmental corridors mapped by the city, and any lands within the Token Creek Watershed. 
    "Site" means the entire area included in the legal description of the land on which the land disturbing or land development activity is proposed in the permit application. 
    "Soil classification" means classification of soils as designated by the soil survey of Dane County, Wisconsin by the United States Department of Agriculture Soil Conservation Service. 
    "Soil loss rate" means the rate, measured in tons per acre per year, at which soil movement occurs as a result of sheet and rill erosion and does not apply to ditches or areas of concentrated flows. The soil loss rate is calculated using the universal soil loss equation. 
    "Stop work order" means an order issued by the engineering or building inspection departments which requires that all construction activity on the site be stopped. 
    "Stormwater drainage system" means and includes channels, swales, pipes, culverts, street gutters, ditches, detention basins, retention basins, infiltration devices and any facilities for conveying, storing, or managing runoff from a site. 
    "WPDES stormwater permit" means the permit issued by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources in accordance with State of Wisconsin Administrative Code, Sections NR 216 and Comm. 50.115, and any other applicable agency regulations, as such regulations may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. 259, § 3, 6-20-2006; Ord. 2002-51 § 3, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-4) 
15.28.050 - Design standards and specifications for erosion control measures. 
A.  The applicant for a permit may employ structural or nonstructural measures necessary to achieve all applicable standards set out in this chapter. However, these measures will be evaluated to determine that they follow currently accepted design criteria and engineering standards. 
B.  The following general principles shall be used when evaluating control plans and granting permits under this chapter: 
1.  Activities on the site shall be conducted in a logical sequence to cause the smallest area of land shall be exposed for the shortest period at any given time during development. 
2.  The rough grading of the lot shall include backfilling the foundation and walls and all excess earth shall be hauled off the lot unless stockpiled and covered to prevent erosion by wind or water. 
3.  Accommodation of any increased runoff caused by changed soil and surface conditions during and after development. 
4.  Runoff from all areas upslope of the site shall be diverted around disturbed areas. Diverted runoff shall be conveyed in a manner that will not erode the receiving channels. 
5.  All roof drainage shall discharge to vegetated, mulched or other stable pervious surface. 
6.  All temporary roadways and parking areas shall be constructed with minimal cuts and on relatively flat grades. All disturbed side slopes shall be stabilized with mulching and seeding or equivalent control measures within seven days of construction of the cuts. 
7.  Permanent final plantings or structures shall be installed prior to final acceptance of public improvements or issuance of occupancy permits. 
8.  The plan of development shall relate to the topography and soils of the site so that the lowest potential for erosion is created. 
9.  Natural plant covering shall be retained and protected and shall be deemed a dominating factor in developing the site and temporary vegetation, mulching or other cover shall be used to protect the area exposed during the land-disturbing activity. 
10.  All detention and retention basins that serve multiple phases or a single drainage area shall first be constructed to act as a settling basin with conversion to the permanent basin upon completion of the development. 
11.  Any soil or dirt piles which will be in existence for more than ten (10) days may not be located within twenty-five (25) feet of a roadway or drainage channel and shall be stabilized by mulching, vegetative cover, tarps or other means. 
12.  The developer for all plats or phases thereof shall submit for approval a "post-improvement erosion control plan" that details structural measures and responsibility for erosion control after the initial improvements have been made. The post-improvement erosion control plan shall propose erosion control measures to protect all improvements and include a revegetation schedule for denuded areas that takes into account the time of year. This plan may accompany the initial plan or be submitted separately, but must be approved prior to the city's acceptance of the plat improvements. 
13.  April 30th through November 30th. Prior to acceptance of site improvements or issuance of occupancy permits, the developer's representative shall visit the site with the city's representative to review the final site stabilization measures. The city's representative must approve the final site stabilization measures prior to acceptance of public utilities or issuance of occupancy permits. 
14.  Winter Construction. As soon as weather conditions permit the completion of final site stabilization measures, but prior to acceptance of site improvements or issuance of occupancy permits, the developer's representative shall visit the site with the city's representative to review the final site stabilization measures. The city's representative must approve the final site stabilization measures prior to acceptance of public utilities or issuance of occupancy permits. 
C.  The following erosion control measures shall be required on sites with public improvements: 
1.  The landowner or his/her representative is required to make erosion control inspections at the end of each week and within twenty-four (24) hours after a precipitation event of 0.5 inches or greater. Inspection reports shall be prepared and filed as required and submitted to the city's representative within four business days of the required inspection. This shall not relieve the landowner or his/her representative of any responsibilities under NR 216 or Comm. 50.115, Wisconsin Administrative Code, and any other applicable agency regulations, as such regulations may hereafter be amended. 
2.  Disturbed areas more than twenty (20) feet behind the curb and gutter shall be restored when rough grading is completed. If the area will not be seeded and mulched within forty-eight (48) hours of rough grading, silt fence or erosion mat shall be installed parallel to the street twenty (20) feet the curb and gutter until final landscaping is completed. 
3.  Install minimum six foot to seven foot wide erosion mat along the back of curb after topsoil has been placed in the terrace if this area will not be seeded and mulched within forty-eight (48) hours of placing topsoil. 
4.  Silt fence or erosion mat shall be installed along the contours at one hundred (100) foot intervals down the slope on disturbed slopes steeper than five percent and more than one hundred (100) long that sheet flow to the roadway. 
5.  Place heavy mulch twenty (20) feet wide to prevent sediment from leaving the lots. Mulch shall be at least twenty (20) mm thick in accordance with latest edition of the state of Wisconsin Standard Specifications for Highway and Structure Construction. Seed and double mulch all terraces. 
6.  Clean sediment from curb and gutter on a daily basis, more often if needed after a rain event, and prior to the project acceptance. 
7.  Place temporary seed if disturbed areas will not be restored immediately after rough grading. Temporary seed shall be placed in accordance with Section 630 of the Wisconsin Standard Specifications for Highway and Structure Construction. 
8.  Catch-all inlet protection devices, or equal as determined by the city engineer, shall be installed in all storm sewer catch basins and maintained until the final surface layer of asphalt has been placed in new developments. The devices shall also be placed and maintained in additional locations, such as catch basins down gradient of the development, as determined by the city engineer. 
D.  Erosion control measures shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the Wisconsin Construction Site Best Management Practice Handbook and the city standard specifications for public works improvements. 
E.  Riprap design for culvert, pond, and storm sewer outfalls shall be in accordance with the state of Wisconsin Department of Transportation Facilities Development Manual Drainage Chapter, Erosion and Water Pollution Control Section. Riprap construction shall be in accordance with the Wisconsin Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Highway and Structure Construction, latest edition. 
F.  Site Dewatering. Water pumped from the site shall be free of visible sediments and shall be discharged to drainage facilities so as not to cause erosion at the discharge point or in the receiving drainage facility. 
G.  Waste and Material Disposal. All waste and unused building materials shall be disposed of frequently and in licensed solid waste or wastewater facilities. No garbage, debris, cleaning wastes, toxic materials or hazardous materials shall be buried on site, dumped on the land surface or in detention basins, or discharged or otherwise allowed to be carried by runoff into a receiving channel or storm sewer system. 
H.  Tracking. Each site shall provide the following to prevent sediment from being tracked onto public or private roadways: 
1.  Each site shall have graveled access drives and parking areas of sufficient width, length and wearing surface. 
2.  All unpaved roads serving more than five vehicles per day shall be graveled. 
3.  Vehicle and equipment wash water shall be discharged to an infiltration area, detention basin or equivalent control measure. 
4.  Any sediment reaching a public or private road shall be removed by sweeping before the end of each work day. 
I.  Drain Inlet Protection. All storm drain inlets on the site shall be protected by a stone weeper placed tightly around the inlet or sand bags piled around the inlet a minimum of one foot above the inlet. 
J.  Minimum Slope Stabilization Requirements. Stabilization practices beyond the standard seeding and mulching are often needed to control erosion on exposed slopes. As the length and steepness of the slope increases, so do the forces of soil erosion and the level of protection needed. Use the chart below to determine the stabilization requirements for any given slope where runoff is in sheet flow. 
MINIMUM SLOPE STABILIZATION REQUIREMENTS*

Slope lengths shown above refer to the area of exposed soil and assumes no runoff from upslope area. If upslope runoff exists, use the next more stringent stabilization measure in the chart, or temporarily divert the runoff around exposed areas.

(Ord. 259, § 4, 6-20-2006; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-5) 
15.28.060 - Maintenance of control measures. 
    All control measures necessary to meet the requirements of this chapter shall be maintained: 
A.  By the applicant or subsequent landowner during both the period of land disturbance and land development of the site and the subsequent occupation of the site; 
B.  At the frequency and in the manner described in the manuals of practice. 
(Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-6) 
15.28.070 - Land-disturbing activities subject to construction site erosion control. 
A.  General Requirement. Any landowner or land user who undertakes, commences or performs land-disturbing activities; or who permits another person to do the same, on land is subject to this section. 
B.  Land-disturbing activities subject to erosion and sediment control: 
1.  Those requiring a subdivision plat approval or the construction of housing or commercial, industrial or institutional buildings on lots of approved subdivision plats; 
2.  Those requiring a certified survey approval or the construction of housing or commercial, industrial or institutional buildings on lots of approved certified surveys; 
3.  Those involving grading, removal of protective ground cover or vegetation, excavation land filling or other land disturbing activity affecting a surface area of four thousand (4,000) square feet or more, or activities on a slope steeper than twelve percent (12%); 
4.  Those involving excavation or filling or a combination of excavation and filling affecting four hundred (400) cubic yards or more of dirt, sand or other excavation and/or fill material; 
5.  Those involving public street, highway, road or bridge, building, parking lot, driveway or walkway construction, enlargement, relocation or reconstruction or substantial reconstruction; 
6.  Ingress or egress of property using areas which are not constructed as driveways or roadways when such activities will disturb existing vegetation, site stabilization, and/or erosion control measures; 
7.  Activities such as, but not limited to, land-disturbing activity prior to excavation for foundation work, landscaping, auxiliary buildings, garages, patios or decks, pools, installation of driveways, parking areas and sidewalks, extensive earth work on sites not directly related to structural concerns, developments of ponds and channelized water courses, commercial parks and landing strips or airport runways; 
8.  The area is adjacent to or draining directly to a sensitive area. 
9.  Land disturbing activity that disturbs more than one hundred (100) lineal feet of road ditch, grass waterway, or other land area where surface drainage flows in a defined open channel; including the placement, repair, or removal of any underground pipe, utility, or other facility within the cross-section of the channel. 
10.  Any new public or private road or access drive longer than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet. 
11.  Land disturbing activity that disturbs less than four thousand (4,000) square feet of land, including the installation of access drives, that the city determines to have a high risk of soil erosion or water pollution, or that may significantly impact a lake, stream, or wetland area. 
C.  Permitting or Causing Erosion Prohibited. In addition to the permit requirements set forth in this chapter, no person shall cause or permit erosion or the tracking or dropping of dirt or sediment deposits upon adjacent lands, public streets or bodies of water from any land, whether or not otherwise subject to this chapter. 
(Ord. 2002-51 § 4, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-7) 
15.28.080 - Performance standards for erosion control measures. 
A.  Allowable Soil Loss Standard. Plans will not be approved nor permits issued unless the proposed design, suggested location and phased implementation of effective, practicable erosion control measures shall prevent gully and bank erosion and: 
1.  Permissible Soil Loss. Limit total off-site annual aggregate soil loss resulting from sheet and rill erosion of exposed areas, to an annual, cumulative rate not to exceed seven and one-half tons per acre per year. 
2.  Erosion control measures for plan approval need not attempt to regulate soil transportation within the boundaries of the applicant's site. 
3.  Discharges from new construction sites must have a stable outlet capable of carrying designed flow as required in Section 15.30.070 C.4., at a nonerosive velocity. Outlet design must consider flow capacity and flow duration. This requirement applies to both the site outlet and the ultimate outlet to stormwater conveyance or water body. 
B.  Calculation Method. Plan compliance under subsection A of this section, shall be determined using the soil conservation service universal soil loss equation (USLE), which includes the following considerations, season of year, site characteristics, soil erodibility and slope. Computer version of USLE for Dane County (Excel or QuatroPro versions) and sample hand calculations are available from Dane County land conservation (www.codane.wi.us). Another commonly accepted soil erosion technology approved by the city engineer and the Dane County conservationist, that considers season of year, site characteristics, soil erodibility and slope, may be considered for use. 
C.  Sites Required to Provide Calculations. Plan compliance shall include the determination of soil loss rates as calculated by accepted soil erosion control methodology for: 
1.  Sites twenty thousand (20,000) square feet or larger, excluding one-family and two-family homes and multifamily dwellings of four units or fewer; 
2.  Sites four thousand (4,000) square feet or larger with any slopes twelve percent (12%) or steeper; and 
3.  All major project sites adjacent to or draining directly into any sensitive area, not including construction or modification of a one-family or two-family home or multifamily dwelling of four units or fewer. 
D.  Internally Drained Site. For internally drained sites, erosion control measures for plan approval need not attempt to regulate soil transportation within the limits of the disturbed area. 
(Ord. 259, § 5, 6-20-2006; Ord. 2002-51 § 5, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-8) 
15.28.090 - Permit application, control plan and permit issuance. 
A.  General. Unless specifically excluded by this chapter, no owner, occupant or user may undertake an activity subject to this chapter without receiving a permit. Each owner, occupant or user desiring to undertake a regulated activity subject to this chapter shall submit an application for a permit together with the appropriate fee. In addition: 
1.  The submittal must be signed by the landowner or included a notarize statement signed by the landowner authorizing the applicant to act as the landowner's agent and bind the landowner to the terms of this ordinance. 
2.  If a landowner appoints an agent to submit an application, the landowner shall be bound by all the requirements of this ordinance and the terms of any permit issued to the agent. 
3.  Submittal for a permit under this ordinance shall constitute permission by the applicant and landowner for the inspecting officer of the city to enter upon the property and inspect the property prior to construction, inspect the project under construction, and inspect the project upon completion of the project to confirm compliance with the requirements of the approved plan. 
B.  Control Plan Required. 
1.  Unless specifically exempted by this chapter, applicants for plats or other developments with public improvements shall submit four copies of a control plan to control erosion and sedimentation which would result from the proposed activity. The materials shall be submitted to the city official designated to review such plans under this chapter. 
2.  For land-disturbing activities covering an area twenty thousand (20,000) square feet or larger, or an area four thousand (4,000) square feet or larger with any slopes of twelve percent (12%) or steeper, or an area draining directly into any sensitive area, applicants shall submit the following along with the permit application: 
a.  The control plan including the information described below; 
b.  Soil loss rate calculations for the construction period per the USLE. 
3.  Sites not requiring a control plan and calculations under subsection B.2. of this section, and one-family and two-family dwellings or multifamily dwellings of four units or fewer shall submit one copy of the erosion control checklist and plan with the application. 
C.  Content of the Control Plan. The site plan for all land-disturbing activities covering an area twenty thousand (20,000) square feet or larger, or an area four thousand (4,000) square feet or larger with any slopes of twelve percent (12%) or steeper shall contain the following control plan information: 
1.  Existing Site Map. A map of existing site conditions on a scale of at least one inch equals fifty (50) feet but no more than one inch equals twenty (20) feet including: 
a.  Site boundaries, property line, lot dimensions and adjacent lands which accurately identity site location; 
b.  Existing site topography at a contour interval not to exceed two feet and extending onto adjacent contiguous properties a minimum of fifty (50) feet or as necessary to show land features and existing drainage patterns; 
c.  All natural and artificial water features including, but not limited to, lakes, streams (including intermittent streams), wetlands as defined by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources and/or the Army Corps of Engineers, environmental corridors as shown on the environmental corridor map for the city prepared by the Dane County regional planning commission, natural and historic resource protection overlay zoning districts as shown on the city zoning map, channels, ditches and other watercourses on the site and those off the site that may be affected by the land disturbing or land development activity; and areas of natural woodland or prairie. 
d.  One hundred-year floodplains, flood fringes and floodways and delineated wetland boundaries. A certified flood zone determination and/or wetland delineation may be required at the applicant's expense. 
e.  Existing drainage patterns; 
f.  Location map and type of predominant soils as determined in the soil survey of Dane County, Wisconsin, by the United States Department of Agriculture Soil Conservation Service, and soil boring or test pit information if available; 
g.  Existing vegetative cover; 
h.  Location and dimensions of existing stormwater drainage systems upstream and downstream to the point of ultimate disposal; 
i.  Locations and dimensions of existing utilities, structures, roads, highways and paving. 
2.  Plan of Final Site Conditions. A plan of final site conditions on the same scale as the existing site map including: 
a.  Site boundaries, property lines, lot dimensions and adjacent lands which accurately identify site location; 
b.  Existing and proposed site topography at a contour interval not to exceed two feet and extending onto adjacent contiguous properties a minimum of fifty (50) feet or as necessary to show land features and existing drainage patterns; 
c.  All natural and artificial water features including, but not limited to, lakes, streams (including intermittent streams), wetlands as defined by the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources and/or the Army Corps of Engineers, environmental corridors as shown on the environmental corridor map for the city prepared by the Dane County regional planning commission, natural and historic resource protection overlay zoning districts as shown on the city zoning map, channels, ditches and other watercourses on the site and those off the site that may be affected by the land disturbing or land development activity; and areas of natural woodland or prairie. 
d.  One hundred-year floodplains, flood fringes and floodways and delineated wetland boundaries. A certified flood zone determination and/or wetland delineation may be required at the applicant's expense. 
e.  Proposed drainage patterns, including watershed size for each drainage area, design discharges for ditches and structural measures, and runoff velocities. 
f.  Cross sections of and profiles of channels, swales, and road ditches. 
g.  Culvert sizes. 
h.  Limits of impervious surfaces in square feet, including buildings include all public and private roads, interior roads, driveways, parking lots, and indicate type of paving and surfacing material. 
i.  Makeup of surface soil (upper six inches) on areas not covered by buildings, structures, or pavement; 
j.  Kind of cover on areas not covered by buildings, structures, or pavement; 
k.  Seeding mixtures and rates, lime and fertilizer application rates, and kind and quantity of mulching for both temporary and permanent vegetative control measures; 
l.  Locations and dimensions of proposed and remaining portions of existing stormwater drainage systems and stormwater management control measures; 
m.  Locations and dimensions of proposed and remaining utilities, structures, roads, highways and paving; 
n.  Calculations of soil loss as calculated using the USLE; 
o.  Prior to acceptance of public improvements or issuance of an occupancy permit, a walk-through of the site shall be conducted to review the final erosion control measures and stabilization measures for the site (measures shall be in place at the time of the walk-through). The walk-through shall be attended by a representative of the city engineering or building department and the owner/developer. 
3.  Site Construction Plan. A site construction plan including: 
a.  Property lines, lot dimensions, and limits of disturbed area; 
b.  Locations and dimensions of all soil stockpiles; 
c.  Locations and dimensions of all construction site erosion control measures. Show phasing of measures where applicable, necessary to meet the requirements of this chapter; 
d.  Schedule of anticipated starting and completion date of each land-disturbing or land developing activity including the installation of construction site erosion control measures needed to meet the requirements of this chapter; and 
e.  Provisions for maintenance of the construction site erosion control measures during construction. 
4.  Erosion Control Methods. A description of the methods to be employed to prevent erosion and sedimentation including the following: 
a.  A detailed land disturbance schedule including time schedules for stabilization of ditches and slopes; 
b.  Provision for sequential steps mitigating erosive effect of land disturbing activities to be followed in appropriate order and in a manner consistent with accepted erosion control methodology suitable to proposed sites and amenable to prompt revegetation, including runoff calculations as appropriate; 
c.  Provisions to prevent mud-tracking off-site onto public thoroughfares during the construction period; 
d.  Provisions to disconnect impervious surfaces, where feasible; 
e.  Provisions to prevent sediment delivery to, and accumulation in, any proposed or existing stormwater conveyance systems; 
f.  Existing or proposed elevations (referenced to the National Geodetic Vertical Datum of 1929) and existing and proposed contours in the area, where deemed necessary; 
g.  Any other information necessary to reasonably determine the location, nature and condition of any physical or environmental features of the site. 
5.  Copies of permits or permit applications or approvals required by any government entity. 
D.  Content of the Erosion Control Checklist Plan. The erosion control checklist plan (the "checklist plan") shall serve as the control plan for lots of less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet and one-family and two-family dwellings or multifamily dwellings of four or fewer units. On lots of less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet and one-family and two-family dwellings, the applicant shall agree to undertake all control measures required by the checklist plan, which are as follows: 
1.  Stripping of vegetation, grading, excavation, or other land-disturbing activities shall be done in a manner which will minimize soil erosion. If possible, construction should be scheduled for times of year when erosion hazards are minimal. 
2.  Only those areas approved for the placement of physical improvements may be cleared of top-soil, trees, and other natural features. Existing stable vegetation shall be retained and protected on all other areas until the final ground cover is placed. 
3.  Only the site referenced on the checklist form shall be included in the construction site activities. Ingress, egress and storage of materials shall take place on this site only. Use of adjacent properties shall constitute a violation of this chapter if a control plan including those properties has not been approved. 
4.  Temporary stabilization and control measures (seeding, mulching, tarping, erosion matting, etc.) are required for protection of exposed areas which will remain unworked for a period in excess of two weeks during construction or other land-disturbing activities. 
5.  Proposed drainage facilities shall be designed to accommodate increased runoff resulting from developments or disturbances to the soil and surface conditions, during and after development or disturbance without causing erosion of the drainage facility. Runoff shall be conveyed to the nearest public drainage facility. 
6.  Water runoff shall be managed in a manner that meets the minimum requirements of the City's Stormwater Management Ordinance. 
7.  Sediment shall be retained onsite. Vehicles shall riot track or direct debris onto adjacent roadways and sediment shall not be carried off the site by surface runoff. 
8.  Any temporary or permanent diversions, sediment basins, or other such erosion and runoff control measures as required, shall be installed prior to any onsite grading or land disturbances except in the areas subject to land disturbance. 
9.  Surplus excavation materials shall be removed from the site immediately after rough grading. The disposal site for the surplus excavation is also subject to the requirements of this chapter if within the city limits. 
E.  Review of Applications. The city shall not begin to review any application submitted under this chapter, until receipt of the application, the control plan (if required), the soil loss calculations (if required) and the application fee (if required). 
1.  Minor Projects. Within seven days of receiving the required information and fee, the building inspector or its designee shall review the information and notify the applicant whether the application is approved, disapproved, approved with modifications, or whether additional information is required. 
2.  Major Projects, Less Than Two Acres. Within twenty (20) days of receiving the required information and fee, the city engineer or its designee shall review the information and notify the applicant in writing whether the application is approved, disapproved, approved with modifications, or whether additional information is required. 
3.  Other Major Projects, Greater Than Two Acres. Within forty-five (45) days of receiving the required information and fee, the city engineer or its designee shall review the information and notify the applicant in writing whether the application is approved, disapproved, approved with modifications, or whether additional information is required. 
4.  Additional Information Requests. For all applications, the reviewing city official may, if deemed appropriate, request comments from other city departments and other governmental agencies. 
5.  Approval, Disapproval, or Supplemental Information Requests. If the requirements of this chapter have been met, the reviewing official shall approve the application, inform the applicant and issue a permit. If the conditions are not met, the reviewing official shall inform the applicant in writing and may either disapprove the permit application or either require needed information to address issues raised by the application. If the applicant promptly submits such information, the reviewing official shall, within ten (10) days for minor projects and within thirty (30) days for major projects of the receipt of such information, determine whether the application and supporting materials now meet the requirements of this chapter. If the application is disapproved, the reviewing official shall inform the applicant in writing of the reasons for the disapproval. 
6.  Permit Conditions. 
a.  Duration. Permits shall be valid a period of one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of issuance, unless otherwise noted. The reviewing official may extend the duration beyond one hundred eighty (180) days on larger projects where the completion is expected to extend beyond this period. The reviewing official may grant an extension on approvals upon written request. Extensions may require additional control measures as a condition of approval if necessary to meet the requirements of this chapter. 
b.  Security. As a condition of approval and issuance of the permit, the city may require the applicant to deposit a surety bond or irrevocable letter of credit, escrow funds, or post other security acceptable to the city to guarantee good faith execution of the approved control plan and any permit conditions. Without limiting the foregoing and subject to applicable law, the city may require such security if the applicant undertakes winter construction, to ensure that any necessary cleanup or landscaping measures shall be implemented promptly upon the conclusion of the freezing weather that prevents immediate implementation. 
c.  Other Permit Conditions. All permits shall require the permittee to: 
i.  Notify the city official who reviewed and issued the permit five work days prior to commencing any land disturbing activity; 
ii.  Notify such reviewing official of the completion of any control measures within ten (10) days of completion of their installation; 
iii.  Obtain written permission from the city prior to modifying the control plan; 
iv.  Maintain all road drainage systems, stormwater drainage systems, control measures and other facilities identified in the control plan; 
v.  Repair any damage to adjoining surfaces and drainage ways resulting from land developing or disturbing activities; 
vi.  Inspect the construction control measures after each rain of one-half inch or more and at least once each week and make needed repairs. Inspection reports shall be submitted to the city representative within four business days of the inspection; 
vii.  Pay any proportional share of the cost of off-site drainageway, stream channel or other modifications necessitated by the land development or land disturbing activity; 
viii.  Allow the inspecting official, as defined below, to enter the site for the purpose of inspecting compliance with the control plan or for performing any work necessary to bring the site into compliance with the control plan; 
ix.  A copy of the approved permit and erosion control plan shall be kept on the project site, in a place readily accessible to contractors, engineers, local approval authority inspection staff and other authorized personnel. 
x.  Make all reasonable corrections or repairs to control measures ordered by the inspecting official so as to meet the requirements of this chapter. 
d.  Release of Security. The city shall release the surety bond or return the irrevocable letter of credit, after verifying the completion of the control plan requirements and satisfaction of the permit conditions. 
e.  Permit Transfers. Shall be required to follow the following procedures: 
i.  Whenever a permittee and/or landowner act to transfer an interest in property subject to an approved plan prior to completion of the proposed steps to attain soil stabilization, the permittee must secure approval from the city engineer. 
ii.  When a permittee and/or landowner transfers ownership, possession, or control of real estate subject to an uncompleted erosion control plan, the successor in interest to any portion of the real estate shall be responsible to control soil erosion and runoff and shall comply with the minimum standards provided in this ordinance. 
iii.  When ownership, possession, or control of property subject to an uncompleted erosion control plan is transferred, the former owner (seller) shall notify the new owner (buyer) as to the current status of compliance with notice to the authority, and provide the new owner (buyer) with a copy of the erosion control plan. 
iv.  Transfers of interest in real estate subject to an approved, uncompleted plan may be conducted consistent with this ordinance under any of the following arrangements; 
(a)  The transferee shall file a new, approved erosion control plan with the city engineer. 
(b)  The transferee shall obtain an approved assignment from the city engineer as subpermittee to complete that portion of the approved plan regulating soil erosion and runoff on the transferee's property. 
v.  If deemed necessary by the city engineer, the permittee shall provide the city with a duly completed and executed continuing approved means of surety in an amount sufficient to complete the work in the approved plan. 
f.  Plan or Permit Amendments. Any proposed modifications to the approved plans, construction schedules, or alterations to accepted sequencing of land disturbing site activities shall be approved by the city engineer in consultation with the city's plan review agency, prior to implementation of said changes. 
(Ord. 407 § 1, 8-18-2009; Ord. 259, §§ 6, 7, 6-20-2006; Ord. 2002-51 § 6, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-9) 
15.28.100 - Inspection. 
A.  The city engineer and/or the city building inspector, or his/her authorized designees (the "inspecting official") shall inspect construction sites periodically to ensure compliance with the approved control plan as follows: 
1.  For major projects, such inspection shall be performed by the city engineer, or the authorized designee; and 
2.  For minor projects, such inspections shall be performed by the city building inspector, or the authorized designee. 
B.  To conduct such inspections, to determine if any activities subject to this chapter are being carried out without a permit, or contrary to the terms of a previously approved control plan, the inspecting official, shall have the authority to enter the land pursuant to the provisions of Sections 66.122 and 123, Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-10) 
15.28.110 - Enforcement. 
    The inspecting official shall cause the enforcement of this chapter. 
A.  The inspecting official may post a stop-work order if: 
1.  Any activity subject to this chapter is being undertaken without a permit; or 
2.  The control plan is not being implemented in a good faith manner; or 
3.  Any permit holder fails to comply with any applicable erosion control requirement set forth in any applicable permit or regulations of the DNR or the Wisconsin Department of Commerce, relating to the site; or 
4.  If the conditions of the permit are not being met. 
B.  If the permittee does not cease the activity or comply with the control plan or permit conditions within twenty-four (24) hours, the inspecting official may revoke the permit. If the permit is revoked, all construction and building activity on the property shall terminate immediately. 
C.  If the landowner or land user where no permit has been issued, or where a permit has been revoked, does not cease the activity within twenty-four (24) hours, the public works committee and/or inspecting official may request the city attorney to obtain a stop work order. 
D.  The inspecting official, the plan commission or the board of appeals, acting upon a properly-presented appeal, may retract the stop-work order or the permit revocation. 
E.  Seventy-two (72) hours after posting a stop-work order, the inspecting official may issue, to the permittee or landowner or land user, a notice of the city's intent to perform work necessary to comply with this chapter. Authorized agents of the city may go on the land and commence the work beginning at any time after twenty-four (24) hours after issuing the notice of intent. The cost of the work performed by the city plus interest at a rate equal to five percent over the city's borrowing rate then in effect, shall be billed to the permittee or the landowner. In the event a permittee or landowner fails to pay the amount due, the city clerk shall enter the amount due on the tax rolls and the city shall proceed to collect the unpaid amounts as a special tax against the land. 
F.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject upon conviction to a civil forfeiture, as provided below and shall be liable to pay the costs of prosecution for each violation. Each day a violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
1.  Minor Projects. 
a.  First Offense. A forfeiture of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties; 
b.  Second Offense. A forfeiture of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties; 
c.  Subsequent Offenses. A forfeiture of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties. 
2.  Major Projects. 
a.  First Offense. A forfeiture of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties; 
b.  Second Offense. A forfeiture of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00), nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties; 
c.  Subsequent Offenses. A forfeiture of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), nor more than one thousand seven hundred fifty dollars ($1,750.00), together with the costs of prosecution and any costs incurred by the city in connection with the claims of third parties. 
3.  Other Violations Under this Chapter. Same schedule of forfeitures as for minor projects. 
G.  The city may also obtain an injunction to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2002-51 § 7, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-11) 
15.28.120 - Appeals-Variances. 
A.  Public Works Committee. The public works committee created under Section 2.08.050 of the City Code: 
1.  Shall hear and decide appeals where it is alleged that there is error in any order, decision or determination made by the inspecting official or public works committee in administering this chapter; 
2.  Upon appeal, may authorize variances form the provisions of this chapter which are not contrary to the public interest and where owning to special conditions a literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter will result in unnecessary hardship; and 
3.  Shall use the rules, procedures, duties and powers authorized by statute in hearing and deciding appeals and authorizing variances. 
B.  Who May Appeal. Any applicant, permittee, landowner, land user may appeal any order, decision or determination made by the plan commission or inspecting official in administering this chapter. 
(Ord. 2002-51 § 8, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code § 15-4-12) 
15.28.130 - Fees for permit administration fee for permit applications and erosion control plans. 
    Applicants for permit, erosion control plans or other approvals under this chapter shall pay the permit application fees based on the city's current fee schedule when a plan or application is filed. The common council shall have authority and discretion to make adjustments to the fees. A schedule of the permit administration fees is available from the city engineering department. The permit application fee also includes the cost for city staff's review of the stormwater management plan submittal as well as all inspection of construction activities. Some projects will require both the submittal of an erosion control plan and a stormwater management plan. 
    When considering a project subject only to the requirements of this ordinance, erosion control permit administration fee shall be determined by the criteria listed in Section 15.28.030. 
( Ord. No. 711, § 1, 12-19-2017 ; Ord. 2002-51 § 9, 2002; Ord. 573 § 1 (part), 2001; prior code §§ 15-4-13, 15-4-14) 
Chapter 15.30 - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 
Sections: 

15.30.010 - Title and authority. 
    The chapter shall be known as the "Stormwater Management Ordinance" and is adopted pursuant to Section 62.11(5), Wisconsin Statutes. 
(Ord. 2002-60 § 1, 2002) 
15.30.020 - Findings and purpose. 
A.  Findings. The common council finds as follows: 
1.  Uncontrolled stormwater runoff from land development has significant adverse impacts on water resources and the health, safety, property and general welfare of the community, and can diminish the public enjoyment and use of natural resources. Specifically, stormwater runoff can: 
a.  Carry sediment, nutrients, pathogens, organic matter, heavy metals, toxins and other pollutants to regional lakes, streams and wetlands; 
b.  Diminish the capacity of water resources to support recreational and water supply uses and a natural diversity of plant and animal life; 
c.  Clog existing drainage systems, increasing maintenance problems and costs; 
d.  Cause bank and channel erosion; 
e.  Increase downstream flooding; 
f.  Reduce groundwater recharge, which may diminish stream base flows and lower water levels in regional lakes, ponds and wetlands; 
g.  Contaminate drinking water supplies; 
h.  Increase risk of property damage and personal injury, and; 
i.  Cause damage to agricultural fields and crops. 
2.  That effective sediment and stormwater management depends on proper planning, design, and timely installation of conservation and management practices and their continuing maintenance. 
3.  Recent developments in stormwater management practices suggest a need to incorporate current practices into the city's stormwater management ordinance. 
B.  Purpose. 
1.  It is the purpose of this chapter to set forth the minimum requirements for stormwater management that when incorporated will diminish threats to public health, safety, public and private property and natural resources of the city of Sun Prairie. 
2.  This chapter is intended to regulate stormwater runoff with the intentions of accomplishing the following objectives: 
a.  Promote regional stormwater management by watershed; 
b.  Minimize sedimentation, water pollution from nutrients, heavy metals, chemical and petroleum products and other contaminants, flooding and thermal impacts to the water resources of the city of Sun Prairie; 
c.  Promote infiltration and groundwater recharge; 
d.  Protect functional values of natural watercourses and wetlands; 
e.  Provide a set of performance standards that are consistent with the standards set forth by Dane County; 
f.  Achieve an eighty percent (80%) reduction in sediment load rates to Dane County waters compared to no controls for all new development, a forty percent (40%) reduction in sediment load rates compared to no controls for all redevelopment and street reconstruction, and a twenty percent (20%) reduction in sediment load rates compared to no controls for existing developments; 
g.  Ensure no increase in temperature of stormwater post-construction in order to protect cold-water communities; 
h.  Ensure no increase in the rate of surface water drainage from sites during or after construction; and 
i.  Protect public and private property from damage resulting from stormwater runoff. 
(Ord. 2002-60 § 1, 2002) 
15.30.030 - Applicability of requirement for stormwater management permits. 
A.  Unless otherwise exempted by Section 15.30.040, a stormwater management permit shall be required and all stormwater management provisions of this chapter shall apply, to any of the following activities within the city of Sun Prairie: 
1.  Any development(s) after August 22, 2001, that result(s) in the cumulative addition of twenty thousand (20,000) square feet of impervious surface to the site. 
2.  Any development that requires a subdivision plat. 
3.  Any development that requires a certified survey map (CSM); for property intended for commercial or industrial use. 
4.  Any redevelopment, as defined in Section 15.30.050, shall meet the requirements specified within this chapter. 
5.  Other land development activities, including but not limited to redevelopment or alteration of existing buildings and other structures, that the city determines may significantly increase downstream runoff volumes, flooding, soil erosion, water pollution, or property damage, or significantly impact a stream, creek, wetland area, or body of water. 
6.  Agricultural development that creates new impervious surface area exceeding twenty thousand (20,000) square feet on the site. 
(Ord. 308, § 1, 3-20-2007; Ord. 260, § 1, 6-20-2006; Ord. 2002-60 § 1, 2002) 
15.30.040 - Exemptions and clarifications. 
A.  The following activities are exempt from all requirements of this chapter. 
1.  Any activity directly related to the planting, growing, and harvesting of agricultural crops. 
2.  Reserved. 
B.  The following activities are exempt from the infiltration standards described in Section 15.30.070 C.6.: 
1.  Redevelopment sites. 
2.  New development sites with less than ten percent (10%) connected imperviousness based on complete development of the post construction site, provided the cumulative area of all impervious surface is less than one acre. 
3.  Agricultural facilities and practices. 
4.  Areas where the infiltration rate of the soil is less than 0.6 inches per hour measured at the bottom of the infiltration system where the soil layer is not easily removed or manipulated. 
5.  Parking areas and access roads less than five thousand (5,000) square feet for commercial and industrial development. 
6.  Roads in commercial, industrial and institutional land uses, and arterial roads. 
(Ord. 260, § 2, 6-20-2006; Ord. 2002-60 § 1, 2002) 
15.30.050 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of these regulations, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular, and vice versa for each. The use of the word "shall" in these definitions, and throughout the text of this title, is always mandatory and not merely suggestive. The following definitions shall be applicable in this title: 
    "Administering authority" means the city employee, or departments(s), agent, or designee empowered to administer this chapter. 
    "Affected" means that a regulated activity has significantly: 
a.  caused negative impacts on water quality or the use or maintenance of land or business; or 
b.  endangered health, safety, or general welfare. 
    "Agricultural land use" means use of land for planting, growing, cultivating and harvesting of crops for human or livestock consumption and pasturing or yarding of livestock. 
    "Applicant" means any person who applies for a permit to undertake activities governed by this chapter. 
    "Average annual rainfall" means measured precipitation in Madison, Wisconsin between March 12 and December 2, 1981. 
    "Bank erosion" means the removal of soil or rock fragments along the banks or bed of a stream channel resulting from high flow after rain events. 
    "Best management practices" means a practice, technique, or measure that is an effective, practical means of preventing or reducing soil erosion or water pollution, or both, from runoff both during and after land development activities. These can include structural, vegetative or operational practices. 
    "Business day" means a day which the city's offices are routinely and customarily open for business. 
    "Chapter" means Title 15, Chapter 15.30 of the Sun Prairie Code of Ordinances. 
    "City" means the incorporated city of Sun Prairie, Wisconsin, and all lands within the boundaries thereof. 
    "Cold water community" means surface waters capable of supporting a community of cold-water fish and other aquatic life, or serving as a spawning area for cold water fish species (NR 102.04(3)(a), Wisconsin Administrative Code). 
    "Connected imperviousness" means an impervious surface that is directly connected to a separate storm sewer or water of the state via an impervious flow path. 
    "Effective infiltration area" means the area of the infiltration system that is used to infiltrate runoff and does not include the area used for site access, berms or pretreatment. 
    "Existing development" means buildings and other structures and impervious area existing prior to August 22, 2001. 
    "Fill" means any act by which earth, sand, gravel, rock or any other material is deposited, placed, replaced, pushed, dumped, pulled, transported, or moved to a new location and shall include the resulting conditions. 
    "Financial security instrument" means a surety bond, performance bond, maintenance bond, irrevocable letter of credit, or similar guarantees submitted to the city finance director/city treasurer to assure that requirement of the ordinance are carried out in compliance with the stormwater management plan. 
    "Hydrologic soil group (HSG)" means has the meaning used in the runoff calculation methodology promulgated by the United States Natural Resources Conservation Service Engineering Field Manual for Conservation Practices. 
    "Impervious surface" means a surface that releases the rainfall as surface runoff during a large portion of the design rainfall event. "Rooftops", "sidewalks", "gravel and pavement parking lots", and "street surfaces" are examples of impervious surfaces. 
    "Infiltration" for the purpose of this chapter, refers to any precipitation that does not leave the site as surface runoff. 
    "Infiltration system" means a device or practice such as a basin, trench, rain garden or swale designed specifically to encourage infiltration, but does not include natural infiltration in pervious surfaces such as lawns, redirecting of rooftop downspouts onto lawns or minimal infiltration from practices such as swales or road side channels designed for conveyance and pollutant removal only. 
    "Karst feature" means an area or surficial geologic feature subject to bedrock dissolution so that it is likely to provide a conduit to groundwater, and may include caves, enlarged fractures, mine features, exposed bedrock surfaces, sinkholes, springs, seeps or swallets. 
    "Lightly disturbed site" means a site where an area of land is subjected to minor compaction due to the limited removal of vegetative cover or earthmoving activities. 
    "Maximum extent practicable (MEP)" means a level of implementing best management practices in order to achieve a performance standard specified in this chapter which takes into account the best available technology, cost effectiveness and other competing issues such as human safety and welfare, endangered and threatened resources, historic properties and geographic features. MEP allows flexibility in the way to meet standards and may vary based on the performance standard and site conditions. 
    "New development" means any of the following: 
a.  Structural development, including construction of a new building or other structures. 
b.  Expansion or alteration of an existing structure that results in an increase in the surface dimension of the building or structure. 
c.  Land-disturbing activities; or 
d.  Creation or expansion of impervious surface. 
    "Non-erosive velocity" means a rate of flow of stormwater runoff, usually measured in feet per second, that does not erode soils. Non-erosive velocities vary for individual sites, taking into account topography, soil type, and runoff rates. 
    "Peak flows" means the maximum rate of flow of water at a given point in a channel, watercourse, or conduit resulting from the predetermined storm or flood.
