When the land division includes a 1/2, 1/4, 1/4-1/4, or other such section monument, the monument shall be preserved, fully restored, and/or reset by the subdivider at such subdivider's cost. 
B.  City Acceptance of Dedicated Public Rights-of-Way. As a condition for the acceptance of the dedication of public rights-of-way, the city shall require that all publicly dedicated rights-of-way identified on the plat or certified survey map shall have installed all of the required public improvements as required by this chapter, including, but not limited to, sewerage, storm drainage, water mains and services, grading, electrical and gas mains and services, grading and improvement to the streets and other public ways, sidewalk, street signing, street lighting, traffic control and such other facilities required by the city council and set forth in the approval of the final plat of subdivision or certified survey map. 
(Ord. 445, § 7, 11-2-2010) 
16.32.020 - Subdivider to install improvements. 
    All required public improvements shall be installed by the subdivider at such subdivider's cost. When certain development fees are required prior to development, or when determined necessary by the city council, the subdivider shall be required to enter into a general development agreement in a form provided by the city, prior to the recording of the plat or certified survey map. Among other things, the general development agreement shall include a phasing schedule formulated by the developer and agreed to by the city for all future phases necessary to complete the plat. The subdivider shall agree in the general development agreement to install the required public improvements in accordance with the most current engineering standards and specifications which have been adopted by the city council. Where standards and/or specifications have not been adopted the improvements shall be made in accordance with established engineering practices as designated and approved by the city engineer. 
A.  Detailed Development Agreement. The subdivider shall be required to enter into a detailed development agreement for the entire plat or any phase of a phased plat with the city for land division improvements agreeing to install improvements as herein provided before construction of any improvements and before issuance of any building permit within the plat or applicable. The agreement form shall be provided by the city and may provide for a phasing of public improvements construction, providing such phasing is approved by the city council. 
1.  The city reserves the right to control the phasing through limits, sequence, and/or additional surety so as to provide for continuity of streets, sewers, water mains, and other necessary public improvements within and between the phases. 
2.  The city may place limits on the number of housing units that are allowed for construction per year based upon the provisions of the development phasing plan. 
3.  The city engineer shall review and approve the construction plans, specifications and calculations for the construction of the required public improvements and shall provide a proposed development agreement to the city council for consideration within sixty (60) days of the filing of the necessary materials by the developer. 
B.  Security. The subdivider shall file with such detailed development agreement a performance bond or irrevocable letter of credit in an amount equal to one hundred twenty (120) percent of the estimate of the cost approved by the city engineer as surety to guarantee that such improvements will be completed by the subdivider or such subdivider's contractors not later than fourteen (14) months after the date the public improvements for which security is provided have been substantially complete. However, the subdivider may elect, with the approval of the city, to install the improvements in construction phases provided that: the phases are specified in the detailed development agreement for land division improvements; that the developer submits security in an amount equal to one hundred twenty (120) percent of the estimate approved by the city engineer sufficient for the construction of all phases of construction and park improvement in progress; that the developer records deed restrictions approved by the city attorney which specify that the lots which are included in future construction phases of the land division will not be transferred or sold unless the city's approval is obtained; that the subdivider minimize grading and other disturbances to lands included in future construction phases in order to prevent erosion and that erosion control plans and measures submitted and approved herein shall address the individual phases of construction. The time limit for completion of phased improvement program shall take into account the needs and desires of the city and adjacent property owners for street and other improvements to serve lands adjacent to and within the land division. As work progresses on installation of improvements constructed as part of the detailed development agreement, the city engineer, upon written request from the subdivider from time to time, is authorized to recommend a reduction in the amount of surety as hereinafter provided. When portions of construction (water, sanitary sewer, street, sidewalk, greenway or other improvements) are completed by the subdivider, and determined acceptable by the city engineer, the city administrator is authorized, upon submission of lien waivers and affidavits by the subdivider's contractors, to reduce the amount of surety. The amount of surety remaining shall be equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimate of the city engineer of costs of work remaining to be completed and accepted. When the work on the major components of construction has been substantially completed except for work which cannot be completed because of weather conditions or other reasons which in the judgment of the city engineer are valid for noncompletion, the finance officer is authorized to accept a reduction in the amount of surety to an amount in the estimate of the city engineer, sufficient to cover the work remaining to be completed. As a further guarantee that all obligations under contract for work on the development are satisfied, the contractor and subcontractors who are to be engaged in the construction of utilities or street improvements on the street right-of-way to be dedicated shall be approved for such work by the city engineer prior to commencing construction. 
C.  Improvement Guarantee. The subdivider shall include in such detailed development agreement an instrument of public improvement guarantee by personal guarantee, thereby guaranteeing maintenance, repair, replacement by the developer of such public improvements which deteriorate or fail to meet performance or operating standards within one year of completing, or acceptance by the city, whichever is later, or as otherwise provided in the detailed development agreement, and payment of any penalties which may be incurred as a result thereof, equal to fifteen (15) percent of the city engineer's estimate of the cost of the public improvements. If within one year after the date of final acceptance of any public improvement by the city council (or such longer period of time as may be prescribed by laws or regulations or by the terms of any special guarantee required by the terms of such detailed development agreement as may be necessary due to the phasing of the construction of public improvements), any work on any public improvement is found to be defective, the subdivider shall remove it and replace it with nondefective work in accordance with written instructions given by the city engineer. If the subdivider does not promptly comply with the terms of such instructions, or in an emergency where delay would cause serious risk of loss or damage, the city may cause the removal and replacement of such defective work and charge all direct, indirect and consequential costs of such removal and replacement to the subdivider. 
D.  The subdivider is responsible for requesting in writing for acceptance of the improvements and to start the one-year guarantee period when the improvements are completed. All improvements with the exception of the binder course of asphalt shall be guaranteed for one year. The binder course of asphalt shall be guaranteed until the surface course of asphalt is placed, at which point in time the one-year guarantee will begin for the surface course of asphalt. The subdivider is responsible for requesting in writing for a one-year guarantee inspection to relieve the subdivider of maintenance of any improvements deemed defective after one year and to release the instrument of surety. 
E.  Designated Projects Manager. The subdivider shall designate a project manager who shall be readily available on the project site during the construction of the required public improvements. The project manager shall be granted authority on behalf of the subdivider to make decisions related to the construction of the required public improvements as they may arise during the course of the construction. The project manager shall also be responsible for the scheduling and coordination of the required work to construct the required improvements. Correspondence with, or verbal orders to the designated project manager shall have the same authority as with the subdivider directly. 
(Ord. 640, § 1, 4-19-2016; Ord. 555, § 1, 1-10-2014) 
16.32.030 - Reserved for future use. 
16.32.040 - Extra-sized and off-site facilities. 
    In order to serve future developments, the city may require proposed developments to provide utilities that are oversized and installed to depths beyond that required to serve the proposed development. The city will require developments to install water mains up to twelve (12) inches in diameter without additional cost to the utility owner. Sanitary sewers shall be installed to diameters up to twelve (12) inches and to depths of sixteen (16) feet (as measured from the finished grade to the pipe invert) without additional cost to the utility owner. 
A.  The city shall pay the developer for the cost of additional depth when the request for additional depth results in the following additional costs to the developer: 
1.  When the sanitary sewer depth to serve the development plus five feet exceeds sixteen (16) feet in depth as measured to the invert. 
2.  When the developer can demonstrate that the additional depth will encounter rock or water conditions that would not have been encountered at the depth required to serve the development. 
3.  Storm sewers, storm channels, retention and detention facilities will be addressed on a case-by-case basis. As a general rule, the developer will be allowed to recover costs for extra/oversize. 
4.  The city may also require and may pay for extra, oversize (except streets), overdepth and off-site improvements to accommodate future development. 
B.  The developer will not be compensated for additional depth under the following conditions: 
1.  Sanitary sewers extended to the perimeter of the proposed land division at minimum grade and when the depth is equal to or less than sixteen (16) feet in total depth as measured to the invert. Sewers may not be laid at greater than minimum grade unless approved by the city engineer. 
2.  If the depth required in order to provide service to the development exceeds sixteen (16) feet. 
3.  Storm sewers extended to the perimeter of the proposed land division at minimum grade and when the depth is equal to or less than ten (10) feet as measured to the invert. 
C.  The developer at no additional cost to the city or upstream development shall install sanitary sewers up to and including twelve (12) inches in diameter. 
D.  The developer at no additional cost to the water and light commission or upstream development shall install water main up to and including twelve (12) inches in diameter. 
E.  When any public improvements of adequate capacity are not available at the boundary of proposed land division, the city, or its duly authorized representative, shall require, as a prerequisite to approval of a final plat or certified survey, assurances that such improvement extensions shall be provided as follows in accordance with the following sections: 
1.  Design Capacity. All improvements within or entering or leaving the proposed development shall be installed to satisfy the service requirements for the entire service or drainage area in which the development is located and the improvements shall be of sufficient capacity to handle the expected development of the overall service area involved. 
2.  Lift Stations. Where sanitary or storm sewer lift stations and force mains are required to lift sewerage to the gravity system, the subdivider shall have plans, profiles, specifications, and estimated operation and maintenance costs prepared for the installation of such facilities to the city engineer's requirements. Equipment similar to existing city equipment shall be utilized whenever possible. The installation, inspection, supervision, and engineering fees for lift stations and/or force mains shall be paid for by the subdivider unless otherwise determined and agreed upon by the city council. Gravity sanitary sewer service shall be employed whenever determined by the city engineer to be feasibly accessible. 
16.32.050 - Site grading. 
A.  The subdivider shall be required to grade the full land division in accordance with the requirements of Section 16.28.080. Prior to receiving acceptance of the public improvements, the subdivider shall submit for approval a master grading map for the limits of the land division phase of development. This map shall show the design spot elevations at all lot corners, break points, and low points. Both an electronic copy and hard copy of this map shall be submitted in a format acceptable to the engineering department. 
B.  Grading of the site may commence after a developer's agreement has been approved and signed by all pertinent parties. If the subdivider wishes to commence with land disturbance activities prior to the finalization of the developer's agreement the subdivider must receive an approved erosion control permit and all required regulatory permits. Surety in an amount acceptable to the city engineer shall be submitted along with an insurance certificate acceptable to the city's finance department prior to the commencement of any land disturbance activities. Grading shall not be allowed on the land development until the land division development agreement is approved, or until the subdivider receives an erosion control permit, provides an insurance certificate, all required regulatory permits and surety covering the intended work. Grading operations occurring prior to the plat being recorded and construction plan approval shall be performed at the subdivider's risk. 
16.32.060 - Recapture agreement. 
    The city may at the discretion of the city council enter into a written recapture agreement with the subdivider which provides for the recapture costs of public improvements from those properties benefiting from the improvements. The recapture agreement shall prohibit development on those properties until payment has been made. The subdivider may contract directly with adjacent property owners and/or subdividers of adjacent land for reimbursement of the oversized and/or off-site improvements constructed. 
    Such recapture agreement shall provide that the subdivider be reimbursed for those oversized improvements constructed within the proposed land division, but which are oversized to serve lands beyond the boundaries of the land division or other lands within the subdivider's control. Such reimbursement shall be only for the actual additional cost of constructing the oversized improvements within the boundaries of the land division and shall not provide for payment of any interest. Only land divisions within Phase I of the staged development plan for public facilities (Map 13-3) identified in the city's comprehensive development plan are eligible to proceed under this provision. 
16.32.070 - Streets. 
A.  Grading. The subdivider shall be required to grade the full width of right-of-way of all roadways, alleys, pedestrian and/or bike paths, access easements, and other public ways required to be improved as a result of the platting whether or not such public ways are within the boundaries of the plat. Such grading shall be made to the required grade and cross section and of the street, and of materials approved by the city engineer. 
B.  Roadways. The subdivider shall be required to provide improved roadways to meet the following criteria for each street classification:

    Required right-of-way width and pavement width may be increased above the minimum standards or reduced below the minimum standards when deemed appropriate by the city engineer. Appropriateness shall be determined based on criteria including, but not limited to, the reduction of environmental impacts due to runoff from impervious cover, the need to calm traffic, and reduced long-term costs for street construction, reconstruction, and long-term maintenance. 
1.  Pavement Designs. The subdivider shall submit to the city engineer for review, alternative bituminous street pavement designs based upon the AASHTO structural number design method (interim guide) and shall include consideration of construction year and design year anticipated traffic loads, soils support values, a 20-year design life, a minimum bituminous pavement serviceability index of 2.5, and a regional factor of 3.0, and summarized as follows: 
SN = a1D1 + a2D2 + a3D3 + .... 
Where 
a = the coeff for each structural material layer 
D = the final design thickness of each structural material layer (in inches) 
Chemical stabilizations will not be considered in the pavement design calculations. The coefficients for geotextile fabrics shall not exceed eighty percent (80%) of the manufacturer's published values when used in the design calculations.
